questions.text: A 6-month-old infant visits the clinic with complaints of frequent respiratory infections. On examination, a cleft palate, difficulty in breathing, cyanosis, and a significant delay in growth are found. A defect involving which of the following structures is associated with this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pharyngeal pouch 3 and 4

  • This patient with frequent respiratory infections, cleft palate, difficulty in breathing, and a significant delay in growth, most likely has DiGeorge syndrome.
  • DiGeorge syndrome is due to defects of pharyngeal pouches 3 and 4.
    • Pouch 3 compromised → No thymus → Cell-mediated immunity decreases → Severe bacterial infections
    • Pouch 3 & 4 compromised → Absent or poorly developed parathyroid → low PTH → Hypocalcemia.

Option A: Pharyngeal pouch 1

  • Pharyngeal pouch 1 develops into
    • Eustachian tube
    • Middle ear cavity
  • Any defect in the development/formation of the pouch will result in a defect in the Eustachian tube and middle ear cavity.

Option B: Pharyngeal pouch 2

  • Pharyngeal pouch 2 forms endodermal epithelium for the palatine tonsil, with no role in developing the thymus.

Option D: Pharyngeal pouch 5

  • Pharyngeal pouch 5 forms superior parathyroid with no role in the thymus development.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common congenital heart defect?
questions.solution:
Option B: Membranous VSD

  • The most common of all congenital cardiac malformations seen clinically are membranous VSDs.

Option A: Persistent truncus arteriosus

  • Partial development of the aorticopulmonary septum due to the absence of migration of neural crest cells to the truncus arteriosus region will cause persistent truncus arteriosus (PTA).

Option C: Common ventricle

  • This is a congenital function in which one of the two ventricles is functional
  • This condition is rare

Option D: Foramen secundum defect

  • It is a genetic defect
  • Since the question asks for the most common defect, the answer is membranous VSD

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department after a fall from a tree house 1 hour ago. He complains of pain in his left arm. Physical examination reveals reduced sensations over the lateral part of the arm and weakness of abduction at 15-90 degrees. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Injury to the lateral cord of the brachial plexus
Tearing of the Teres major muscle
Inferior dislocation of the head of the humerus

questions.solution:
Option D: Inferior dislocation of the head of the humerus

  • The patient presents with injury to the axillary nerve.
  • Inferior dislocation of the head of the humerus may damage the axillary nerve.
  • The axillary nerve arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.
  • It runs through the quadrangular space accompanied by the posterior humeral circumflex vessels around the surgical neck of the humerus.
  • It supplies sensations to the lateral part of the arm via the upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm.
  • It supplies the deltoid and teres minor.
  • An articular branch supplies the glenohumeral joint.
  • The deltoid is responsible for 15-90 degrees of abduction.
  • Damage to the axillary nerve causes the loss of both these functions along with the flattened shape of the deltoid/shoulder.

Option A: Injury to the lateral cord of the brachial plexus

  • The lateral cord of the brachial plexus gives rise to the lateral root of the median nerve, the musculocutaneous nerve, the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, and the lateral pectoral nerve.
  • The lateral cord branches contribute to the medianMedian Nerve from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages"> and musculocutaneous nerve
  • The musculocutaneous nerve innervates the biceps brachii, coracobrachialis, and brachialis muscle
  • It is, therefore, primarily responsible for the flexion of the forearm.

Option B: Supracondylar fracture of humerus

  • Supracondylar humeral fractures are a common pediatric elbow injury but rarely seen in adults.
  • The most common mechanism of injury is falling on an outstretched hand with the elbow in extension (a small percentage occurs from landing directly onto a flexed elbow).
  • On examination, gross deformity, swelling, limited elbow movement (secondary to pain), and ecchymosis of the anterior cubital fossa may be present.
  • Nerve palsies are common with supracondylar fractures, with neuropraxia rates around 10%; however, this rarely results in permanent damage.
  • The anterior interosseous nerve is most commonly affected by the initial injury; however, ulnar nerve palsy is the most common postoperative complication.
  • The axillary nerve terminates before reaching the elbow, hence has no role in elbow injuries.

Option C: Tearing of the Teres major muscle

  • The primary function of the Teres major muscle is to produce arm movements on the shoulder joint.
  • Contraction of the muscle pulls the humerus posteriorly (extension) and rotates it medially towards the trunk (internal rotation).
  • It contributes to the stabilization of the shoulder joint.

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient came to your consultant’s clinic complaining of pain over the penis and posterior surface of the scrotum for the past few months. He is a known case of IBS with constipation and is on and off medications for the same. You, being an intern, ask about any history of trauma/fall/surgery as you suspect pudendal nerve involvement which has the root value:-
questions.solution:
• Pudendal nerve arises from the sacral plexus in the pelvis( S2- S4).
  • Pudendal nerve is nerve of perineum.
  • External urethral sphincter is supplied by the pudendal nerve.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male complained of left flank pain, decreased urine output, and painful micturition. On diagnostic evaluation, a USG shows that the patient has a large stone that may require open surgery. Concerning essential surgical anatomy, a trainee surgical resident must know which of the following structure is unrelated to the ureter?
questions.solution:
Option C: Quadratus lumborum

  • The left ureter is related posteriorly to the psoas major muscle (not quadratus lumborum).
  • Posterior relations: The ureters run anterior to the psoas major muscle and bifurcation of the common iliac artery.
  • Anterior relation: Gonadal vessels cross the ureters anteriorly (medial to lateral) and descend along with them.
  • Medially the right ureter is related to the inferior vena cava, and the left ureter is related to the inferior mesenteric vein.

Option A: Sigmoid mesentery

  • It is the fold of the peritoneum.
  • It attaches the sigmoid colon to the pelvic wall.
  • The left ureter is related to the inferior mesenteric vein.

Option B: Bifurcation of common iliac artery

  • It comes from the aortic bifurcation at the level of L4.
  • The common iliac artery bifurcates anterior to the sacroiliac joint.
  • Both the ureters run anterior to the psoas major muscle and bifurcation of the common iliac artery.

Option D: Gonadal vessels

  • These vessels carry the blood from the gonads to the heart.
  • These vessels ascend into the abdomen along the psoas muscle anterior to the ureter.
  • Gonadal vessels cross the ureters anteriorly (medial to lateral) and descend along with them.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in a positive Trendelenburg sign in the right limb?

choices.text: Difficulty in standing from a sitting position
The left side of the pelvis droops or sags when he attempts to stand with his weight, supported by the right lower limb.
The right side of the pelvis droops or sags when he attempts to stand with his weight, supported just by the left lower limb.
Weakened flexion of the right hip

questions.solution:
Option B: The left side of the pelvis droops or sags when he attempts to stand with his weight supported just by the right lower limb

  • The patient suffered damage to the superior gluteal nerve in the motorcycle accident on the right side
  • Injury involving the superior gluteus nerve leads to characteristic motor loss with paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles.
  • If the patient is asked to stand on the limb on the injured side, the pelvis will be lowered on the opposite side, indicating a positive Trendelenburg test.
  • The gluteal duct, or the wobbling that results from this injury, is characterized by the pelvis sinking to the unaffected side as the opposite leg is raised.
  • When stepping forward, the affected person leans on the injured side by lifting the healthy limb off the floor. The uninjured limb then swings forward.

 

Option A: Difficulty in standing from a sitting position

  • The extensor muscle of the hip gluteus maximus is responsible for standing from a sitting position and is innervated by the inferior gluteal nerve. This patient has suffered an injury to the superior gluteal nerve; hence the positive Trendelenburg sign

Option C: The right side of the pelvis droops or sags when he attempts to stand with his weight supported just by the left lower limb.

  • The patient suffered an injury on the right limb, so the right superior gluteal nerve is damaged; hence the opposite side the left side will droop or sag when he attempts to stand on the right side. If he stands on the left leg, the right side will not droop

Option D: Weakened flexion of the right hip

  • Hip flexion is done by the quadriceps muscle innervated by the femoral nerve and is not injured in the accident. If it was injured. It would show a loss of extension at the knee

questions.text: Which ganglia is absent in the suspected disorder of a 28-year-old G2P1 mother's newborn who presents with no passage of meconium for 36 hours, bilious vomiting, the abdomen distended with hypoactive bowel sounds and a reducible umbilical hernia, tight anal sphincter, and explosive passage of air and feces on the removal of the examining finger?
questions.solution:
Option A: Auerbach's plexus

  • The above given is a case of Hirschsprung disease.
  • No meconium with bilious vomiting is suggestive.
  • The GIT mucosa consists of the following layers:
    • Mucosa
    • Sub-mucosa
    • Muscularis propria
      • Inner circular
      • Outer longitudinal
    • Auerbach's plexus lies between the inner circular and outer longitudinal layer, and it is responsible for peristalsis or motility.

Option B: Meissner's plexus

  • Sub mucous/Meissner's plexus (sensory).
  • Ganglia missing Auerbach’s >> Meissner’s plexus in Hirschsprung disease.
  • Achalasia cardia: Failure of LES to relax due to degeneration of inhibitory neurons (containing NO and VIP) in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus of the esophageal wall.

Option C: Lumbar plexus

  • It is formed by the L1 to L5 part of the anterior rami and also T12.
  • It supplies motor and sensory innervation to the pelvis and lower limb.
  • Diseases involving the lumbar plexus cause a problem in the pelvic region and lower limb.

Option D: Sacral plexus

  • Sacral plexus disorder can cause problems in the gluteal, tibial, sciatic, and peroneal nerve regions.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female presents with sudden changes in speech characterized by slow, limited utterances but with preserved understanding and task performance. Weakness in the right half of the face is noted. Suspecting a lesion or loss of blood supply, which Brodmann's area is implicated in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: 44

 

  • The patient has ischaemic injury to left inferior frontal gyrus affecting Brodmann area (44), and motor homunculus for face.
  • Motor aphasia is due to a lesion in Broca’s area which belongs to Brodmann’s area 44, (inferior frontal gyrus).
  • The weakness of the right side of the face suggests the lesion to be in the left inferior frontal gyrus (motor homunculus for face).

  • Aphasia is a condition that results from disturbance to parts of the brain that are responsible for language.
  • A disturbance to one or more of the language centers of the brain results in aphasia. A stroke is the most frequent reason for brain damage. A blood clot that blocks blood flow to a portion of the brain causes a stroke.
  • It can be ischemic or hemorrhagic in nature.
  • There are two main categories of aphasia: These are fluent and non-fluent, and there are several types within these groups.
  • Damage to Wernicke's area = Wernicke's aphasia (lack of meaning), also known as fluent aphasia.
  • People with Wernicke's aphasia may speak in long, complete sentences that have no meaning, adding unnecessary words and even creating made-up words.
  • Damage to Broca's area = motor aphasia (vocal system couldn't emit words), also known as non-fluent aphasia.
  • People with Broca's aphasia may understand speech and know what they want to say, but they frequently speak in short phrases that are produced with huge effort.

Option A: 22

  • Area 22 is Wernicke's sensory area, the superior temporal gyrus.
  • Wernicke is wordy but makes no sense.
  • Patients do not have insight.

Option B: 17

  • Area 17: It is the occipital visual cortex.

Option C: 41

  • Area 41,42: It is the temporal auditory cortex.
  • In areas 41 and 42, the primary auditory cortex includes the gyrus of Heschl on the upper surface of the superior temporal lobe. It is also known as the transverse temporal gyrus, which is entirely hidden within the Sylvian fissure.
  • The secondary auditory area helps in the recognition and interpretation of sounds on the basis of past experience.

questions.text: A baby was born to a young woman whose pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios and was admitted to the intensive care unit because of repeated episodes of vomiting, which was containing bile. The stomach was moderately distended, and only small amounts of meconium passed through the anus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Duodenal atresia

  • This baby has duodenal atresia distal to the opening of the common bile duct.
  • It is defined as either absence or complete occlusion of the duodenal lumen.
  • This leads to reflux of bile and its presence in the vomit.
  • Presents with vomiting in few hours of birth, delayed passage of meconium, and distended upper abdomen.
  • On the x-ray of the abdomen, there is a double bubble sign, and the distal bowel is gasless.
  • Polyhydramnios made pregnancy more difficult, as the duodenal atresia prevented the passage of amniotic fluid into the intestine for absorption.
  • Treatment is surgical, but before that patient is managed by providing parenteral nutrition through the central catheter, gastric decompression, fluid replacement, and electrolytes balance.
  • This is not a case of esophageal atresia because, in this case, there is no bile in vomiting.

Option B: Esophageal atresia

  •  There is no bile in vomiting in cases of esophageal atresia.

Option C: Pancreatic divisum

  •  Despite being the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas, pancreas divisum goes undetected because it causes no problem.

Option D: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

  •  There is no bile in vomiting in cases of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male involved in a road accident undergoes a head CT, revealing an incidental tumor in the base of the skull, obscuring part of the jugular foramen. The Xth cranial nerve involvement is suspected. Which of the following muscles' actions cannot confirm this involvement through testing?
questions.solution:
Option B: Stylopharyngeus

  • All muscles of the pharynx are supplied by the Xth nerve, except the stylopharyngeus.
  • The Glossopharyngeal nerve supplies the stylopharyngeus.
  • Stylopharyngeal muscles are elevators of the pharynx.
  • Hence, testing the action of the stylopharyngeus cannot be used to test the vagus nerve.
  • Vagus nerve also supplies the heart, lungs, and upper gastrointestinal tract.

​​​​​​​Option A: Palatopharyngeus

  • Vagus nerve supplies palatopharyngeus
  • The Passavant’s ridge is also often termed as Passavant’s fold, formed by the palatopharyngeal muscle.
  • The ridge can be observed just inferior to the pharyngeal tonsils and posterior and inferior to the pharyngeal opening of the Eustachian tube.

Option C: Salpingopharyngeus

  • The vagus nerve supplies this muscle
  • This muscle elevates the pharynx

 Option D: Middle constrictor

  • It is a pharyngeal constrictor muscle and is supplied by the vagus nerve.

questions.text: A 24-year-old cyclist participated in Tour de France competition. While making a sharp turn downslope, the cyclist suffered a fall and injured his right shoulder. In the hospital, an X-ray was taken, and it revealed that the patient had a fracture of the neck of the humerus. Which of the following is the most likely nerve involved?
questions.solution:
Option D: Axillary nerve

  • Axillary nerve (C5, C6) runs freely in the loose fatty tissue in the axilla, then it is lateral to the radial nerve, posterior to the axillary artery, and anterior to subscapularis to pass almost horizontally through the quadrilateral tunnel, where it is accompanied by the posterior circumflex humeral vessels transverses a quadrangular space bounded above by subscapularis (anteriorly) and teres minor (posteriorly) below by teres major medially by the long head of triceps and laterally by the surgical neck of the humerus.
  • It divides the space into anterior and posterior branches.
  • The anterior branch curves around the neck of the humerus with the posterior circumflex humeral vessels, deep to the deltoid, to reach the anterior part of the muscle.
  • The nerve often consists of two or more thin filaments that supply the anterior deltoid at the level of the anterior border of the acromion. It gives off a few small cutaneous branches that pierce the deltoid and ramify in the skin over its lower part.
  • The posterior branch courses medially and posteriorly along the attachment of the lateral head of the triceps, inferior to the glenoid rim. It usually lies medial to the branch in the quadrangular space.
  • It gives off the nerve to teres minor and the upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm at the lateral edge of the attachment of the long head of the triceps.
  • It innervates teres minor and deltoid, and the skin overlies the deltoid's lower half on the shoulder's lateral aspect.
  • Dislocation of the shoulder or fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus can damage the axillary nerve.

Effects of damage:

  • The deltoid is paralyzed, leading to loss of power of abduction up to 90° at the shoulder
  • Sensory loss over the lower half of the deltoid.

Option A: Musculocutaneous nerve

  • It is caused by upper trunk compression, which causes decreased biceps reflex, and loss of forearm flexion and supination; also, loss of sensation occurs over the radial and dorsal forearm.

Option B: Median

  • Supracondylar fracture of humerus causes proximal lesion of the nerve
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome and wrist laceration causes distal lesion of the nerve.
  • Present with “Ape hand” and “Hand of benediction”; loss of wrist flexion and function of the lateral two lumbricals, opponens pollicis, abductor pollicis brevis, flexor pollicis brevis.
  • Loss of sensation over thenar eminence and dorsal and palmar aspects of lateral three-and-a-half fingers with proximal lesions.

Option C: Ulnar

  • The nerve root value of the ulnar nerve is C8-T1
  • The fracture of the medial epicondyle of the humerus (proximal lesion); Fracture of the hook of the hamate (distal lesion) from a fall on an outstretched hand, or compression of the nerve against hamate resting on the handlebar during cycling.
  • The proximal lesion causes ulnar claw hand on digit extension and radial deviation of the wrist upon flexion.
  • The distal lesion causes decreased flexion of ulnar fingers, abduction and adduction of fingers (interossei), thumb adduction, actions of ulnar 2 lumbrical muscles, and loss of sensation over ulnar 1 and a half fingers, including hypothenar eminence.

questions.text: A pediatric surgeon resects a possible malignant mass from a newborn baby's liver with cerebral palsy. The surgeon cuts the round ligament of the liver during the operation. A fibrous remnant from which of the following fetal vessels has been severed?
questions.solution:
Option C: Left umbilical vein

  • The left umbilical vein becomes the round ligament of the liver after birth. So this is injured during the surgery.

Remanent of the embryonic structures:

  • The left umbilical vein becomes the round ligament of the liver after birth.
  • The right umbilical vein is not left a fibrous remnant because it degenerates during the early embryonic period.
  • The ductus venosus forms the ligamentum venosum, and the ductus arteriosus forms the ligamentum arteriosum.
  • The umbilical artery forms the medial umbilical ligament.

Option A: Ductus venosus

  • The ductus venosus forms the ligamentum venosum, and the ductus arteriosus forms the ligamentum arteriosum.

Option B: Ductus arteriosus

  • The ductus venosus forms the ligamentum venosum, and the ductus arteriosus forms the ligamentum arteriosum.

Option D: Right umbilical vein

  • The right umbilical vein is not left a fibrous remnant because it degenerates during the early embryonic period.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with a complaint of dizziness and palpitations for one day. He gives a history of attending a bachelor party where he drank alcohol and played a few games. The physical examination shows no abnormality. There is a narrow QRS complex and indiscernible P waves on ECG. Which of the following is true in a patient with damaged cardiac muscle during the T-P interval in an ECG?

choices.text: The entire ventricle is depolarized except for the damaged cardiac muscle
The entire ventricle is repolarized except for the damaged cardiac muscle

questions.solution:
Option D: The entire ventricle is repolarised except for the damaged cardiac muscle

  • In a patient with a damaged ventricle, the only area depolarised is the damaged muscle, which is reflected at the point of the T-P interval.
  • Therefore, the remainder of the ventricle is repolarised.
  • The entire ventricle is depolarised in a patient with a damaged cardiac muscle or in a patient with a normal cardiac muscle and is reflected at the J point.
  • Repolarisation will not happen in the area of the damaged heart, but that area remains depolarised at all times.
  • After the ventricular muscle has become depolarised, about 0.15 seconds later, repolarisation begins and proceeds until complete at about 0.35 seconds.
  • This repolarisation causes the T wave in the electrocardiogram.

Option A: The entire ventricle is depolarised

  • The entire ventricle is repolarised except for the damaged cardiac muscle.
  • In a patient with a damaged ventricle, the only area depolarised is the damaged muscle, which is reflected at the point of the T-P interval.

Option B: The entire ventricle is depolarised except for the damaged cardiac muscle

  • In a patient with a damaged ventricle, the only area depolarised is the damaged muscle, which is reflected at the point of the T-P interval.

Option C: The entire ventricle is repolarised

  • The entire ventricle is repolarised except for the damaged cardiac muscle.
  • Repolarisation will not happen in the area of the damaged heart, but that area remains depolarised at all times.

questions.text: Intrathoracic pressure influences venous return and consequently cardiac output and arterial pressure. Inspiration drops intrathoracic pressure, causing a reflex increase in heart rate. Exhalation reverses the above steps. Which among the given options would produce the most negative intrathoracic pressure?
questions.solution:
Option D: Muller's maneuver

  • The negative intrathoracic pressure increases transmural pressure of the cardiac chambers (which increases left ventricular afterload and oxygen demand) and dilatation of the cardiac chambers, both predisposing to atrioventricular arrhythmias
  • In this maneuver, the patient attempts to inhale with his mouth closed and his nostrils plugged, which leads to a collapse of the airway.
  • Introducing a flexible fiberoptic scope into the hypo-pharynx to obtain a view, the examiner may witness the collapse and identify weakened sections of the airway.
  • Muller maneuver helps us to evaluate the level and degree of upper airway narrowing, and it has also been shown to be a predictive value for OSAS surgery.
  • Muller maneuver is a beneficial technique for deciding the type of surgical procedure we use in OSAS patients.

Under quiet breathing →

  • At the start of inspiration, normal ITP → -5 cm H2O
  • At the end of inspiration, normal ITP → -7 cm H2O

Forceful breathing ITP: - ·

  • deep sigh or a yawn-30 cm H2O
  • The first cry of a neonate (first breath ITP) → -60cmH2O

Muller's maneuver

  •  - 100cm H2O
  • Max negative ITP
  • It is the counterpart of the Valsalva maneuver
  • Muller maneuver is a forced inspiratory effort against a closed glottis.

Option A: Yawning

  • Yawning is a complex event that includes a significant transient decrease in intrathoracic pressure that is highly effective in increasing venous return (especially when combined with stretching). Deep sigh or a yawn- 30 cm H2O

Option B: First cry of a neonate

  • Crying also has significant hemodynamic effects in the newborn, and the high intrathoracic pressures generated during the cry make it clinically similar to a Valsalva maneuver performed by adults. The first cry of a neonate (first breath ITP) → -60cmH2O

Option C: High-pitch opera singing

  • High-pitch opera singing does not have the highest negative intrathoracic pressure.

questions.text: In a physiology seminar, a group of medical students gives a presentation on renal physiology. They elaborate on the process of filtration and reabsorption. Filtration is the mass movement of water and solutes from plasma to the renal tubule that occurs in the renal corpuscle. About 20% of the plasma volume passing through the glomerulus at any given time is filtered. This means that the kidneys filter about 180 liters of fluid daily. Thus, the entire plasma volume (about 3 liters) is filtered 60 times daily. A substance is present in a concentration of 2 mg% in the afferent arteriole and 0 mg% in the efferent. A true statement about the substance is?

choices.text: It is freely filtered at the glomerulus
Impermeable in the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
Option A: It is freely filtered at the glomerulus

  • This is only a hypothetical situation. The filtration fraction is about 20%. It means that of the total plasma passing through the glomerulus per unit of time, about 20% is filtered out. Suppose a substance has zero concentration in the efferent arteriole. In that case, it means all that substance was freely and completely filtered out in the plasma that formed the glomerular filtrate.

Option B: Secreted in the cortical nephron

  • A substance is secreted in the nephrons after the filtration in glomeruli. This substance has a 0mg% concentration left in the plasma. Hence it cannot be secreted further.

Option C: Absorbed in the PCT

  • The concentration of 0mg% in the efferent arteriole represents free filtration of a substance.
  • Reabsorbed substances would lead to increased concentration in peritubular capillaries (not in efferent arteriole)

Option D: Impermeable in the loop of Henle

  • If a substance is impermeable in the loop of Henle, it cannot be reabsorbed.

  • However, a concentration of 0mg% in efferent arteriole represents that it is freely filtered.

  • It does not give information about the permeability of the loop of Henle

questions.text: All of the following developmental events depend on the production of maternal or fetal glucocorticoids EXCEPT?

choices.text: Production of surfactant by type II alveolar cells

questions.solution:
Option A: Induction of thymic involution

  • Thymic involution has no association with fetal or maternal glucocorticoids. The thymic involution process includes blockage of T-cell receptor gene rearrangement, decreased self-peptide MHC molecules, and depletion of T-cell progenitor. 

Option B: Production of surfactant by type II alveolar cells

  • Fetal and maternal steroids are of great value in the synthesis and maturation of surfactant from type II alveolar cells.

Option C: Functional thyroid

  • Before the second trimester, most of the T4 in the fetus is maternal. Fetal production of thyrotropin (TSH) and T4 begin to increase in the second trimester, concurrent with the development of the hypothalamic-pituitary portal system 

Option D: Functional hypothalamic-pituitary axis

  • Maternal glucocorticoids may have a role in the functional hypothalamic-pituitary axis in the fetus.

questions.text: A clinical study is conducted to determine the actions of an unknown test solution on red blood cell volume. One milliliter of heparinized human blood is pipetted into 100 milliliters of the test solution and mixed. Samples are taken and analyzed immediately before and at 1-second intervals after mixing. The results show that red blood cells placed into the test solution immediately swell and burst. Which of the following best describes the tonicity and osmolarity of the test solution?

choices.text: Hypertonic; could be hyperosmotic, hypo-osmotic, or iso-osmotic
Hypertonic; must be hyperosmotic or hypo-osmotic
Hypotonic; could be hyperosmotic, hypo-osmotic, or iso-osmotic

questions.solution:
• Depending on the osmotic status, the organism may face consequences, if it does not adapt to its environment by some mechanism.
  • Hypoosmotic environment: Swelling and bursting.
  • Isosmotic environment: Suitable for survival
  • Hyperosmotic environment: Shrinkage.
  • Tonicity and osmolarity are different.
  • Osmolarity is merely another measure of solute concentration.
  • Tonicity depends on the cell membrane and the solute and is determined by the behavior of the cells. The fact that red blood cells placed into the test solution gained volume (swelled) indicates that the test solution is hypotonic.
  • In contrast, the osmolarity of the test solution cannot be determined by the behavior of the cells.
  • Tonicity takes into consideration only non-penetrating substances whereas osmolarity includes both penetrating and non-penetrating and is regardless of the permeability of the substance.

questions.text: In a 40-year-old female, total blood flow to all the muscles is 800 ml/min, her arterial pO2 is 90 mmHg, and her arterial pCO2 is 50 mmHg. Now, her sympathetic system is activated, decreasing blood flow to 400 ml/min to all the muscles. What will happen to Venous pO2 and Venous pCO2?
questions.solution:
Option A: ↓ Venous pO2  ↑ Venous pCO2

  • Sympathetic stimulation results in vasoconstriction, which causes a redistribution in cardiac output to the muscles. Still, due to no change in metabolism, there is an increase in oxygen diffusion from the blood, which lowers venous pO2. Still, simultaneously it also decreases the flushing out of carbon dioxide from the blood, increasing the venous pCO2.
  • Oxygen supply at tissue levels must be maintained due to high aerobic activity.
  • The diffusion of oxygen is crucial for survival.
  • The partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) results from the balance between oxygen consumption and delivery.
  • The delivery of oxygen depends on each organ tissue's metabolic needs.
  • Certain pathological conditions, e.g. diabetes, stroke etc., can result in a decrease in pO2.
  • On the contrary, the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) is a marker for adequate alveolar ventilation.

Option B: ↑ Venous pO2 ↓ Venous pCO2

  • This condition may be seen in polycythemia.
  • This condition is not seen with sympathetic stimulation.

Option C: ↔ Venous pO2 ↑ Venous pCO2

  • This condition is not seen with sympathetic stimulation.

Option D: ↓ Venous pO2 ↔ Venous pCO2

  • This condition may be seen in aerobic exercise due to the shunting of blood from non-metabolically active sites resulting in greater oxygen extraction.
  • pCO2 does not increase during exercise.
  • This condition is not seen with sympathetic stimulation.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to the physician’s office asking for dietary instructions. He eats a low-carbohydrate meal rich in proteins containing the amino acids that stimulate insulin secretion. Which response accounts for the absence of hypoglycemia?
questions.solution:
Option D: Stimulation of glucagon secretion.

  • This man consumes a low-carbohydrate meal rich in proteins containing amino acids that stimulate insulin secretion.
  • The increased amount of amino acids, particularly glucogenic amino acids: alanine, serine, glycine, cysteine, and threonine, are major stimulators of glucagon secretion.
  • A protein meal and infusion of various amino acids increase glucagon secretion. These amino acids get converted into the liver under the influence of glucagon. This effect is also important since the amino acids stimulate insulin secretion, and the secreted glucagon prevents the development of hypoglycemia. In contrast, insulin promotes the storage of absorbed carbohydrates and lipids.

Option A: Suppression of GH

  • Consumption of amino acids also stimulates the secretion of the growth hormone. It does not cause suppression of growth hormone.

Option B: Suppression of somatomedin C secretion

  • Also called the insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1). Diet rich in amino acids increases the release of growth hormone, and subsequently, somatomedin C. Stimulation of somatomedin C facilitates the growth effects of growth hormone.

Option C: Stimulation of cortisol secretion

  • When decreased carbohydrate intake occurs, corticotropin is released from the adenohypophysis, which stimulates cortisol production. The cortisol mobilizes the proteins from all cells to use the amino acids to form glucose. This will lead to hyperglycemia.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the cardiology clinic for a routine wellness visit. ECG shows no P wave but has a normal QRS complex and a normal T wave. With this given information, which is the most probable location of the pacemaker in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Atrioventricular (AV) node

  • There are absent P waves in the ECG when there is no atrial depolarisation. Therefore, the pacemaker is not situated in the sinoatrial node.
  • Since the QRS and T waves are normal, the depolarisation and repolarisation of the ventricle should be in the normal sequence.
  • This situation can occur if the pacemaker is located in the atrioventricular (AV) node.
  • When the pacemaker is placed in the bundle of His or the Purkinje system, the ventricles will be activated in the abnormal sequence, and the QRS complex in ECG will have an abnormal configuration.
  • Ventricular muscle does not have pacemaker properties.

Option A: In the Sinoatrial (SA) node,

  • There are absent P waves in the ECG when there is no atrial depolarisation. Therefore, the pacemaker is not situated in the sinoatrial node.

Option C: Bundle of His

  • When the pacemaker is placed in His bundle, the ventricles will be activated in the abnormal sequence, and the QRS complex in ECG will have an abnormal configuration.

Option D: Purkinje system

  • When the pacemaker is placed in the Purkinje system, the ventricles will be activated in the abnormal sequence, and the QRS complex in ECG will have an abnormal configuration.

questions.text: What is the main difference between the measurement of BP with a sphygmomanometer and intra-arterial pressure measurements?
questions.solution:
Option B:  More than intravascular pressure

  • A hypertensive patient is presented in this case for his blood pressure evaluation.
  • When BP is measured by sphygmomanometry, the principle is balancing pressure between the cuff and the brachial artery.
  • Suppose the pressure in the artery is, say, 100 mmHg. When the pressure outside the artery is 100 mmHg, the artery will be occluded completely, or when the pressure outside the artery becomes less than 100mmHg, the artery will open up, and the flow will start in the artery.
  • However, for pressure just outside the artery to be 100mmHg, pressure in the cuff has to be about 106 mmHg; about six mmHg is dissipated in the intervening tissue (muscle, fat) between the cuff and the artery.
  • Thus, if we are looking for a point at which the artery is just occluded (with arterial pressure being 100), the cuff pressure at which it happens is about 106 mm Hg.
  • Hence, by sphygmomanometry, the pressure measured is higher than direct intravascular pressure measurement.
  • The reason for this is – the "dissipation of pressure".

Option A: Less than intravascular pressure

  • The cuff is always outside the artery, so there is no chance that the measurement of the sphygmomanometer is less than intravascular pressure.
  • It is always more than intravascular pressure.

Option C: Equal to intravascular pressure

  • The measurement of a sphygmomanometer and intravascular pressure can never be equal to each other.
  • As the cuff has to occlude the artery, and for this, it must have more pressure than the artery.

Option D: Depends upon blood flow

  • Blood flow will affect both measurements equally.
  • Blood pressure is directly proportional to blood flow.
  • So, measurements of a sphygmomanometer and intravascular pressure will both be affected by blood flow but with equal proportions.

questions.text: A surgeon presents an article on tetany to second-year medical students. He explains that sudden onset of carpopedal spasms can occur in perioperative patients. When a person hyperventilates, it can result in tetany. Which one of the following is the basis for carpopedal spasm in hyperventilation?

choices.text: Increased sequestration of Ca2+ in SER
Increased plasma protein binding of Ca2+
Increased excretion of calcium in urine

questions.solution:
Option B: Increased plasma protein binding of Ca2+

  • When people hyperventilate, they breathe faster and deeper than usual.
  • As a result, they release even the minimum amount of carbon dioxide the blood requires.
  • Decreased carbon dioxide level causes an increase in pH.
  • Increased pH causes the binding of calcium to plasma proteins.
  • Thus, there is an increase in plasma protein binding to Ca++, and the body’s calcium level also goes down.
  • Hence, hyperventilation leads to carpopedal spasms.

Option A: Increased sequestration of Ca2+ in SER

  • Calcium sequestration in SER can cause low cytoplasmic calcium. However, this is not the mechanism through which hyperventilation causes decreased calcium level that leads to tetany.

Option C: Ca2+ utilized in bones

  • Hyperventilation does not lead to increased calcium utilization in bones

Option D: Increased excretion of calcium in urine

  • Increased excretion of calcium can lead to hypocalcemia. However, hyperventilation causes tetany by increasing protein-bound calcium.

questions.text: A loss of which of the following causes the hyperkinetic symptoms of Huntington's disease?
questions.solution:
Option D: Intrastriatal GABA-ergic and cholinergic system

  • Huntington's disease is an autosomal dominant condition inherited and often manifests between 30 and 50. The defective gene is found on chromosome 4's short arm, close to the end. It typically has between 11 and 34 CAG repeats, each of which codes for glutamine. This number rises to 42–86 or more copies in patients with Huntington's disease; the higher the number of repeats, the earlier the age of onset and the quicker the disease advances.
  • The gene encodes the protein huntingtin, which is required for axonal transport, gene transcription regulation, and cell survival. Toxic, poorly soluble protein aggregates occur in cells.
  • In Huntington's disease, the first observable damage occurs to medium spiny neurons in the striatum.
  • The Corpus striatum sends inhibitory input to globus pallidus (external); globus pallidus is reciprocally connected with the subthalamic nucleus.
  • Loss of this GABAergic route causes inhibition to be released in the exterior section of the globus pallidus, allowing the disease's hyperkinetic characteristics to emerge.
  • When trying to touch something, the hand may move erratically, especially as it nears its destination.
  • Later, hyperkinetic choreiform motions start to manifest and steadily get worse until they render the patient unconscious.
  • Within 10 to 15 years of the start of symptoms, speech gets slurred and becomes unintelligible, and eventually, death results from gradual dementia.

Option A: Nigrostriatal dopaminergic system

  • Parkinson's disease is caused by the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta. The fibres leading to the putamen (a portion of the striatum) are the most severely impacted.
  • It has hypokinetic characteristics such as akinesia and bradykinesia.
  • Cogwheel stiffness and rest tremor are hyperkinetic characteristics.

Option B: Intrastriatal cholinergic system

  • Alzheimer's disease occurs due to the loss of acetylcholine.
  • It is the most common cause of dementia in the aged.
  • Patients with Down syndrome have an increased risk of developing early-onset Alzheimer's disease, as the APP gene is located on chromosome 21 and in Down syndrome, there are three copies of chromosome 21.
  • ApoE-2 is associated with decreased risk of sporadic form, and  ApoE-4 is associated with an increased risk of sporadic form.
  • There is widespread cortical atrophy, especially in the hippocampus, narrowing gyri and widening of sulci.
  • Senile plaques, neurofibrillary tangles and Hirano bodies are also found.

Option C: Subthalamic nucleus

  • Lesions of the subthalamic nucleus cause contralateral hemiballismus
  • Lacunar strokes usually cause it.
  • Hemiballismus manifests as sudden, wild flailing of one side of the body.

questions.text: A group of neurologists is investigating action potentials and refractory nerve periods. What is the greatest nerve stimulation frequency if the nerve's refractory period is 1/2500th of a second?
questions.solution:
Option D: 2500 times/sec

  • The refractory period is the time after the initial stimulus when the nerve is "refractory" to further stimulation.
  • As a result, the maximal stimulation frequency is 2500 times per second.
  • Each subsequent stimulus might stimulate the nerve if administered promptly after the refractory period (1/2500th of a second).

Option A: 100 times/sec

  • The excitation frequency cannot be 100 times per second since the following stimulus, administered immediately after the conclusion of the refractory period, can stimulate the nerve.

Option B: 250 times/sec

  • Because the next stimulus can excite the nerve if applied immediately at the end of the refractory period, the maximum excitation potential frequency in this scenario is 2500 times/second.

Option C: 2000 times/sec

  • During an action potential, the nerve remains resistant to the following stimulus.
  • As a result, the maximum frequency would be 2500 times per second.

questions.text: Which of the following TCA cycle enzymes is most likely to be affected by riboflavin deficiency?
questions.solution:
Option A: Succinate dehydrogenase

  • The patient has a deficiency in riboflavin (urinary excretion of fewer than 30 μg/mg creatinine is considered clinically deficient).
  • Riboflavin is a component of the flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) cofactor, which is required to convert succinate to fumarate by succinate dehydrogenase.
  • Deficiency leads to less activity of succinate dehydrogenase.
  • Other enzymes that require FAD are:
    1. Xanthine oxidase
    2. Succinyl CoA dehydrogenase
    3. G-3-P dehydrogenase

Option B and C: MDH and IDH

  • Both are dehydrogenase and requires NAD as coenzyme.
  • NAD requires vitamin B3 (Niacin)for its synthesis. So, deficiency of Vitamin B3 will affect their activity

Option D: Citrate synthase

  • One of the RLE of TCA but does not require any coenzyme
  • Activity is affected by NADH, succinyl-CoA, citrate, ATP and ADP allosterically

questions.text: A 2-week-old child being breastfed is brought to the hospital by his mother because the infant appears restless. The mother also states that the infant has looked yellow since birth. On examination, the physician observed that the infant had icterus, hepatomegaly and bilateral cataracts. The blood examination shows normal blood glucose levels. What is the most probable reason for the child's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option C: Galactosemia

  • If the blood glucose level is normal, but the urine benedict's test is positive, this likely suggests galactosemia.
  • Benedict’s test positive means a reducing sugar is present in urine. Both fructose and galactose are reducing.
  • But if blood glucose is normal, then it cannot be fructosemia because fructose accumulation causes hypoglycemia as fructose-1-P inhibits glycogenolysis by inhibiting Glycogen phosphorylase (Option B is excluded).
  • So, the answer is galactosemia, because in galactosemia, blood glucose is normal.
  • In both fructosemia and galactosemia, liver is affected but hypoglycemia occurs only in fructosemia.

Option A: False positive

  • It cannot be a false positive as Benedict's test is a control for GOD-POD and vice versa.

Option B: Fructosemia

  • In fructosemia, there is hypoglycemia and  here normal glucose level rules out fructosemia.

Option D: Glucose intolerance

  • Glucose intolerance (GI) can be defined as dysglycemia and includes the conditions of Impaired Fasting Glucose (IFG), Impaired Glucose Tolerance (IGT), and Diabetes Mellitus (DM).
  • The blood glucose is higher than normal in a person with impaired glucose tolerance which is not the case in this patient.

questions.text: A patient presented to casualty with nausea and vomiting. Intravenous glucose was given & the patient recovered. After a few months, the patient presented with the same complaints, along with increased blood glutamine and elevated uracil levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency

  • In the urea cycle, ammonia combines with carbon dioxide and forms carbamoyl phosphate. The carbamoyl phosphate combines with ornithine and forms citrulline. The enzyme responsible for the reaction is carbamoyl phosphate synthase and ornithine carbamoyl transferase, respectively.
  • If the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase is deficient, it leads to elevated levels of ammonia in the blood and carbamoyl phosphate from in liver mitochondria .
  • The excess carbamoyl phosphate from mitochondria enters the cytoplasm and takes part in pyrimidine synthesis leading to increased uracil synthesis (see fig).
  • Orotic acid, OMP, and UMP are all increased in OTC defect.

  • Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency presents with the symptoms of refusal to eat, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, seizures, etc.
  • It is an X-linked recessive disorder. It is the most common urea cycle disorder.
  • It is characterized by decreased levels of blood urea nitrogen.
  • CPS-II (carbamoyl phosphate synthetase-II) is an enzyme involved in pyrimidine synthesis, not in the urea cycle.

Choice A: CPS-I deficiency

  • CPS-I enzyme is involved in the urea cycle. It is present in the mitochondria.
  • It leads to elevated ammonia levels in the blood, which can have toxic effects on the brain.
  • It does not lead to elevated levels of orotic acids in the blood.

Choice B: Arginosuccinate synthetase deficiency

  • Arginosuccinate synthase enzyme is a part of the urea cycle. It is involved in the synthesis of argininosuccinate via the enzyme argininosuccinate synthase.
  • If citrulline is increased, then it means that Arginosuccinate synthetase is the deficient enzyme.

Choice C: CPS-II deficiency

  • CPS-II is involved in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidine.
  • It is activated by ATP and is inhibited by UMP.
  • ​​​​​​​Its deficiency is associated with the decreased synthesis of pyrimidine.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with elevated cholesterol levels of 325 mg/dL on a routine checkup. His father consistently had high levels of cholesterol throughout his life and eventually died of a heart attack at the age of 42. He was prescribed lovastatin, and his cholesterol levels dropped to 170 mg/dL. The most likely reason for the elevated cholesterol in this patient is due to a mutation in which one of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
Option D: LDL receptor

  • The patient's condition suggests that it might be a case of Familial hypercholesterolemia, which is either due to a defect in the LDL receptor present in the liver or defective Apo B100 protein present on LDL.
  • It is a genetically heritable disease passed in an autosomal dominant fashion in the family.
  • The condition leads to high levels of cholesterol in the blood of the patient leading to atherosclerosis and other cardiovascular diseases at a very young age.
  • The LDL receptor is required for liver uptake of LDL and further processing of the endogenous cholesterol, while apo B100 protein present on LDL acts as a legend for this receptor and helps in engulfment of LDL in the liver.
  • A defect in either of these results in the inability to clear excess endogenous cholesterol and leads to its accumulation in the blood vessels hence increasing the

Option A: Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein

  • Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein deficiency causes abetalipoproteinemia (ABL).
  • ABL is a rare autosomal recessive disorder which is characterized by the secretion of plasma apolipoprotein.

Option B: Lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT)

  • Mutation in the LCAT gene causes Norum's and fish-eye disease.
  • It also causes hemolytic anemia and kidney failure.

Option C: Lipoprotein lipase

  • The LPL gene gives instructions to produce the LPL enzyme.
  • Gene mutation in lipoprotein lipase cause familial LPL.

questions.text: Several techniques such as PCR and in situ hybridization require DNA strands to be separated for analysis. Heating is one of the most common methods to denature a dsDNA into a single-stranded form. What percentage of dsDNA is denatured at a widely used temperature in molecular biology called Tm or melting temperature?
questions.solution:
Option B: 50%

  • Several techniques such as PCR and in situ hybridization require DNA strands to be separated for analysis.
  • Heating is one of the most common methods to denature a dsDNA into a single-stranded form.
  • Melting temperature or Tm
  • The temperature at which one-half of the DNA duplex will dissociate to become single-stranded. Tm indicates the stability of DNA.
  • At lower temperatures, the melted strands are re-associated, called annealing.
  • When DNA is denatured, unstacking of bases occurs, resulting in increased absorbance at 260 nm-hyperchromicity.
  • Tm is an important parameter for designing of primers for PCR reactions.
  • Tm is directly proportional to the GC content of the DNA.

Option A, C and D: Refer to explanation of B

questions.text: A 2-year-old male infant is presented to a pediatrician with dilated cardiomyopathy, hypothyroidism, inability to gain weight, dry skin, and failure to thrive. The patient is diagnosed with mineral deficiency, an essential component of the enzyme glutathione peroxidase. Based on the given information, which one of the following mineral supplements can help improve this child's condition?
questions.solution:
Selenium

  • Selenium as selenocysteine is an essential component of the enzyme glutathione peroxidase
  • Selenium-containing enzyme 5'-deiodinase converts thyroxine (T4) to triiodothyronine in the thyroid gland.
  • Thioredoxin reductase isinvolved in purine nucleotide metabolism
  • Sources- Seafood and meat, Nuts
  • Deficiency – Keshan’s disease
  • C/f:
    • Endemic Cardiomyopathy (endemic to a province of china due to soil poor in Se)
    • Muscular weakness and muscular dystrophy
    • Inability to gain weight
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Hypertension
    • Eczema
    • Increased risk of stroke and even cancer
  • Clinical features are emotional disturbance, diarrhea, hair loss, garlic odor (due to dimethyl selenide) in breath

questions.text: Which amino acid substitution would enhance the protein's UV absorption at 280 nm in the lab?
questions.solution:
Option C: Tryptophan

UV absorption of amino acid:

  • Aromatic side chains are responsible for the UV absorption of most proteins, which have absorption maxima between 275 nm and 285 nm.
  • This absorption of UV light is because of conjugated double bonds present in the ring.
  • Aromatic amino acids:
    • Tryptophan
    • Tyrosine
    • Phenylalanine
  • Absorption is the maximum for tryptophan.
  • Since nearly all proteins contain aromatic amino acids, the amount of light absorbed at 280 nm by a protein is used as an indirect measure of protein concentration.
  • UV absorption is used to quickly quantify protein concentration in a small size samples non-destructively.

Protein detection by UV absorption

 

Option A: Leucine

  • Leucine is an essential amino acid that cannot absorb UV light. 

Option B: Arginine

  • Arginine is a non-essential, basic amino acid that cannot absorb UV light. 

Option D: Proline

  • Proline is a non-essential amino acid that cannot absorb UV light.

questions.text:
In the graph below, Curve A is obtained for liver glucokinase, while Curve B is for muscle glucokinase under similar conditions.

 



Which is the correct statement regarding the relationship between these enzymes?

choices.text: A is the same enzyme as B but in the presence of a competitive inhibitor
B has a greater affinity for glucose than A.
At maximal substrate concentrations, both enzymes display first-order kinetics.
B has a higher Michaelis-Menten constant (Km) than A.

questions.solution:
Option D: B has a higher Michaelis-Menten constant (Km) than A.

  • One can estimate the Michaelis-Menten constant (Km) on this graph by taking the concentration of substrate at one-half of the enzyme's maximal velocity (Vmax).
  • As Km define the substrate concentration at which the velocity of the reaction is half of Vmax

  • The graph above shows that B has a higher Km as it has a higher Vmax than A.

Option A: A is the same enzyme as B but in the presence of a competitive inhibitor.

  • If A and B were the same enzyme with a competitive inhibitor added at maximal substrate concentrations, the Vmax of both enzymes would be equal. Based on the graph, this is not the case. Vmax of B is higher than A.

Option B: B has a greater affinity for glucose than A.

  • Affinity is based on the Km of an enzyme. The lower the Km, the higher the affinity. Therefore, enzyme A has a greater affinity for glucose than enzyme B.

Option C: At maximal substrate concentrations, both enzymes display first-order kinetics.

  • At maximal concentrations, enzyme binding sites become saturated, and the curves of both enzymes flatten and therefore become independent of substrate concentration, implying zero-order kinetics. First-order kinetics is seen during the initial stage of low substrate concentration.

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy was hospitalized after experiencing a seizure, lethargy and dehydration. The infant had reduced food intake due to a stomach infection, and the blood glucose level upon admission was 28 mg/dl. Urine analysis revealed the absence of ketone bodies but the presence of various dicarboxylic acids. What could be the underlying cause of fasting hypoglycemia in this case?

choices.text: Defect in converting acetyl CoA to glucose
High production of ATP and NADH
Increased conversion of acetyl CoA to acetoacetate

questions.solution:
Option D: Low acetyl-CoA production

  • MCAD deficiency results in decreased production of acetyl-CoA due to impaired oxidation of medium chain fatty acids (<12 C in length).
  • As acetyl-CoA is an allosteric activator of gluconeogenic enzyme pyruvate carboxylase, hence, glucose levels fall.
  • MCAD patients have non-ketotic hypoglycemia during starvation due to a lack of availability of ketone body substrate acetyl-CoA and dicarboxylic acidosis.
  • Acetyl CoA cannot be used for the net synthesis of glucose.
  • In MCAD deficiency, ketogenesis is decreased due to low acetyl CoA due to impaired fatty acid oxidation, which also means low ATP and NADH synthesis (option B), both of which are also needed for gluconeogenesis.

Option A: Defect in converting acetyl-CoA to glucose

  • Acetyl CoA cannot be used for the net synthesis of glucose.

Option B: High production of ATP and NADH

  • ATP and NADH are produced in the electron transport chain.
  • ATP is used to store and transport energy to the cells of the body.
  • During the overproduction of ATP, the liver uses ATP to produce glycogen.

Option C: Increased conversion of acetyl CoA to acetoacetate

  • Acetoacetate is a ketone body that provides energy to the body cells.
  • Excess conversion of acetyl-CoA to acetoacetate leads to an increase in ketone bodies in the blood.
  • Increased ketone bodies level in the blood cause ketoacidosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy suffering from congenital deficiency of muscle phosphorylase is getting examined by an ischemic forearm exercise test by squeezing a rubber ball. This patient would exhibit which one of the following as compared to a normal person performing the same test?

choices.text: Increased blood glucose in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein
Increased lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein
Relatively decreased blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

questions.solution:
Option D: Relatively decreased blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

  • Normal or low blood lactate and increased blood ammonia after an ischemic exercise test suggest a defect in the conversion of glycogen (glucose) to lactate.
  • This is observed in the case of McArdle's disease, which occurs due to a deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase enzyme such that glycogen cannot be converted to glucose and further to lactate in exercising muscle.
  • Hence, relatively low levels of lactate will be formed from muscle glycogen after exercise compared to a normal individual.
  • Another thing that happens is that due to a lack of energy and ATP, muscle cells get damaged. Hence myoglobin will be released in urine, causing myoglobinuria.
  • Definitive diagnosis of this disease can be done by:
    • Enzymatic assay in muscle tissue
    • Mutation analysis of the myophosphorylase gene
  • Abnormal exercise response also occurs with
    • Deficiencies of muscle phosphofructokinase
    • Deficiencies of the debranching enzyme (when the test is done after fasting).

Option A: Exercise endurance

  • Any type of glycogen storage disease in muscles causes exercise intolerance and muscle cramps due to a lack of stored muscle glycogen utilization.
  • So, in McArdle’s disease also, there is no chance of developing exercise endurance.

Option B: Increased  blood glucose in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

  • Muscle cells can take glucose from the blood during exercise, but muscle glycogen cannot contribute to blood glucose due to a lack of a glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme.
  • So, there can’t be any increased blood glucose in the blood vein of exercising forearm; rather, it will show decreased blood glucose

Option C: Increased lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

  • In glycogen phosphorylase deficiency, free glucose is not generated
  • Hence no lactate is formed due to a lack of glucose
  • Therefore, the blood level of lactate falls.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the Medicine outpatient department with complaints of easy bruising for three years. He has no risk factors and is not on any medication that could cause bruising. He reports no family history of any disease related to his condition. Further evaluation reveals a genetically transmitted disease. He is married to an albino girl. What are the possibilities that they will have an affected child and that their children will be carriers?
questions.solution:
Option A: None affected, and all carriers

  • The case mentioned above is married to a girl who has albinism. It is an autosomal recessive disease; all the offspring would be carried, but none would be affected.
  • Albinism is an autosomal recessive (AR) disorder.
  • AR disorders are any situation when the previous generation of the affected individual is not affected; the condition is recessive.
    • In X-linked recessive disease, the female won't have the disease, but she will transmit it to her son.
    • If there is selective male-to-female transmission: most likely, it is X linked condition.
    • Male-to-male transmission is seen in the autosomal condition.
  • Only expressed in the homozygous condition, i.e. when both alleles are mutant.
  • As a result, all offspring are genotypically carriers.
  • Phenotypically, all of them will be normal.

Option B: All normal

  • In X-linked recessive disease, the female won't have the disease,
  • But she will transmit it to her son.
  • Son will be affected.

Option C: 50% carriers

  • X-linked recessive diseases express in the homozygous condition, i.e., when both alleles are mutant.
  • As a result, all offspring are genotypically carriers, not 50%.
  • Phenotypically, all of them will be normal.

Option D: 50% affected, 50% carriers

  • X-linked recessive diseases are expressed in the homozygous condition, i.e., when both alleles are mutant.
  • All offspring are genotypically carriers, not 50%.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman had jaundice and was easily fatigable for the past few months. She also reports a racing heart and shortness of breath on exertion. Splenomegaly is discovered during the examination. Her history is significant for gallstones. According to the patient, her mother had a similar history of jaundice, and her father died of an ischemic stroke. Spherocytes can be seen in the patient's peripheral blood smear. Which of the following is the most important investigation to make a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Osmotic fragility test

Hereditary Spherocytosis (HS)

  • A hereditary Spherocytosis is a form of intrinsic hemolytic anaemia. It is primarily an autosomal dominant disease.
  • It occurs due to a defect in protein interacting with the RBC membrane skeleton and plasma membrane. For example, ankyrin, spectrin, and Protein 4.2
  • Peripheral smear shows small round RBCs with a lack of central pallor. There is a decreased surface area of the RBCs.

 

 

  • MCHC is usually increased.
  • Premature removal of RBCs by the spleen leads to extravascular hemolysis.
  • Findings include splenomegaly, pigmented gall stones, aplastic anaemia, etc.
  • Decreased mean fluorescence of RBCs in the EMA binding test and increased fragility in the osmotic fragility test.
  • Laboratory findings include
    • --->unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia
    • --->elevated reticulocyte count
    • --->normal or mildly reduced Hb
    • --->increased osmotic fragility test
    • --->positive sucrose/glycerol lysis test
    • --->positive EMA (eosin-5-maleimide) dye binding test
    • --->Elevated reticulocyte count can be present in other hemolytic anaemias, so it will not help differentiate HS
  • The osmotic fragility test tests whether RBCs are more prone to breakdown.
  • This condition causes the red blood cells more likely to break and become smaller.
  • MCV is normal to decrease, and there is an abundance of RBCs.
  • In chronic hemolysis, pigmented stones are formed in the gall bladder. Pigmented gall stones are usually seen made up of bilirubin.
  • Anisocytosis and several hyperchromic spherocytes are seen. Howell-Jolly bodies can be seen.
  • Splenectomy may be performed in the management.

 

Option A: FLAER Test for PNH

  • FLAER is an Alexa488-labeled inactive variant of aerolysin that does not cause lysis of cells.
  • Flow cytometric assay to diagnose paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). 

 

Option C: Coombs test

  • Coombs test is used in the diagnosis of autoimmune hemolytic anaemia.
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia is of two subtypes warm and cold hemolytic anaemia.

 

Option D: Reticulocyte count

  • Reticulocyte count is an important laboratory investigation to diagnose the cause of anaemia.
  • The count may be decreased if the bone marrow is defective, and reticulocytosis is observed if the bone marrow functions properly.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic smoker with retrosternal chest pain, cough, and choking. ECG showed sinus rhythm. The cardiologist rules out any cardiac involvement. Upper GI endoscopy revealed a punched-out ulcer, and a biopsy taken from the edge of the ulcer showed multinucleated squamous epithelium cells and eosinophilic Cowdry 'A' inclusions. Which of the following virus is involved in the disease's pathogenesis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Herpes simplex virus (HSV)

  • The patient described in the clinical vignette is a typical viral oesophagitis caused by the herpes simplex virus.
  • It is characterized by the following:-
    • Punched-out ulcers on upper GI endoscopy
    • The biopsy will show cowdry A inclusions and multinucleated cells with nuclear moulding and ground glass appearance.

Option A: Cytomegalovirus (CMV)

  • Shallow ulcerations
  • Cytomegalic cells, typically 2-4 fold larger than normal, contain basophilic cytoplasmic & intranuclear inclusion bodies surrounded by a clear halo, giving the appearance of an owl's eye within capillary endothelium & stromal cells.

Option C: Adenovirus

  • Adenovirus is unlikely to cause esophagitis.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option D: Coxsackie virus

  • It rarely causes esophagitis; if it occurs, it is generally mild and does not cause ulcers.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with a solitary breast mass, and a biopsy reveals malignant cells. Immunohistochemical staining shows that the tumour cells are positive for estrogen receptor (ER) and negative for Her2/neu. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Invasive ductal carcinoma

  • Cancer in the breast of males is uncommon and accounts for < 1% of all breast cancer cases.
  • The most common subtype is infiltrating(invasive) ductal carcinoma.
  • As there is less fat in the male breast, invasion of chest wall muscles is more frequent at the time of the diagnosis.
  • More than90% of breast cancers in males are of luminal type, while triple-negative breast cancer and Her2/neu enriched cancers are very rare (<5%).
  • The most important familial factor conferring an increased risk for male breast cancer is germline mutation of the BRCA2 tumour suppressor gene.

Option A: Basal cell carcinoma

  • Skin exposed to the sun, such as the face, is more likely to develop basal cell carcinoma than other types of skin cancer.
  • On brown and Black skin, basal cell carcinoma often looks like a brown or glossy black bump with a rolled border.
  • Basal cell carcinoma is a form of skin cancer.
  • It can also develop in sites not usually exposed to sunlight or artificial ultraviolet radiation, such as the breast, palm or groin.

Option C: Medullary carcinoma

  • Medullary carcinomas present as fleshy, bulky tumours measuring 5 to 10 cm in diameter.
  • Presents as a circumscribed mass that lacks calcifications.
  • Gross examination: well-circumscribed, fleshy, pale grey mass.
  • Microscopically:-Composed of highly pleomorphic sheets of cells with a high mitotic index, with lymphoid infiltrate encompassing the periphery of the tumour.
  • Better prognosis than infiltrating ductal or lobular carcinoma.
  • A dense lymphoid infiltrate is not characteristic of the other choices.

Option D: Tubular adenoma

  • Tubular adenomas are rare benign breast tumours often found in young women and related to fibroadenomas.
  • Histologically, tubular adenomas are distinguished by their homogeneously tightly packed tubular or acinar epithelial component and sparse connective tissue.
  • A tubular adenoma is not known to be associated with cancer risk.
  • But in the literature cases, tubular adenoma associated with carcinoma has been reported. However, this is a fortuitous association.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents with complaints of increasing skin pigmentation for the past few months. The axilla, neck, flexures, and anogenital region all have hyperkeratosis and hyperpigmentation on physical examination. According to endocrinologic tests, adrenal corticosteroids and glucocorticoid levels in the blood are normal. If this patient's skin colouration represents a paraneoplastic syndrome, the main tumour would most likely be detected in which of the following anatomic areas?
questions.solution:
Option D: Stomach

  • Hyperkeratosis and pigmentation of the axilla, neck, flexures and anogenital region characterise Acanthosis nigricans, a cutaneous condition.
  • It's particularly interesting because cancer affects more than half of patients with acanthosis nigricans.
  • More than 90% of cases are associated with gastrointestinal carcinomas (primarily stomach cancer).

Option A: Mouth: Acanthosis nigricans is not typically associated with oral cancers.

Option B: Kidney

  • Renal carcinoma is mostly associated with polycythemia rather than acanthosis nigricans.

Option C: Oesophagus

  • Acanthosis nigricans has no documented association with oesophagal carcinoma.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man is admitted to the medicine ward with complaints of pain in the lower limbs upon walking and blackening of the tips of his fingers. He has an 80-pack-year history of smoking. Laboratory investigations show haemoglobin of 15 g/dL, WBC of 8,300/μL, cholesterol of 223 mg/dL, and fasting blood sugar of 97 mg/dL. Tests for antinuclear antibodies are negative. Biopsy of the affected area (shown in the image) shows intraluminal thrombi in medium-sized arteries and inflammation extending from arteries to neighbouring veins and nerves. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Buerger disease

  • Thromboangiitis obliterans, often known as Buerger disease, is an occlusive inflammatory illness that affects the small and medium arteries in the distal hands and legs.
  • The etiologic role of smoking has been highlighted by the observation that smoking cessation might be recognised through remission.
  • Small to medium-sized arteries and veins can develop thrombosis, accompanied by microabscesses, multinucleated giant cells, and extensive polymorphonuclear leukocyte aggregation. End-stage lesions exhibit a well-organised thrombus and fibrosis of the blood vessels.
  • A microscopic examination of the afflicted vessels indicates a polymorphonuclear infiltration that extends to nearby veins and nerves.
  • Patients usually have signs and symptoms of ischemia in the distal arteries of the upper or lower limbs, such as claudication in the calf and the foot arch.
  • This condition, which manifests as pain in the hands, feet, and fingers when at rest, is known as the Raynaud phenomenon or livedo reticularis.
  • Thrombosis and the obliteration of the afflicted arteries are associated with endothelial inflammation. The various choices are unrelated to smoking and no longer highlight those noteworthy histologic results.

Option B: Churg-Strauss disease

  • Churg-Strauss syndrome is characterised by nonspecific findings, which frequently include flu-like symptoms such as fever, malaise, generalised weakness and exhaustion, anorexia, weight loss, and muscle discomfort (myalgia).
  • It is also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA).
  • The histology of EGPA demonstrates tissue eosinophilia, necrotising vasculitis, and granulomatous inflammation that is eosinophil-rich.

Option C: Wegener granulomatosis

  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, formerly known as Wegener granulomatosis (WG), is a small-to-medium vessel necrotising vasculitis that is a part of a wide range of conditions known as anti-neutrophil-cytoplasmic-antibody (ANCA) linked vasculitides (AAV).
  • Hallmark features include necrotising granulomas and pauci-immune vasculitis that most commonly affects the upper respiratory tract, lungs, and kidneys.

Option D: Takayasu arteritis

  • Takayasu arteritis, also known as pulseless disease, is a chronic inflammatory illness that damages the medium and large arteries and their branches.
  • It primarily affects girls and women younger than 40.
  • It typically affects the aorta and its major branches, especially the carotid, subclavian, and renal arteries, and causes stenosis, occlusions, or aneurysmal degeneration of these large arteries.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of heavy bleeding from the vagina. She is concerned because she had her menopause three years ago. The ultrasonographic evaluation shows a large pelvic tumour with multiple locules. Surgery is planned, and the tumour is resected. The histopathological evaluation of the tumour reveals Call-Exner bodies. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Granulosa cell tumour

  • The patient’s clinical symptoms and pathological findings of the lesion are diagnostic of granulosa cell tumours of the ovary.
  • Granulosa cell tumours are the most common malignant sex cord-stromal neoplasms of the ovary.
  • Granulosa cell tumours usually occur in women of the age group 50 to 55 years (like this patient).
  • The clinical symptoms of granulosa cell tumours are associated with excessive secretion of estrogen and/or progesterone. These hormones induce endometrial hyperplasia and result in menstrual irregularities such as heavy menstrual bleeding and post-menopausal bleeding (as in this patient).
  • These tumours are also associated with an increased risk of endometrial cancer of the uterus.
  • The histopathological hallmark of the diagnosis of granulosa cell tumours is Call-Exner bodies.
  • Call-Exner bodies are a cluster of granulosa cells that surround a central cavity with eosinophilic secretions, as shown below:

  • The presence of the Call-Exner bodies on the biopsy specimen of this patient confirms granulosa cell tumours of the ovary.

Option B: Leydig cell tumour

  • Leydig cell tumours secrete androgens which can cause virilization and acne.
  • These tumours can also cause estrogenic symptoms like heavy menstrual bleeding.
  • The histopathology of Leydig cell tumours is characterized by the presence of seminiferous-like tubules lined by Sertoli cells and Reinke crystals.
  • Call-Exner bodies are not seen in Leydig cell tumours.

Option C: Yolk-sac tumour

  • The yolk-sac tumours of the ovary usually occur in children and adolescent age groups (rather than this patient of the middle-aged group).
  • The histopathology of yolk-sac tumours is significant for Schiller-Duval bodies (structures resembling primitive glomeruli) rather than the Call-Exner bodies.

Option D: Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma

  • Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma occurs in the pediatric age group, unlike this patient.
  • These tumours can contain Tennis-Racket cells, but Call-Exner bodies are not characteristic of these tumours.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents with involuntary facial grimaces and movements of the fingers. His mother also had the same symptoms starting at approximately the same age. Her disorder also had progressed from dancing movements, writhing of the arms and legs, and finally, coma and death. His maternal grandfather also had a similar disorder but was older than his mother. Which of the following is the most defining characteristic of this disease?

choices.text: Degeneration of upper and lower motor neurons
Dopamine depletion and depigmentation of the substantia nigra
Increased number of trinucleotide repeats in a gene on chromosome 4
Neurofibrillary tangles and amyloid plaques in the cerebral cortex

questions.solution:
Option C: Increased number of trinucleotide repeats in a gene on chromosome 4

This is a case of Huntington's disease.

  • It is an autosomal dominant disorder
  • It is a fatal, progressive degeneration and atrophy of the Striatum (Caudate nucleus and Putamen).
  • It is Characterised by an increased number of trinucleotide repeats (CAG) in the Huntington gene on the short arm of chromosome 4.

Option A: Degeneration of upper and lower motor neurons

  • Degeneration of the upper and lower motor neurons is characteristic of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.
  • It is also called Lou Gehrig's disease
  • Progressive nervous system disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord results in loss of muscle control.
  • Loss of upper motor neurons in the cerebral cortex and lower motor neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem.
  • The diagnosis is based on clinical criteria in which there are both Upper and lower motor neuron signs with progressive disease.

Option B: Dopamine depletion and depigmentation of the substantia nigra

  • Dopamine depletion and depigmentation of the substantia nigra are characteristic of Parkinson's disease.
  • Parkinson's disease is characterized by a degenerative loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra of the basal ganglia.
  • In Parkinson's disease, histology reveals loss of pigmented neurons in the substantia nigra and round, eosinophilic inclusions of an α-synuclein protein (Lewy bodies) in affected neurons.
  • Clinical features are tremors, rigidity, akinesia/bradykinesia, and postural instability.
  • Dementia is a common feature of late disease.

Option D: Neurofibrillary tangles and amyloid plaques in the cerebral cortex

  • Neurofibrillary tangles and amyloid plaques are found in Alzheimer's disease.
  • Pick bodies can be found in Pick disease, which clinically resembles Alzheimer's disease.
  • Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia.
  • Morphological features include cerebral atrophy with narrowing of the gyri, widening of sulci, and dilation of the ventricles.
  • Neuritic plaques are extracellular core comprised of Aβ amyloid with entangled neuritic processes.
  • Aβ amyloid is derived from amyloid precursor protein (APP) which normally undergoes alpha cleavage; beta cleavage results in Aβ amyloid.
  • Neurofibrillary tangles are intracellular aggregates of fibers composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein.
  • Loss of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and mild fever for one day. He further explains that the pain was initially in the periumbilical region but has moved to the lower right quadrant of the abdomen. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. On abdominal examination, there is maximum tenderness at McBurney's point.
