Laboratory tests reveal a WBC count of 14,000 / mm3, with 74% segmented and 12% neutrophils. Which of the following statements describes the expected results at the site of inflammation in the patient’s current pathology?

choices.text: Fistula (abnormal duct or passage) connecting to the abdominal wall
Granulomatous inflammation with prominent aggregates of epithelioid cells and multinucleated giant cells
Massive infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells
Prominent areas of oedema, congestion, and a purulent reaction with localised areas of abscess formation

questions.solution:
Option D: Prominent areas of oedema, congestion, and a purulent reaction with localised areas of abscess formation

  • This is a case of acute appendicitis in which the patient presents with complaints of severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and mild fever for one day. The pain was initially in the periumbilical region but has moved to the lower right quadrant of the abdomen.
  • On abdominal examination, there is maximum tenderness at McBurney's point. Laboratory tests reveal a WBC count of 14,000 / mm3, with 74% segmented and 12% neutrophils.
  • Because the danger of perforation is great, early appendectomy is the treatment of choice.
  • Acute appendicitis is a type of suppurative or purulent inflammation which is characterised by:
    • Prominent areas of oedema (Due to increased vascular permeability, congestion, and a purulent (pus-containing) exudate consisting of necrotic cells and large numbers of neutrophils).
    • Congestion is prominent.

Option A: Fistula (abnormal duct or passage) connecting to the abdominal wall

  • In acute appendicitis, there is supportive inflammation of the appendix, which causes oedema. There is no fistula formation.

Option B: Granulomatous inflammation with prominent aggregates of epithelioid cells and multinucleated giant cells

  • There is no granulomatous inflammation in acute appendicitis.
  • There is supportive inflammation with prominent necrotic cells.

Option C: Massive infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells

  • Acute appendicitis causes inflammation of the appendix, which increases its vascular permeability that results in massive infiltration of neutrophils.
  • It is acute inflammation, so neutrophils are prominent.
  • Lymphocytes are prominent in chronic inflammation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the physician with complaints of severe anaemia for two months. She has been a known case of myasthenia gravis for eight years, for which he has been taking medication. Investigation results show a haemoglobin concentration of 4.7 g/dl, hematocrit at 13.7%, and reticulocyte counts at 0.1%. Both direct and indirect Coombs’s tests were positive. However, there was no evidence of Haemolysis. Screening tests for other possible causes of anaemia were negative. The bone marrow examination results revealed severe erythroid hypoplasia. Based on the clinical findings, which of the following condition is usually associated with this pathology?
questions.solution:
Option A: Thymoma

  • This is the case of pure red cell aplasia (PRCA), in which the patient presents with signs and symptoms of severe anaemia.
  • The patient is a known case of myasthenia gravis, which is strongly associated with pure red cell aplasia with thymoma.
  • Investigation results reveal severe anaemia, decreased hematocrit, and abnormally low reticulocyte count with positive direct and indirect Coombs tests. This confirms severely decreased levels of erythrocytes.
  • However, there is no evidence of haemolysis, and no other possible cause of anaemia can be established by routine screening procedures.
  • Severe erythroid hypoplasia on the bone marrow examination in the presence of severely decreased reticulocyte count confirms the diagnosis.
  • Pure red cell aplasia is a primary bone marrow disorder in which only erythroid progenitors are either inhibited or maybe completely absent in severe cases.
  • PRCA can be inherited or acquired and can occur in association with neoplasms, particularly thymoma and large granular lymphocytic leukaemia, drug exposures, autoimmune disorders & parvovirus infection.

Option B: Renal cell carcinoma

  • Warm autoimmune haemolytic anaemia has been reported to be associated with renal cell carcinoma in patients with unusual haematological alterations.
  • It is associated with significant morbidity and even mortality in such cases.

Option C: Hepatocellular carcinoma

  • Hepatocellular carcinoma is usually characterised by mild anaemia and increased erythropoietin levels due to decreased hepatic clearance of erythropoietin and influence by cytokine-mediated inflammatory markers.
  • It is not usually associated with pure red cell aplasia as the production of red blood cells is decreased due to decreased erythropoietin levels.

Option D: Prostate carcinoma

  • Anaemia in prostate cancer is usually seen with metastatic bone marrow infiltration resulting in impaired erythropoiesis, which is usually evident on the peripheral blood smear.
  • Patients with metastatic prostate cancer are usually found to have leucoerythroblastic Anaemia.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the clinic with fever and lymphadenopathy; a provisional diagnosis of leukaemia is made after a series of examinations. Her blood smear examination was sent to a pathologist, revealing leukaemia composed of small mature lymphocytes without blast forms. Which of the following is the patient's most likely age of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: 65 years

  • This patient's signs and symptoms suggest chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL) and small lymphocytic leukaemia (SLL).
  • CLL and SLL are the same diseases.
  • The only difference is that CLL is mostly found in the blood and bone marrow, whereas SLL is found in the lymph nodes.
  • CLL/SLL cells express pan-B cell markers (CD19 and CD20) and CD5, found on a small subset of normal B cells.
  • It is one of the most common types of leukaemia in the adult population.
  • It occurs in older adults after the age of 40.
  • The median age of 60 years
  • It is characterized by an absolute lymphocyte count of more than 4000 cells/mL.
  • Characteristic features include :
    • Nonspecific symptoms like weight loss, easy fatigability, and anorexia.
    • hepatosplenomegaly and Generalized lymphadenopathy (50% to 60% of patients)
    • Lymphocytosis (up to 200,000/mL) in CLL.
    • Immune abnormalities like hypogammaglobulinemia commonly lead to increased susceptibility to bacterial infections and autoantibodies against platelets or erythrocytes (10% to 15% of patients).

Option A: 1 year

  • Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia most frequently occurs in children.
  • It peaks between 2 and 5 years of age.

Option B: 20 years

  • Acute myeloid leukaemia is the most common type in adults ages 25 to 49.
  • It is uncommon before the age of 45 years.

Option C: 45 years

  • Chronic myeloid leukaemia is a tumour that can occur at any age.
  • However, it is more common in adults around 60-65, with a median age of 64.

questions.text: A twelve-year-old girl is brought to your clinic by her parents with complaints of high-grade fever. The fever has been going on for the past week. Examination findings reveal 38°C (101°F) temperature and lymphadenopathy. Initial laboratory findings are normal. A biopsy of the inflamed lymph node reveals benign follicular hyperplasia (shown in the image below). Which of the following best describes this pathologic finding?
questions.solution:
Option A: Proliferation in B-cell areas

  • Follicular hyperplasia is characterised by enlarged lymph follicles (primarily in the cortex of the lymph node) composed of B lymphocytes.
  • Numerous activated B cells, scattered T cells, phagocytic macrophages containing nuclear debris (tingible body macrophages), and a meshwork of antigen-presenting follicular dendritic cells are found in reactive follicles.
  • Secondary follicle hyperplasia, germinal centre hyperplasia, and plasmacytosis of the medullary cords all indicate B-lymphocyte immunoreactivity.
  • Deep cortex or paracortical hyperplasia (interfollicular or diffuse hyperplasia) is a feature of (T-lymphocyte immunoreactivity)

Option B: Proliferation of dendritic cells

  • Follicular hyperplasia is the diagnosis for this patient.
  • The proliferation of B cell areas characterises follicular hyperplasia.

Option C: Proliferation of plasma cells

  • Follicular hyperplasia is the diagnosis for this patient.
  • The proliferation of B cell areas characterises follicular hyperplasia.

Option D: Proliferation in T-cell areas

  • Follicular hyperplasia is the diagnosis for this patient.
  • The proliferation of B cell areas characterises follicular hyperplasia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has come to the clinic with complaints of fever, chills, and cough for the last 20 days. He also reports shortness of breath. He has also experienced mild weight loss. He is a farmer by profession and has had a history significant for uncontrolled diabetes and hypertension for the last 10 years. His father died from colon cancer at the age of 87. HRCT and biopsy are performed, which confirms the diagnosis of hypersensitivity pneumonitis. Following statements are true regarding histological features of Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis, except:
questions.solution:
Option C: Eosinophilic abscess

  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is an immune-mediated disease in the lungs associated with inflammation as an allergic reaction to inhaled antigens.
  • Microorganisms, plants, proteins, animals, or chemicals may inhale the antigen.
  • The disease is also called farmer’s lungs or bird fancier’s lungs.
  • It is a mild type 3 or 4 hypersensitivity reaction to the environmental antigen. It is often seen in farmers or bird fancier.
  • Signs and symptoms of hypersensitivity pneumonitis include dyspnea, fever, chills, shortness of breath, etc.
  • HRCT and biopsy of the lungs can be used to diagnose the condition.

  • Histological changes of Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis are characteristically present in bronchioles.

They include:

  1. Interstitial pneumonitis consists primarily of macrophages, plasma cells, and lymphocytes (rarely eosinophils);
  2. Non-caseating granulomas are seen in two-thirds of patients and
  3. Interstitial fibrosis with honeycombing, fibroblastic foci, and obliterative bronchiolitis (in late stages).
  • An eosinophilic abscess is not associated with hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

Interalveolar infiltrate is seen in more than half of patients.

  • The disease is often self-limited if the stimulus is removed.
  • Chronically it leads to irreversible fibrosis with non-caseating granulomas, alveolar septal thickening, and traction bronchiectasis.

Option A: Interstitial pneumonitis

  • Interstitial pneumonitis is associated with hypersensitivity pneumonitis.
  • Interstitial pneumonitis consists primarily of macrophages, plasma cells, and lymphocytes.

Option B: Non-caseating granuloma

  • Noncaseating granulomas are associated with hypersensitivity pneumonitis.
  • They are seen in two third of the patients with hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

Option D: Interstitial fibrosis

  • Interstitial fibrosis is also seen in the case of hypersensitivity pneumonitis.
  • Interstitial fibrosis with honeycombing, fibroblastic foci, and obliterative bronchiolitis (in late stages).

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with end-stage renal disease. On examination, right eye lens dislocation is found. His maternal uncle also died of the same illness. On electron microscopy of renal biopsy, a basket-weave appearance of glomerular basement membrane (GBM) is seen. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Alport syndrome

  • Presentation of a male patient with lens dislocation, end-stage renal disease with a family history of renal disease, and a distinctive "basket-weave" appearance of glomerular basement membrane (GBM) s highly suggestive of Alport syndrome.
  • The following are characteristics of Alport syndrome:
  • Clinical signs consist of abnormalities related to the eyes, ears, and kidneys; mutations affecting the gene encoding for the type IV collagen alpha-5 chain.
  • The BM's distinctive basket-weave appearance.

Option A: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

  • AD polycystic kidney disease is ruled out because there is no association of ADPKD with lens dislocation, as is men­tioned in this case.​​​​​​​

Option B: Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease

  • AR polycystic kidney disease is ruled out because the age of presentation in ARPKD is childhood, and most affected children do not survive beyond childhood.

Option C: Marfan's syndrome

  • Lens dislocation is also a feature of Marfan's syndrome, but it has no documented association with renal disease or renal disease-related death.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the paediatrician for a physical examination before beginning elementary school. On examination, the boy has only one palpable testis in the scrotum. Further examination shows a palpable mass in the inguinal region on the left side. What is this condition referred to as?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cryptorchidism

  • Only One palpable testis in the scrotal sac and a palpable mass in the inguinal region suggest Cryptorchidism.
  • It is associated with an increased incidence of germ cell tumours of the testes, even if the testis is surgically moved from its ectopic location back to the scrotum.
  • The descent of the testes occurs in two phases:

1. Transabdominal phase

  • During this phase, the testes lie within the lower abdomen or brim of the pelvis.
  • Mullerian inhibiting substances regulate this phase.

2. Inguinoscrotal Phase

  • In this phase, the testes descend through the inguinal canal into the scrotum.
  • Testes' descent may arrest anywhere between the pathway, but the most common site is in the inguinal canal.

Option B: Hydrocele

  • A hydrocele is a serous fluid collection in the scrotum.
  • A testicle's thin sheath can get clogged with fluid, causing a scrotal enlargement known as a hydrocele.
  • Hydrocele is frequent in babies and typically goes away untreated by age 1.
  • Typically, hydroceles are painless.
  • The most typical sign is typically an enlarged scrotum.
  • However, pain or discomfort may also occur depending on the severity of the swelling.
  •  In adults, there may be a feeling of heaviness in the scrotum.

Option C: Orchitis

  • Orchitis (inflammation of the testis) can result from bacterial or viral infection.
  • Bacterial or viral infections can cause orchitis, or the cause can be unknown.
  • Orchitis is often the result of a bacterial infection, such as a sexually transmitted infection (STI).
  • In some cases, the mumps virus can cause orchitis.

Option D: Varicocele

  • A varicocele is caused by dilation of the veins of the spermatic cord, and the term “bag of worms” aptly describes the abnormality.
  • A varicocele is an enlargement of the veins within the loose bag of skin that holds the testicles (scrotum).
  • These veins transport oxygen-depleted blood from the testicles.
  • A varicocele occurs when blood pools in the veins rather than circulating efficiently out of the scrotum.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents to the clinic with a complaint of headache and palpitations. His blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg. He reports similar symptoms in the past. After making a thorough assessment, a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma is made. Which of the following familial syndromes is least likely to be associated with developing pheochromocytomas?
questions.solution:
Option D: Prader-Willi syndrome

  • Prader Willi is not associated with pheochromocytoma
  • Prader Willi is a genetic syndrome caused by microdeletion (at 15q11-q13) in combination with genomic imprinting.
  • Deletion or mutation of paternal gene copy and maternal gene methylation (silencing)
  • Caused by maternal uniparental disomy in about 20–35% of cases

Pheochromocytoma:

  • A pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumour that typically develops in the adrenal medulla.
  • Pheochromocytomas are usually benign (∼ 90% of cases) but may also be malignant.
  • Classic clinical features are due to excess sympathetic nervous system stimulation and involve episodic blood pressure crises with paroxysmal headaches, diaphoresis, heart palpitations, and pallor.
  • However, pheochromocytomas may also be asymptomatic or manifest with persistent hypertension.
  • Elevated catecholamine metabolites in the plasma or urine confirm the diagnosis, while imaging studies in patients with positive biochemistry are used to determine the tumour's location.
  • Surgical resection is the treatment of choice but is only carried out once alpha-adrenergic blockade with phenoxybenzamine has become effective.

Associated syndromes with pheochromocytoma:

  • MEN II A and B
  • Von Hippel Landau syndrome
  • Neurofibromatosis I

Option A: MEN II A

  • MEN II A is associated with pheochromocytoma, parathyroid hyperplasia, and medullary carcinoma of the thyroid

Option B: Von Hipple Landau syndrome

  • VHL is associated with hemangioblastoma, pheochromocytoma, and renal cell carcinoma.

Option C: MEN Type II B

  • MEN II B is associated with mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, medullary carcinoma of the thyroid and pheochromocytoma

questions.text: A 70-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by his son 30 minutes after he lost consciousness. The son of the patient further explains that his father was playing with his 2-year-old grandson when he suddenly collapsed and became unresponsive for 2 minutes. The patient normally responded after regaining consciousness. He had an episode of mild abdominal discomfort and chest pain three months ago. He has been a known case of hypertension for the past ten years. The cardiac examination reveals a grade 3/6 late systolic murmur at the right sternal border that radiates to the carotid arteries. There is no erythema or swelling of the lower limb. The transthoracic echocardiogram confirmed the diagnosis of aortic valve stenosis. The patient was posted for aortic valve replacement, and the surgery was done. Immediately post-replacement of the aortic valve, the patient was kept on IV unfractionated heparin infusion. If its dosing can be evaluated and changed accordingly, when is the steady state concentration expected to be reached?
questions.solution:
• This is a case of aortic valve stenosis in which the patient is brought to the emergency department by his son 30 minutes after he lost consciousness.
  • The cardiac examination reveals a grade 3/6 late systolic murmur at the right sternal border that radiates to the carotid arteries.
  • There is no erythema or swelling of the lower limb. The transthoracic echocardiogram confirmed the diagnosis of aortic valve stenosis.

Steady-state:

  • If a fixed dose of a drug is administered after regular intervals, its plasma concentration starts increasing.
  • However, as plasma concentration rises, the rate of elimination also starts increasing. When the rate of administration becomes equal to the rate of elimination, plasma concentration stabilizes. This is called a steady state.
  • The time to reach a steady state depends on t½. It takes approximately 4-5 half-lives.
  • The steady-state plasma concentration achieved depends on the dose rate.
  • Variation between peak and trough concentration at a steady state depends on the dosing interval. However, average steady-state plasma concentration remains the same irrespective of a dosing interval, provided the dose rate remains the same.

questions.text: A 55-year-old with a history of overactive bladder, currently on oxybutynin, seeks a regular check-up after six years. He reports experiencing dry mouth since starting the drug and consumes 3L of water daily despite concerns about increased urination. The physician prescribes a more uroselective muscarinic antagonist. Which drug did the physician prescribe?
questions.solution:
Option A: Darifenacin

  • This is a case of overactive bladder syndrome in which the patient presents for a regular check-up with his family physician.
  • The patient has been on oxybutynin for six years due to an overactive bladder.
  • In the case of an overactive bladder, the patient usually has excessive urination and dribbling.
  • The overactive bladder, in this case, is caused due to decreased tone of the detrusor muscle.
  • The doctor prescribed darifenacin to the patient, which is a more uroselective muscarinic antagonist.
  • Darifenacin is commonly used for the management of urinary incontinence caused due to overactive bladder syndrome.
  • Muscarinic antagonists acting on the bladder: SOFT BLADDER
    • S – Solifenacin
    • O – Oxybutynin
    • F – Flavoxate
    • T – Tolterodine and trospium chloride
    • Bladder– Darifenacin
  • Urinary retention is the most common side effect of darifenacin.

Option B: Tolbutamide

  • Tolbutamide is a sulfonylurea used as a hypoglycemic agent that stimulates the secretion of insulin by the pancreas.

Option C: Duloxetine

  • Duloxetine is an SNRI.
  • It is usually used in cases of:
    • Depression
    • Neuropathic pain
    • Fibromyalgia

Option D: Tamsulosin

  • Tamsulosin is a uroselective alpha-blocker.
  • It is commonly used in the treatment of benign prostate hyperplasia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about digoxin is the most accurate?

choices.text: Primarily acts by reducing sympathetic outflow, leading to decreased heart rate.
Contraindicated in patients with atrial fibrillation, especially in the elderly.
Narrow therapeutic window, requiring regular monitoring to avoid toxicity.
Administered concurrently with loop diuretics to enhance its efficacy.

questions.solution:
Explanation:

A) Incorrect Option: Digoxin's primary mechanism of action is to inhibit the sodium-potassium ATPase pump, which increases intracellular calcium levels and indirectly enhances myocardial contractility. It does not primarily reduce sympathetic outflow.

B) Incorrect Option: Digoxin can be used to control heart rate in atrial fibrillation, particularly in patients with heart failure. While it may not be a first-line treatment, it is not contraindicated, especially in the elderly.

C) Correct Option: This statement is most accurate. Digoxin has a narrow therapeutic window, meaning that the difference between a therapeutic dose and a toxic dose is relatively small. Regular monitoring of digoxin levels is necessary to avoid toxicity, which can manifest as nausea, vomiting, arrhythmias, and visual disturbances.

D) Incorrect Option: Loop diuretics can lead to hypokalemia (low potassium levels), which can increase the risk of digoxin toxicity. Therefore, administering digoxin with loop diuretics without proper potassium management could exacerbate the risk of digoxin toxicity.

In summary, the correct option is C) Digoxin has a narrow therapeutic window, requiring regular monitoring to avoid toxicity.

questions.text: An antimicrobial drug ‘X’ can cause pseudotumor cerebri in infants even when given at normal doses. Identify the mechanism of action of this drug ‘X’?

choices.text: Binding of a component of the 50S ribosomal subunits
Blockade of binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to bacterial ribosomes by binding to 30S ribosome
Selective inhibition of ribosomal peptidyl transferase

questions.solution:
Option C: Blockade of binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to bacterial ribosomes by binding to 30S ribosome

  • Pseudotumor cerebri in infants is most commonly caused by Tetracyclines.
  • Tetracyclines act by binding to 30S ribosome and inhibiting the binding of acyl tRNA to the A site of the mRNA-ribosome complex.
  • It enters bacteria by forming pores in the cell membrane and by active transport, which pumps it across the cell membrane.

Option A: Binding of a component of the 50S ribosomal subunits

  • Linezolid binds to the 23S fraction P site of the 50S ribosome and interferes with the formation of the ternary N- formylmethionine-tRNA (tRNA f met) 70S initiation complex.
  • It is not associated with pseudotumor cerebri.

Option B: Inhibition of translocase activity

  • Macrolides, Clindamycin and Quinpristine act by inhibiting translocation.
  • These are not associated with pseudotumor cerebri

Option D: Selective inhibition of ribosomal peptidyl transferase

  • Chloramphenicol acts by blocking peptide bond formation due to the inhibition of ribosomal peptidyl transferase.
  • It is not associated with pseudotumor cerebri

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient with a history of rheumatoid arthritis presents to her physician with complaints of persistent pain in her joints of both hands. She also complains of morning stiffness which lasts for approximately 2 hours. She was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis one year back and was commenced on ibuprofen, corticosteroids, and methotrexate. She is a non-smoker and drinks only occasionally. There is no history of any other comorbidity. She is vitally stable. Tender and swollen metacarpophalangeal joints and proximal interphalangeal joints are noted on examination. X-ray of the hands reveals erosions, joint space narrowing and soft tissue swelling. What is the next best step in treating this patient?

choices.text: Start monotherapy with anti-TNF alpha drugs

questions.solution:
Option D: Add sulfasalazine

  • In patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), NSAIDs and glucocorticoids are used for acute pain management.

  • As per the current recommendations, disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs (DMARDs) should be added as soon as the diagnosis of RA is made. Methotrexate is the top choice among DMARDs. Methotrexate is a folic acid analogue that causes inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase.

  • If the patient still has persisting symptoms, then sulfasalazine is added to the regimen in combination with methotrexate. Common side effects of sulfasalazine include malaise, nausea and reversible oligospermia.

  • Triple therapy is used in refractory cases, and hydroxychloroquine or leflunomide is added to the medication regimen.

Option A: Start monotherapy with anti-TNF alpha drugs

  • Anti-TNF alpha drugs are added to the regimen when triple therapy fails to alleviate the symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis.​​​​​​​

Option B: Continue current treatment

  • Since the patient has persistent symptoms, current therapy should be modified. Sulfasalazine should be added to her treatment regimen.

Option C: Increase the dose of ibuprofen

  • Due to significant side effects associated with the use of high-dose ibuprofen, other therapy modalities should be explored. ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with seizures and not responding to anticonvulsants since birth. She has abnormally tiny eyes and microcephaly. Her MRI brain reveals agenesis of the corpus callosum. Further examination reveals retinal colobomas and intellectual disability. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Aicardi syndrome

  • The patient, in this case, presents with seizures, abnormally small eyes and microcephaly.
  • This suggests it is Aicardi syndrome.
  • The patient usually presents with seizures during 1st few months of birth, resistant to anticonvulsants.
  • It is characterized by
    • Agenesis of corpus callosum
    • Retinal colobomas
    • Infantile spasms in girls
    • Intellectual disability

Option A: Alagille Syndrome

  • A genetic disorder characterized by aplasia or hypoplasia of the intrahepatic biliary tree.
  • This syndrome is typically caused by a mutation of the JAG1 gene on chromosome 20.
  • It presents with triangular faces, conjugated jaundice, a congenital heart defect and butterfly vertebrae.

Option C: Apert syndrome

  • A genetic disorder which is characterized by skeletal defects.
  • The main feature of Apert syndrome is the premature or early closure of the skull bones.

Option D: Ataxia-telangiectasia

  • Ataxia-telangiectasia is a rare childhood disease.
  • It affects the brain and other parts of the body.
  • Ataxia refers to uncoordinated movements during walking.
  • Telangiectasias are enlarged blood vessels (capillaries) just below the skin's surface.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male visits your clinic, reporting symptoms of a runny nose, cough, and throat pain, along with body aches. These symptoms emerged shortly after he began antitubercular therapy, following a recent diagnosis of Tuberculosis. Which antitubercular drug is likely responsible for the patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Rifampicin

  • Rifampicin is a derivative of rifamycin (other derivatives are rifabutin and rifapentine).
  • It is bactericidal and acts against dividing and non-dividing mycobacterium by inhibiting DNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
  • Its metabolites are coloured and can cause orange discolouration of the urine and secretions.
  • It can also cause orange staining of contact lenses.
  • It is eliminated mainly in the faeces and can be used safely in renal dysfunction.
  • Food interferes with its absorption.
  • It penetrates all membranes, including the blood-brain and the placental barrier.
  • It is equally effective against intra- and extra-cellular bacilli.
  • It is the only bactericidal drug active against dormant bacteria in solid caseous lesions.
  • It is the most effective and fastest-acting drug for leprosy.
  • It can cause light chain proteinuria and may impair antibody responses.
  • It is also hepatotoxic and may cause skin rash, flu-like syndrome (more prominent with intermittent regimen) and anaemia.

Option A: Para amino salicylic acid (PAS)

  • PAS is a second-line antitubercular drug.
  • It is a prodrug and acts by getting incorporated into the folate pathway and therefore inhibits dihydrofolate reductase enzymatic activity.
  • Side effects of PAS include:
    • Kidney and liver dysfunction
    • Thyroid dysfunction.

Option B: Pyrazinamide

  • Pyrazinamide is a first-line antitubercular drug used for the treatment of TB.
  • It is a prodrug that blocks the synthesis of coenzyme A.
  • Pyrazinamide acts against slowly dividing bacteria inside macrophages.
  • Side effects of pyrazinamide include:
    • Hepatotoxicity.
    • Hyperuricemia

Option D: Streptomycin

  • Streptomycin is a first-line drug used for the treatment of TB
  • Streptomycin irreversibly binds to the small 16S rRNA of the 30S ribosomal subunit.
  • This interferes with the binding of formyl-methionyl-tRNA to the 30S ribosomal subunit.
  • Adverse effects of streptomycin include:
    • Tinnitus
    • Vertigo
    • Ataxia
    • Nephrotoxicity

questions.text: Which of the following antiretroviral drugs is associated with acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Didanosine

  • The clinical features and laboratory investigations in the given clinical scenario suggest acute pancreatitis.
  • ART-induced pancreatitis should be considered an important cause in patients with HIV infection.
  • NRTIs, particularly didanosine and stavudine, are associated with an increased risk of pancreatitis. These drugs, on prolonged exposure, can cause mitochondrial toxicity due to the inhibition of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) polymerase.
  • Didanosine is the most commonly implicated antiretroviral drug in causing acute pancreatitis.

Option B: Indinavir

  • It belongs to HIV protease inhibitors.
  • It can cause stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, indigestion, and heartburn.
  • It is not associated with acute pancreatitis.

Option C: Raltegravir

  • It can cause severe skin rash, allergic reactions, and liver problems.
  • It is not associated with pancreatitis

Option D: Zidovudine

  • Zidovudine belongs to the nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) class and is commonly used in the HAART regimen.
  • The most serious side effect of zidovudine is bone marrow suppression
  • It is unlikely to cause pancreatitis

questions.text: A 33-year-old male with a family history of bipolar disorder was brought to a psychiatry clinic with complaints of elevated mood, non-stop talking, and paranoid behavior. His spouse mentions that he has not slept for five days and spent fifty thousand rupees on unnecessary shopping in a week. He is diagnosed with acute mania. Which of the following antipsychotics is the drug of choice for rapidly managing acute symptoms in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Haloperidol

  • In the given scenario, the adult suffers from an acute manic episode of bipolar disorder.
  • Antipsychotic medications like olanzapine, aripiprazole, quetiapine, risperidone, and haloperidol are the agents of choice for rapid control of the symptoms in severe mania, and these drugs are usually used in combination with lithium or valproic acid for the prophylaxis and maintenance pharmacotherapy of manic episodes and bipolar disorders.

Option A: Lithium Carbonate

  • Lithium is usually used in combination with antipsychotics for the maintenance therapy of severe mania and bipolar disorder.
    • It is a drug of choice in bipolar patients with some liver disease.

Option B: Phenobarbitone

  • Phenobarbitone is an anti-seizure medication used to manage generalized tonic-clonic seizures, status epilepticus, and partial seizures.

Option D: Valproic Acid

  • Valproic acid is a good alternative to lithium to be used in combination with antipsychotics for the maintenance therapy of severe mania and bipolar disorder.
    • It is preferred to lithium in bipolar patients with some renal disease.

questions.text: Which of the following medications used in preventing and treating angina acts mainly through the opening of cardiac potassium channels?
questions.solution:
Option B: Nicorandil

  • Based on the symptoms of severe left-sided chest pain, a significant history of hypertension, ischemic heart disease, and a history of taking nitrates, beta blockers and diuretics for the cardiac symptoms, the patient is likely suffering from angina pectoris.
  • Angina pectoris is characterized by recurrent attacks of retrosternal chest pain, pressure or tightness secondary to myocardial ischemia. Triggering factors include stress or exertion, which increases oxygen demand in the myocardium.
  • The objectives of management are to improve ischemia, reduce cardiovascular morbidity and mortality and maintain quality of life.
  • Nicorandil is a novel anti-angina drug that acts by activating potassium channels at myocytes and has arterial vasodilator properties. It activates ATP-sensitive K+ channels, thereby hyperpolarizing vascular smooth muscle.
  • At low doses, it possesses nitrate-like properties and dilates coronary arteries.
  • It acts as a potassium channel agonist at higher doses and reduces coronary arterial resistance by opening potassium channels. It also stimulates guanylate cyclase, which activates cyclic GMP, ultimately increasing nitric oxide concentration.
  • It is also believed to have cardioprotective action by mimicking 'ischemic preconditioning' by activating mitochondrial K-ATP channels.

Option A: Ranolazine

  • It shifts ATP production away from fatty acid oxidation, i.e., partial inhibition of fatty acid oxidation, in favour of more oxygen-efficient glucose oxidation.
  • It inhibits the late phase of sodium current, improving the oxygen supply and demand equation.
  • It has anti-anginal as well as antiarrhythmic properties.
  • Higher doses inhibit rapid delayed rectifier potassium current, thereby prolonging ventricular action potential.

Option C: Verapamil

  • It is a traditional anti-anginal drug.
  • It is a centrally acting calcium channel blocker acting mainly on cardiac myocytes.
  • It slows AV conduction directly and decreases HR, contractility, BP and oxygen demand.

Option D: Lidocaine

  • It is not an anti-anginal drug. Rather, it is a class IB antiarrhythmic drug.
  • It is a membrane-stabilizing antiarrhythmic agent.
  • Mainly recommended in controlling ventricular arrhythmias by suppression of automaticity in the His-Purkinje system and by suppression of spontaneous ventricular depolarization.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male factory worker presents to the emergency department complaining of nausea, vomiting and fatigue. There were three episodes of vomiting, which was a non-projectile, watery containing food particle. There was no blood. He was recently diagnosed with bladder adenocarcinoma. He has been advised chemotherapy. Episodes of vomiting occur 48 hours after the first chemotherapy (cisplatin) session. Which drug is given to alleviate the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option C: Aprepitant

  • Vomiting occurs after the first session of chemotherapy after 48 hours and is suggestive of chemotherapy-induced vomiting. Anti-emetics significantly reduce the frequency of vomiting.
  • Various classes of anti-emetics target different pro-emetic pathways to alleviate nausea and vomiting. These are as follows:
    • Dopamine antagonists
    • Serotonin antagonists
    • Neurokinin antagonists
    • Antihistamines
    • Anticholinergics
    • Corticosteroids
    • Benzodiazepines
    • Cannabinoids
  • Chemotherapy drugs release substance P, which then binds to neurokinin type 1 receptor mainly in the nucleus of the solitary tract to induce vomiting.
  • Neurokinins modulate the activity of emetic neurotransmitters.
  • Neurokinin antagonists block neurokinin type 1 receptors in the central and peripheral systems.
  • Neurokinin antagonists are as follows;
    • Aprepitant
    • Fosaprepitant
    • Netupitant
    • Netupitant/palonosetron
  • They are used in chemotherapy-induced vomiting and nausea.

Option A: Omeprazole

  • Omeprazole is a proton-pump inhibitor (PPI).
  • It acts by inhibiting H+/K+ ATPase present in the parietal cells of the stomach.
  • The inhibitory effects occur within one hour of administration and last 2 hours.
  • It is used to treat peptic ulcer disease and gastro-oesophagal reflux disease.
  • Long-term use is associated with an increased risk for osteoporosis.

Option B: Carbamazepine

  • Carbamazepine acts on voltage-gated sodium channels, causing inhibition of action potentials and decreased synaptic transmission.
  • It is used for epilepsy and trigeminal neuralgia.
  • The common side effects are dizziness, drowsiness, ataxia, nausea and vomiting.

Option D: Dexamethasone

  • Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid with anti-emetic and high anti-inflammatory effects.
  • It is a synthetic steroid.
  • The anti-emetic effect is due to the inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis.
  • Dexamethasone, in combination with ondansetron, is used to control post-operative vomiting and nausea.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male undergoing inguinal hernia repair is administered general anesthesia by an intern, who intends to use d-tubocurarine to relax skeletal muscles. However, the senior anaesthetist intervenes, citing d-tubocurarine's propensity to induce severe hypotension. What mechanism underlies d-tubocurarine's hypotensive effect?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above

  • d-Tubocurarine is a long-acting, non-depolarizing (competitive) neuromuscular blocking agent.
  • It is not used nowadays because of its severe cardiovascular side effects.
  • One of the serious cardiovascular effects is hypotension.
  • The mechanism by which d-Tubocurarine causes hypotension includes:
  • Ganglionic blockade (sympathetic ganglionic blockade results in loss of vascular tone leading to vasodilation)
  • Histamine release (releases histamine from mast cells due to the bulky nature of d-Tubocurarine, leading to flushing, bronchospasm, and increased respiratory secretions along with hypotension)
  • Reduced venous return (due to respiratory and limb muscle paralysis)
  • Heart rate may increase due to ganglionic blockade (predominant vagal supply).

 

Option A: Reduction of venous return

  • Reduction of venous return alone is not responsible for hypotension.

 

Option B: Ganglionic blockade

  • Ganglionic blockade alone is not responsible for hypotension.

 

Option C: Histamine release

  • Histamine release alone is not responsible for hypotension in a patient.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of stuff nose, sore throat, cough and hoarseness in voice in the morning session of the OPD. The doctor decided to send his sample for culture examination to the laboratory. The microbiologist cultured his sample on blood agar as shown in the image below. Identify the organism showing this Bacitracin sensitivity test.
questions.solution:
• The given image is showing Bacitracin sensitive organism.
  • Streptococcus pyogenes is bacitracin sensitive.
  • Staphylococus and Streptococcus agalactiae are bacitracin resistant.
Streptococcus pyogenes Streptococcus agalactiae
CAMP CAMP test (-) ve (+) ve
Hippurate hydrolysis test (-) ve (+) ve
Bacitracin SENSITIVE RESISTANT
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae :
    • Presents with a typical tonsillar pseudomembrane and bull neck appearance.
    • Potassium tellurite agar shows black colored colonies. Hence, excluded.

questions.text: A 22-year male presents to the emergency department with a fever and 2 days of bloody diarrhoea, and severe abdominal cramps. On examination, the boy looked very dehydrated with a blood pressure of 113/73 mmHg. On labs, the patient has an elevation of WBCs and ESR. The stool culture showed Gram-negative bacilli, non-motile, with no H2S production. Which of the following organism is the most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Shigella

  • The above clinical scenario raises the suspicion of shigellosis.
  • Points in favour of Shigella:
    • Gram negative bacilli
    • Non-motile
    • No H2S production
  • All other options are motile bacteria. Hence, excluded.

Other features of Shigella:

  • Mannitol fermentation-based classification was used.
  • Non mannitol fermenter → Shigella dysenteriae.
  • Catalase positive (Shigella dysenteriae type 1 is the exception).
  • VMA [virulence Marker Antigen] → responsible for invasiveness.
  • SHIGA TOXIN - Exotoxin produced by shigella dysenteriae.
  • The stool is the specimen of choice.
  • Diagnosis of shigellosis is made by isolating shigella spp. from faeces.
  • Transport media: Sachs’ buffered glycerol saline.
  • Also, sigmoidoscopy may take rectal swabs from the site of the ulcer.

Option B: Salmonella

  • Facultative gram-negative rods.
  • It is speciated with biochemical reactions and serotyped with O, H, and Vi antigens.
  • It is present in enteric tracts of humans and domestic animals, e.g., chickens and turtles.
  • Raw chicken and eggs in the kitchen, food-borne outbreaks.
  • It causes enterocolitis/gastroenteritis 6–48 hour incubation, nausea, vomiting and, loose stools, occasionally blood.
  • Self-limiting gastroenteritis.
  • Ampicillin, third-generation cephalosporin, fluoroquinolone, or TMP-SMX for invasive disease.
  • Prevention: properly cook foods and wash hands, particularly food handlers

Option  C: Enterohaemorrhagic E.coli

  • EHEC (VTEC): O157:H7
  • Verotoxin: Shigella-like toxins 1 and 2 decreased protein synthesis by interfering with the 60S ribosomal subunit.
  • No fever, no PMNs, blood in stool, non-fermenters of sorbitol; may progress to hemorrhagic colitis and HUS, most common in children age five.
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome risk associated with antibiotics

Option D: Campylobacter

  • Distinguishing Features: Gram-negative curved rods with polar flagella (“gulls’ wings”); oxidase-positive; microaerophilic; grows at 42˚C on campy or skirrow agar.
  • Reservoir: intestinal tracts of humans, cattle, sheep, dogs, cats, and poultry.
  • Transmission: fecal-oral, skirrow agar primarily from poultry
  • Pathogenesis: low infectious dose (as few as 500); invades mucosa of the colon, destroying mucosal surfaces; blood and pus in stools (inflammatory diarrhoea); rarely penetrates to cause septicemia.
  • Disease: gastroenteritis
    • A common cause of infectious diarrhoea worldwide.
    • Ten stools/day (maybe frankly bloody).
    • Abdominal pain, fever, malaise, nausea, and vomiting.
    • Generally self-limiting in 3–5 days but may last longer.
  • Treatment: mostly supportive, i.e., fluid and electrolyte replacement; erythromycin, fluoroquinolones; resistant to penicillins.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of uncontrolled diabetes presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of difficulty in breathing and persistent cough for several days. On examination, he has a black lesion on the upper bridge of the nose. His chest x-ray showed irregular solitary nodules. The physician recommended a tissue biopsy with H&E staining to ascertain the cause. The results of which showed Aseptate hyphae. Which of the following is the characteristic of the biopsy finding?
questions.solution:
Option B: Absidia

  • Aseptate hyphae characterize Absidia and Apophysomyces.
  • Absidia is a genus of zygote fungi in the family Cunninghamellaceae. Absidia species are ubiquitous in most environments, where they are often associated with warm decaying plant matter, such as compost heaps.
  • Absidia genus belonging to the Mucorales group of the Zygomycetes class is a ubiquitous saprophyte in the ground which may cause Zygomycosis.
  • Mucormycosis (Zygomycosis) is a fungal infection caused by Zygomycetes. Symptoms include fever, headache, coughing, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, bloody vomit, and possible altered mental status.

  • Hyphae may be septate or aseptate (coenocytic).
  • Aseptate hyphae are seen in:
    • Rhizopus (Image below)

    • Mucor (Image below)

    • Rhizomucor
    • Absidia
    • Basidiobolus
    • Conidiobolus
    • Saksanea
    • Cunninghamella
    • Apophysomyces
  • The image below: Broad aseptate hyphae of Mucormycosis

Option A: Aspergillus

  • It has septate hyphae.
  • Aspergillus: acute angle branching with septate hyphae (Image below)

Option C: Scedosporium

  • It has septate hyphae.
  • Superficial soft tissue infections after trauma.
  • Fungal keratitis (Image below).

Option D: Acremonium

  • It has septate hyphae.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents to the OPD with a complaint of abdominal pain and blood in the urine for the last three days. His examination reveals a blood pressure of 110/70mmHg with a regular pulse of 80/min. The rest of his general physical and systemic examinations are unremarkable. On microscopic examination of stools, sample eggs with terminal spine were seen. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Schistosoma haematobium

  • The scenario with blood in urine is suggestive of S. haematobium infection. Eggs having terminal spine eggs are characteristic of Schistosoma haematobium.
  • Schistosoma haematobium:
    • Resides in the Vesical plexus.
    • Causes squamous cell carcinoma of the urinary bladder> transitional cell carcinoma.
    • Causes terminal hematuria.
    • The egg has a terminal spine.
    • Eggs are excreted in the urine.
  • Five main Schistosoma species infect humans.
  • S. haematobium - eggs with the terminal spine (image below).

Option B: Schistosoma mansoni.

  • S. mansoni has eggs with the lateral spine.
  • S. mansoni causes Katayama fever.
  • S. mansoni - eggs with the lateral spine (image below).

Option C: Schistosoma japonicum

  • S. japonicum has a minute spine.
  • Round eggs with the minute spine (lateral knob) - image below.

Option D: Chlonorchis sinensis

  • Chinese or oriental liver fluke- embryonated operculated eggs.
  • Only S. haematobium is found in India.

questions.text: A 39-year-old homosexual HIV patient visits out door patient with OPD with complaints of visual disturbances. The patient is admitted as the patient has HIV. His CD4 count is measured, and on evaluation, the CD4 count measures 40 cells/mm3. All vitals are measured within normal limits. On Fundal examination, bilateral retinal exudates and perivascular haemorrhages are also noted. Physical examination and low CD4 indicate viral aetiology. A urine sample is collected for the PCR CMV test, and the results are suggestive of CMV retinitis. Which type of inclusion body is likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Intranuclear + Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies

  • HIV patients are highly at risk for Cytomegalovirus retinitis.
  • It occurs in almost 70% of HIV patients.
  • CD4 count of the patient can tell the possible infection.

 

CD4 count

Possible infection

<500

TB

<200

P. jiroveci

<100

Cerebral Toxoplasmosis

<50

CMV

M.A.C (mycobacterium avium complex)

 

Features of CMV (Cytomegalovirus) :

  • Largest herpes virus.
  • A person having a healthy immune system has a rare case of CMV infection. However, in immunosuppressed HIV patients, it can cause;
    • CMV retinitis (blurred vision, blind spots, floaters and retinal detachment).
    • Congenital CMV syndrome (hepatosplenomegaly, petechial lesions, chorioretinitis, calcification, microcephaly and mental retardation).
    • Mononucleosis-like syndrome (atypical lymphocytes [CD8 T cells mainly).
  • Histopathological examination of an infected cell has an owl eye appearance.
  • Inclusion bodies are the aggregate or viral factories in the nuclear and cytoplasmic regions of infected cells.
  • Both intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies are found in CMV infection.

Lab diagnosis of CMV:

  • Culture on human fibroblast cell line (W1-38)
  • PCR for CMV
  • ELISA for CMV

Option A: Intranuclear inclusion bodies

  •  Intranuclear inclusion bodies are found in viral infection.
  • In CMV, not only are intranuclear inclusion bodies found but also there are intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies.

Option B: Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies

  • Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies can be seen in RNA viruses.
  • There are not only intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies seen but also intranuclear bodies seen in CMV.

Option D:  None of the above

  • There are intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies seen in CMV.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy living in rural India had a history of cowpox infection. His sister's rash on the skin turned into a fluid-filled blister with a dent in the center. On history taking, the patient says it was just nausea, vomiting, and fever in the beginning. Later, she started having ulcers in the mouth and a rash that turned into blisters. The doctor suspected it was a contagious viral infection. The strange thing, in this case, is that the boy who is her brother, despite coming in contact with his sister multiple times, was not infected. The boy's protection from this disease by the previous infection is due to the?
questions.solution:
Option A: Antigenic cross-reactivity

The protection against smallpox by previous infection with cowpox represents antigenic cross-reactivity.

  • The above given is a case of smallpox. The fluid-filled blister with a dent in the center is characteristic of smallpox.
  • The initial mouth ulcer followed rash; eventually, blisters are a classical pattern for smallpox.
  • Antigenic cross-reactivity- Sometimes single antigen stimulates the production of various antibodies that more or less resemble the correct fit for the antigen.
  • Each of these antibodies may attack different antigens that more or less resemble one another.
  • Cross Reactivity: The ability of an individual antibody combining site to react with more than one antigenic determinant.
  • The ability of a population of antibody molecules to react with more than one Ag.

Option B: Activation Of B cell

  • Lymphocytes are part of the adaptive immune system.
  • Both T lymphocytes and B lymphocytes come under the same banner of the adaptive immune system.
  • Activation of B lymphocytes by T-lymphocytes leads to maturation of B-cell into plasma cells and antibodies formation from plasma.

Option C: Passive immunity

  • This immunity is conferred by the transfer of serum or lymphocytes from a specifically immunized individual.

Option D:Innate immunity

  •  It is the resistance that an individual possesses by birth.
  • It is not specific and is the first line of defense against pathogens.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man presents to the emergency with complaints of severe vomiting, fatigue, inability to urinate, and dehydration for 2 weeks. The patient has been a known case of end-stage renal disease for 6 months. He also has hypertension. Nephrosclerosis was determined to be the cause of renal disease. The doctor evaluated the patient for a kidney transplant, but within 5 hours of the transplant, the patient developed a high fever, swelling in the area of the kidney, and malaise. The physician has determined the hyperacute rejection to be causing these symptoms. Major histocompatibility complex plays a vital role in this type of rejection. Which of the following factor encodes with MHC genes to cause this rejection?
questions.solution:
Option B: TNF-alpha

  • The case presents a patient with nephrosclerosis who is in end-stage renal disease. In this condition, the arteries that carry blood to the kidney become stiff, and as a result, the kidney suffers badly.
  • End-stage renal disease usually presents with an array of symptoms that the patient has presented, like dehydration, urine cessation, confusion, and various others.
  • During the transplantation process, the patient suffers from hyper-acute rejection caused by the occupancy of existing antibodies in the receiver that recognizes antigens from the donor organ.
  • MHC comprises 4 different class of genes that encodes various factors on the cell's surface that helps recognize foreign objects. It is present on chromosome 6p.
  • Tumour necrosis factor-alpha encoded in the MHC class 3 gene is the cause of this rejection in this case. TNF has a pro-inflammatory function suggesting that it plays a role in initiating rejection.

Option A: Complement component C3

  • It is an essential protein of the human immune system that helps the body's innate immunity.
  • It is encoded on chromosome no 19 by the gene C3. People with this protein deficiency are more susceptible to bacterial infections.

Option C: Interleukin-2

  • It is produced by activated CD4+ T cells, CD8+ T cells, and dendritic cells. It is a pro-inflammatory cytokine that is secreted by Th1 cells.
  • It also helps in the growth of naïve T lymphocytes and B lymphocytes and plays a role in the development of the immune system.

Option D: Beta 2 microglobulin

  • It is a component of MHC class I molecules; they have α1, α2, and α3 proteins, which are present in all nucleated cells.

  • It helps bind proteins and plays a vital role in immunoglobulin transport and iron metabolism.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the physician with a complaint of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain for one day. He further explains that his symptoms started 5 hours after having street food. He has no history of diarrhoea or fever. The doctor suspected food poisoning and sent his sample to the lab, which revealed Gram-positive bacilli growth. Which food item is most likely to be associated with this type of food poisoning?
questions.solution:
Option D: Fried rice

  • This is a case of food poisoning.
  • Fried rice is most likely to be associated with this type of food poisoning.
  • The growth of Gram-positive bacilli suggests food poisoning caused by Bacillus species.
  • Food items associated:
    • Diarrheal type - Meat, vegetables, dried beans, cereals.
    • Emetic type - Rice (Chinese fried rice).
  • Bacillus cereus food poisoning is of two types. Emetic type and Diarrheal type, abdominal cramps are common features in both. Other features are:
    • Emetic Type: On ingestion of the rice, the toxin causes nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps after a short incubation period of 6 hours. Diarrhoea and fever are rare.
    • Diarrhoeal type: History of intake of cooked meat and vegetables 8-16 hours earlier. The symptoms include acute abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and nausea; vomiting is rare.

Option A: Meat

  • The food poisoning mentioned in this case is emetic type.

  • The food poisoning caused due to meat is diarrheal type.

Option B: Milk product

  • Brucellosis: Ingestion of raw milk or dairy products.

  • Staphylococcal food poisoning: Most common food items involved are milk products, bakery food, custards, potato salad, or processed meats.

Option C: Canned food

  • Botulism: Food-borne botulism occurs due to preformed toxins mixed with canned food.

questions.text: A Patient complaining of fever, chills, and haemoptysis was sent for sputum analysis, which showed white cottony mycelial growth on SDA media. He works as a miner. The physician made the diagnosis of Histoplasmosis. Which of the following statements about this condition is true?

choices.text: In the late stage, it is indistinguishable from TB
Person-to-person spread occurs by droplet infection

questions.solution:
Correct Answer

Option A: In the late stage, it is indistinguishable from TB

  • The fungus Histoplasma capsulatum causes Histoplasmosis.
  • Histoplasma capsulatum is found in bird droppings, soil, and decaying trees.
  • Infection by this fungus is acquired via inhalation of spores.
  • Most infected individuals are asymptomatic and heal spontaneously, leaving behind an area of miliary calcification.
  • Chronic cases of Histoplasmosis worsen and are indistinguishable from tuberculosis.
  • In chronic infections of Histoplasmosis, the patient presents with hemoptysis. Imaging shows apical cavities and calcifications resembling tuberculosis.
  • Histoplasmosis is also called Darling's disease.
  • Granulomatous and ulcerative lesions on the skin and mucous membranes are seen in severe infections.

Other Options

Option B: Culture is not diagnostic

  • Histoplasmosis is a dimorphic fungus. It exists in a mycelial form and a yeast form.
  • On Sabourad agar culture medium, white, cottony, mycelial growth appears. Large, thick-walled, spherical spores with tubercles are also seen.
  • These findings are characteristic of Histoplasma capsulatum.
  • Therefore, culture from the infected tissue is highly diagnostic for Histoplasmosis.

Option C: Hyphal forms are infectious form

  • Hyphal forms of Histoplasma capsulatum are found in the environment.
  • Hyphal forms of this fungus are not infectious.
  • The intracellular yeast form is infectious.
  • Histoplasma capsulatum exists in the environment as hyphae with microconidia and tuberculate macroconidia.

Option D: Person-to-person spread occurs by droplet infection

  • Histoplasma infection does not spread from person to person.
  • Suspected individuals get Histoplasmosis by breathing in the fungus from the air.
  • Tuberculate spores are inhaled, which then causes Histoplasmosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. The patient has multiple lacerations on his arms. The patient is alert and orientated to time and space with a GCS of 15/15. The patient is vitally stable. The patient is taken to the minor operation theatre for washing and stitching the wound. The house officer on duty asks his senior resident about the disinfection of bacteria and viruses at low pH. Which of the following should be the correct answer?
questions.solution:
Option D: Chlorine

  • In this case, the patient presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident.

  • The patient has multiple lacerations on his arm, for which he is taken to the minor operation theatre.

  • The patient's wounds will be washed and stitched

  •  in the minor operation theatre.

  • Proline sutures usually stitch the laceration wounds on the arms.

  • Chlorine is the disinfectant that is normally used for the disinfection of the wound at low ph.

  • The disinfection action of chlorine compounds is by the release of free chlorine.

  • When hypochlorite is added to water, hypochlorous acid is formed, a strong oxidising agent and an effective disinfectant.

  • Action is stable in even low ph.

  • Hypochlorite (1%) used for routine serological disinfection should not be used in the presence of formaldehyde as it is carcinogenic.

  • The major limitations of chlorine compounds are that they are:

  • Ineffective if used at an alkaline pH

  • Less effective in the presence of excess organic matter

  • Relatively unstable, especially if exposed to light.

Option A: Alcohol

  • Isopropyl alcohol quickly kills bacteria, fungi, and viruses, especially in concentrations between 60% and 90% alcohol and 10–40% filtered water.

  • Alcohol is not recommended for the sterilization of medical and surgical instruments.

Option B: Hexachlorophene

  • Hexachlorophene can be used to disinfect the skin before surgery, but its action is not stable at low ph.

Option C: Phenol

  • Phenol is usually used as a mouthwash for disinfecting the mouth.

  • It can be used for oral candidiasis or oral yeast infection.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man suffered fatal head injuries when he was hit by a lorry while riding his motorbike. His right leg had got entangled amidst the bike's broken parts. An autopsy of his body revealed a collection of blood in the subarachnoid space and multiple incision like clean wounds ranging from 5- 10 cm along the shin of his right leg. All of the following statements about incision-like lacerations are true except?

choices.text: Avulsion lacerated wound caused by blunt object

questions.solution:
Option B is the false statement about an incised-looking wound.

Avulsion Lacerations or Grinding Compression

  • Avulsion of the skin and subcutaneous tissues from the underlying structures can occur when a weight, such as a wheel of a big vehicle or a heavy piece of machinery, passes over the limb (shearing lacerations).
  • Known as 'flaying,' this is when a revolving wheel rips off the skin across a large region.
  • When a large vehicle drives over a body that has already been knocked down on the ground, it most commonly occurs on the legs.
  • Extensive abrading and bruising of the ripped skin's edges are possible.
  • Internally, the organs might be avulsed or pulled away from their attachments partially or totally.
  • The skin may not exhibit indications of damage in certain cases, but the sub-cut may.
  • Flapping/ Flaying: A flap of tissues is stripped off from the underlying bone.
  • Note: These fancy terms are of academic importance only because to a careful observer, Incised wounds look like incised and lacerations look like lacerations only.

Incised-looking laceration

  • The laceration looks like an incised wound (margins appear to be regular & clean cut)
  • It is a type of split laceration wound
  • Sites: Where the soft tissues are ‘sandwiched’ between an underlying bone and the weapon. eg., Scalp, shin, eyebrows, zygoma, iliac crest, knee etc.

questions.text: The HR of a company sent a notice to a 28 year old man who was absent quite frequently over the past month. He used to be a confident and alert employee until recently, when he started complaining of insects crawling beneath his skin. One of his friends also noticed that his pupils were constantly dilated. Which of the following conditions could this employee have?
questions.solution:
Option C: Chronic cocaine poisoning

  • Magnan's symptom or cocaine bugs is characteristic of Chronic cocaine poisoning, in which there is a feeling as if grains of sand are lying under the skin or some small insects are creeping on the skin giving rise to an itching sensation (formication, tactile hallucination).
  • The pulse is rapid, respirations rapid and deep, pupils dilated, headache, pallor of the skin, cyanosis, sweating, and the temperature is raised.

Option A: Parkinsonism

  • Parkinson’s disease can cause varying and progressive symptoms throughout its course. Some of the most common symptoms associated with the disease include:
    • Difficulty showing facial expressions
    • Muscle stiffness
    • Slowed, affected movements
    • Speech changes
    • Tremor, especially of one hand

Option B: Chronic depression

  • Dysthymia (Chronic Depression): A mood disorder consisting of the same cognitive and physical problems as in depression, with less severe but longer-lasting symptoms.
  • The gloomy black cloud overhead hangs around for so long that many people can’t even remember what it was like to not be depressed. They feel like they’ve always been exhausted, anti-social, emotionally hollow, and living on autopilot.

Option D: Acute barbiturate poisoning

  • BARBITURATE POISONING: Shallow respiration, deep coma, no response to painful stimuli, deep reflexes are depressed, subnormal temperature, low blood pressure, thready pulse, dilated pupils.

questions.text: The forensic team has begun its investigations at the crime scene. A well-known politician was found dead from a gunshot wound in his bedroom. The relatives and the political friend circle are alleging that he was murdered. On initial investigation, the victim was found with the shotgun lying next to his right hand and there was also a clear handwritten suicide note by the side of the bed. Which among the following  would help the team to confirm it to be suicidal in nature?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Gunshot residues in the hand

 

Explanation:

 

To differentiate between suicide and homicide, forensic evidence must demonstrate that the deceased fired the weapon. The most reliable indicator of this is the presence of gunshot residue (GSR) on the hand, especially on the dorsum (back) of the dominant hand and web space between thumb and index finger.

The presence of GSR particles (lead, barium, antimony) on the hand provides objective chemical evidence that the person discharged the firearm, strongly supporting a suicidal act.

Gunshot Residue testing (e.g., using SEM or Griess test) is the most reliable indicator that the victim personally fired the gun, helping to confirm suicide over homicide.

 

Forensic Significance of GSR:

Factor Suicide Homicide
GSR on deceased's hand Common Usually absent
Gun in hand May be present Can be staged
Suicide note Suggestive, not definitive May be forged
Fingerprints on weapon Helpful, but inconclusive Can be absent even in suicide

 

Fingerprint on the gun (Option A): While helpful, fingerprints can be planted or wiped, and the presence alone doesn’t confirm the person fired the weapon.

Blood on the gun (Option B): Blood may be present due to proximity to the wound, not necessarily from the act of firing.

Gun in hand (Option C): "Gun in hand" can be staged post-mortem. It is not a definitive sign of suicide.

questions.text: While reporting to the police who are investigating the death of the 30-year-old actress, the forensic team was enquired about the possible time frame of the murder. The forensic team has an approximate time of death which they determine from various observations. In the eyes, ‘trucking’ or segmentation of retinal blood vessels is one of the first observable signs.  The skin loses its elasticity and luster within the first few hours after death and appears pale. Histological examination of the skin,  shows no morphological changes within 6 hours post-mortem. All of the following can also be studied by the team to narrow the time frame of death, except?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cadaveric Spasm

  • Cadaveric spasm is a condition in which the muscles of the body which were in a state of contraction immediately before death, continue to be so after death without passing through the stage of primary relaxation.
  • Cadaveric spasm, being an antemortem phenomenon, reflects the last act of the subject performed before and at the time of his death. The cause and the manner of death may be judged.

Option B: Algor Mortis

  • Algor mortis is the cooling of the body that normally takes place after death, where the body temperature equilibrates with its environmental temperature.
    • It is a sign of death.
    • It helps in the estimation of the time of death.
    • Rapid cooling of a dead body delays the processes of rigor mortis and decomposition. If the heat is preserved for a longer period, then both processes start early.

Option C: Rigor mortis

  • Rigor mortis (stiffness of death) is the state of the muscles in a dead body when they become stiff or rigid with some degree of shortening.
  • It is a sign of death and indicates molecular death of the muscle involved.

Option D: Livor Mortis

  • Postmortem staining or PM staining is bluish or purplish-red discolouration resulting from the gravitational settling of blood in the toneless capillaries and venules of the dependent parts of the dead body.
    • It is a sign of death.
    • The time since death can be roughly estimated from the formation, extension and fixation of the PM staining.
    • It indicates the posture of the body at the time of death.

questions.text: Marsh test, a method for the detection of a particular element so sensitive that it can be used to detect minute amounts of it in foods (the residue of fruit spray) or in stomach contents. The sample is placed in a flask with free zinc and sulfuric acid. The gaseous form of the element (also hydrogen) forms and is led through a drying tube to a hard glass tube in which it is heated. The gaseous form has a characteristic garlic odor. This test, named after its inventor, the English chemist James Marsh, is used for the detection of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: Arsenic

  • Detection by atomic absorption spectroscopy: Marsh's test and Reinsch's tests are absolute.
  • Arseniuretted hydrogen or arsine is a colorless gas with a garlic-like, non-irritating odor.
  • Arsenic is used in fruit sprays, sheep-dips, weed-killers, insecticides, rat poisons, fly papers, calico-printing, taxidermy, wallpapers, and artificial flowers, as mordant in dyeing and for preserving timber and skin against white ants.

Option A: Lead

  • TEST: Hydrochloric acid produces a white precipitate, soluble in boiling water, and crystallizes on cooling.
  • Signs and Symptoms: Anemia; Burtonian line/Basophilic stippling, Bone lines, Colic, Constipation (dry belly ache); Drop (wrist/Foot drop) - Lead palsy, Encephalopathy, Facial pallor (earliest sign), Gout (saturnine gout), Hypertension, Impotence.

Option B: Mercury

  • In mercury poisoning, we can see black blue lines of gums, intentional tremors (hatters shaking palsy); erethism, acrodynia or pinks disease, mercuria lentis, minimata disease; membranous glomerulopathy.
  • TEST: If a piece of copper wire is introduced into the solution and a few drops of hydrochloric acid are added, a silver coating of mercury will be formed on the wire.

Option D: Nickel

  • The symptoms of nickel poisoning: Headache, Nausea, Vomiting, Dizziness, Irritability, and Difficulty Sleeping.
  • The second group of symptoms will become more severe after a few days: Chest Pains, Sweating, Rapid Heart Beat, and Dry Cough. These symptoms are similar to pneumonia but may be fatal in the case of nickel poisoning.

questions.text: 20 pregnant women were asked about their history of smoking when they came for a regular antenatal visit and then followed up to see how many of them had low birth weight babies. What is the type of study?
questions.solution:
• 20 pregnant women were asked about their history of smoking when they came for a regular antenatal visit and then followed up to see how many of them had low birth weight babies.
  • Since the persons with exposure were followed to see the occurrence of the disease, this is an example of a Prospective Cohort.
  • Prospective cohort study
    • This study design gives us incidence and RR which is very accurate.
    • Advantage is very accurate.
    • Major disadvantage is time taking.
  • Retrospective Cohort Study
    • The combination of prospective cohort study and case-control study is known as a retrospective cohort study.
    • This study gives Incidence, RR, AR, PAR, and this study also saves time.
  • Mixed Cohort Study
    • Combination of both retrospective & prospective cohort study.
    • Mixed cohort study is the cohort study because the direction is from exposure to outcome.

questions.text: A researcher draws an unbiased sample of 100 adult Delhiites and finds that their mean weight is 72 kg with a standard deviation of 1.5. 95% of the weight of Delhiites shall be between:
questions.solution:
Option B: 69 and 75 kg

  • Mean (μ) + 2 SD (s): 95 % of total values
  • In the given question,
    • n = 100 adult Delhiites,
    • Mean weight (µ) = 72kg,
    • Standard deviation (SD) = 1.5
  • 95% weight of Delhiites = Mean ± 2SD (µ ± 2SD) = 72 ± 2 (1.5) = 72 ± 3 =b/w 69 & 75 kg wt.

questions.text: Which among the following is the study design of choice for finding out The average fat intake of the adult population is 20gm/day in a city?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option D: Ecological study

  • ECOLOGICAL STUDY

    · Done at a point of time

    · Generally used for Nutritional surveys

    · E.g., Average fat intake of adult population is 20gm/day in a city

    · Can't calculate incidence, RR, OR, strength of Association or Prevalence

    · RC > PC > CC > CS > E

    · Based on secondary data (collected by someone else, studied by investigator)

Other options

Option A: Prospective cohort

  • Prospective cohort: This study design gives us incidence and RR which is very accurate.
  • This study is not done at a point of time.
  • Major disadvantage: Time-consuming.

Option B: Ambispective cohort

  • Ambispective cohort: Observations are bidirectional (past and future both) from the time point it begins.

Option C: Case-control

  • A case-control study is not done at a point of time.
  • It is better for rare diseases.
  • A case-control study has 2 groups.
    • Cases: Having the disease.
    • Controls: Comparison groups (not having the disease).
  • We ask about the history of the same exposure in both groups & then compare both groups.

questions.text: The secondary level of prevention includes all of the following, except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Reconstructive surgery in leprosy

  • Reconstructive surgery in leprosy aims to rehabilitate the patient.
  • Thus it is a form of Tertiary level of prevention.

Option A: Health screening for diabetes mellitus

  • The health screening of Diabetes Mellitus is a secondary level of prevention.
  • Secondary prevention refers to an action that halts the progress of a disease.

Option B: Case finding for falciparum malaria

  • The case finding for falciparum malaria is done with the help of screening tests. Hence, it is a form of secondary level of prevention.
  • All screening & diagnostic tests come under the secondary level of prevention.

Option C: Contact tracing for STIs

  • Contact tracing for STIs represents a secondary level of prevention.
  • As it is an action that halts the progress of the disease, it is grouped under secondary prevention.

questions.text: A rural village is reporting many cases of disease with similar symptoms among the villagers. Which of the following is the most economical and best screening method?
questions.solution:
Option B: High risk screening

  • In High-risk screening, besides effectiveness, economical use of resources is also seen as screening tests are selectively applied to individuals in high-risk groups.
  • High-risk selective screening gives maximum yield. E.g., HIV screening in commercial sex workers.
  • Therefore, it is the most economical and best screening method.

Option A: Mass screening

  • Mass screening simple means screening of a whole population or subgroup.
  • Since in village many villagers developed similar symptoms High risk screening would be appropriate.

Option C: Multiphasic screening

  • Application of two or more screening tests in combination to a large number of people at one time.
  • Frist of all this not economical and there are more than one tests applied in multiphasic screening, so it is incorrect regarding the scenario mentioned above.

Option D: None of the above

  • Since high risk screening is correct answer, so this option is incorrect.

Learning Objective

  • Multiphasic screening means application of two or more screening tests in combination to a large number of people at one time.
  • High risk/ selective screening when applied selectively to high risk groups.
  • Mass screening means screening of a whole population or subgroup.

questions.text: Calories are units that measure the energy in food and the energy produced, stored, and utilized by living organisms. What is the caloric requirement of adult male workers with moderate activity levels?
questions.solution:
Option C: 2710 Kcal/day

NEW NUTRITION GUIDELINES

Set up by Agencies:

  • ICMR (Indian Council of Medical Research) at Delhi.
  • NIN (National Institutional of Nutrition) at Hyderabad.
  • DHR (Department of Health Research) & MOHFW (Ministry of Health and Family Welfare) Delhi.

Caloric requirement of Adult Male worker:

  • Sedentary level of activity: 2110 Kcal/day
  • Moderate level of activity: 2710 Kcal/day
  • Heavy level of activity: 3470 Kcal/day.

Option A: 1660 Kcal/day

  • This is recommended for a sedentary active adult female.

Option B: 2110 Kcal/day

  • This is recommended for a sedentary active adult male.

Option D: 3470 kcal/day

  • This is recommended for those doing Heavy levels of activity in adult males.

questions.text: Xerophthalmia is considered a public health problem if the prevalence of bitot's spot is more than?
questions.solution:
Option C: 0.5 %

Vitamin A deficiency:

  • The signs of vitamin A deficiency are predominantly ocular.
  • They include night blindness, conjunctival xerosis, Bitot's spots, corneal xerosis, and keratomalacia.
  • The term "xerophthalmia" (dry eye) comprises all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency ranging from night blindness to keratomalacia.

Option A: 0.01 %

  • Corneal xerosis/ corneal ulceration/ keratomalacia prevalence of more than 0.01 percent is to be considered evidence of a xerophthalmia problem in the community.

Option B: 0.05 %

  • Corneal ulcer prevalence of more than 0.05 percent is to be considered evidence of a xerophthalmia problem in the community.

Option D: 1 %

  • Night blindness prevalence of more than 1 percent is to be considered evidence of a xerophthalmia problem in the community.

questions.text: A rural village after massive outbreak of malaria was undergoing massive mosquito control drive. All of the following are Organophosphate insecticides except?
questions.solution:
Option A: Dieldrin

  • Dieldrin is actually one the example for organochlorine.

Organophosphorus insecticides

  • Malathion
  • Parathion
  • Fenthion
  • Diazion
  • Fenitrothion
  • Chlorpyrifos
  • Dioxathion
  • Chlorthion

Organochlorine insecticides

  • DDT
  • BHC (HCH)
  • Lindane
  • Dieldrin

Carbamate insecticides

  • Carbaryl
  • Propoxur

Option B/ C/ D: Fenthion/ Diazion/ Chlorpyrifos

  • All of these options mentioned above are example for Organophosphates.

Learning Objective

  • Organochlorine insecticides
    • DDT
    • BHC (HCH)
    • Lindane
    • Dieldrin
  • Carbamate insecticides
    • Carbaryl
