    • Propoxur

questions.text: A community medicine intern was asked to measure the air humidity of a given area using the instrument shown below. Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
Option A: Sling Psychrometer

  • Sling Psychrometer: Used for air humidity levels.

Other options

Option B: Kata Thermometer

  • Kata Thermometer (red bulb present at its end): used to measure low air velocity (previously used for cooling power).

Option C: Chloroscope

  • Chloroscope: Used to estimate free chlorine levels in the water.

Option D: Horrock’s apparatus

  • Horrock’s apparatus: Estimates chlorine demand of water.

questions.text: An accredited social health activist is a community health worker instituted by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare as a part of the National Rural Health Mission. Which of the following is the ‘Impact indicator’ for the evaluation of ASHA’s performance?
questions.solution:
Option C: Reduction in infant mortality

  • The most important ‘Impact indicator’ for the evaluation of ASHA’s performance is the Reduction in infant mortality.
  • Impact indicators for the evaluation of ASHA’s performance:
    • TB cases
    • Leprosy cases
    • Protein Energy Malnutrition rates.
    • ↓ Infant Mortality Rates (Most important indicator).

Option A: Number of meetings attended

  • Number of meetings attended is not an impact indicator for the evaluation of ASHA's performance.

Option B: Number of institutional deliveries

  • Number of ASHA visits in case of delivery (6 visits in Institutional deliveries): On Days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42 post-delivery.

Option D: Hours of training

  • Hours of training is is not an impact indicator for the evaluation of ASHA's performance.

questions.text: A rural PHC reported many cases of xeropthalmia among the village population. Which among the following is the correct sequence of symptoms in Xerophthalmia?

choices.text: Corneal xerosis → Night blindness → Conjunctival xerosis → Keratomalacia
Conjunctival xerosis → Corneal xerosis → Keratomalacia → Night blindness
Night blindness → Conjunctival xerosis → Corneal xerosis → Keratomalacia
Corneal xerosis → Conjunctival xerosis → Keratomalacia → Night blindness

questions.solution:
Option C: Night blindness → Conjunctival xerosis → Corneal xerosis → Keratomalacia

  • Option C is the correct sequence of symptoms in Xerophthalmia.
  • The correct sequence of symptoms in Xerophthalmia is Night blindness→Conjunctival xerosis→Corneal xerosis→Keratomalacia.

Other options

Option A: Corneal xerosis → Night blindness → Conjunctival xerosis → Keratomalacia

  • Night blindness is the first manifestation and symptom of xerophthalmia.
  • This is not the correct sequence of symptoms in Xeropthalmia.

Option B: Conjunctival xerosis → Corneal xerosis → Keratomalacia → Night blindness

  • Night blindness is the first manifestation and symptom of xerophthalmia.

  • Prevalence of night blindness > 1%

  • Conjunctival xerosis is the first of Vitamin A deficiency.
  • This is not the correct sequence of symptoms in Xeropthalmia.

Option D: Corneal xerosis → Conjunctival xerosis → Keratomalacia → Night blindness

  • Night blindness is the first manifestation and symptom of xerophthalmia.
  • The correct sequence of symptoms in Xerophthalmia is Night blindness→Conjunctival xerosis→Corneal xerosis→Keratomalacia.
  • This is not the correct sequence of symptoms in Xeropthalmia.

questions.text: A state in India had a massive earthquake on 26th January. All of the following can cause an epidemic in the post-disaster period, except?
questions.solution:
Option A: Leishmaniasis

  • The most commonly reported disease in the post-disaster phase is Gastroenteritis.
  • Diseases common in Post-disaster Phase: Gastroenteritis (MC), Acute respiratory tract infections (Pneumonia), Leptospirosis, Rickettsiosis, Rabies, and Equine encephalitis.
  • Leishmaniasis cannot cause an epidemic in the post-disaster period as it spreads through the sand fly.
  • DOC: Liposormal Amphotericin B 10mg/kg single dose.

Option B: Leptospirosis

  • A blood infection called leptospirosis is brought on by the Leptospira bacteria. There are several levels of signs and symptoms, including none, mild (fever, headaches, and muscle discomfort), and severe (bleeding in the lungs or meningitis).
  • Weil's disease, the acute severe type of leptospirosis, results in bleeding, kidney failure, and jaundice . Leptospirosis-related lung bleeding is referred to as severe pulmonary haemorrhage syndrome.

Option C: Scabies

  • Scabies, is a skin infection caused by Sarcoptes scabiei. The most common sign of scabies is severe itching where the mites have made their burrows.

Option D: Acute respiratory infections

  • Acute respiratory tract infections (Pneumonia) is also common during post-disaster phase.

questions.text: National strategic plan on HIV was brought into action by the government. Which of the following is/are not true about 90-90-90 policy in AIDS Control?

choices.text: 90% of those who are HIV positive in the country know their status
90% of those who know their status are on treatment
90% of those who are on treatment experience effective viral load suppression

questions.solution:
Option B: 90% reduction in new HIV Infections

  • 75% reduction in new HIV Infections.

Option A/ C/ D: 90% of those who are HIV positive in the country know their status/ 90% of those who know their status are on treatment/ 90% of those who are on treatment experience effective viral load suppression

  • Options A, C, and D are true about the 90-90-90 policy in AIDS Control.
  • The term 90-90-90 means:
    • 90% of those who are HIV positive in the country know their status.
    • 90% of those who know their status are on treatment.
    • 90% of those who are on treatment experience effective viral load suppression.

Learning Objective

  • 90-90-90 in AIDS Control is a target under National Strategic Plan on HIV/AIDS and STI, 2017-24 to be achieved by year 2020.
  • The term 90-90-90 means:
    1. 90% of those who are HIV positive in the country know their status.
    2. 90% of those who know their status are on treatment.
    3. 90% of those who are on treatment experience effective viral load suppression.

questions.text: The annual parasite index (API) refers to high and moderate malaria transmission risk areas. Which of the following is/are not the activities in the modified plan of operation in areas where API < 2?

choices.text: Active and passive surveillance every fortnight
Insecticidal spray with rounds of HCH every 6 weeks
Radical treatment of all cases detected

questions.solution:
Option B: Insecticidal spray with rounds of HCH every 6 weeks

  • Insecticidal spray with rounds of HCH every 6 weeks is the activity in the modified plan of operation in areas where API > 2; not in areas where API < 2.
  • All other options are activities in the area where API < 2.
  • Areas with API <2:
    • A focal spray of DDT of a case of Pf occurs in the area.
    • Active and passive surveillance.
    • Presumptive treatment to all suspected fever cases.
    • Ensuring radical treatment to those found positive on a blood smear.
    • Epidemiological investigation of cases to determine causative factors.

Option A: Active and passive surveillance every fortnight

  • Active and passive surveillance every front night is an activity in the area where API < 2.

Option C:  Radical treatment of all cases detected

  • Ensuring radical treatment to those found positive on a blood smear is an activity in the area where API < 2.

 Option D: Mass surveys

  • The mass survey is also an activity in the area where API < 2.

questions.text: Identify the symbol as shown in the photograph?
questions.solution:
Option D: NREGA Act 2005

  • NATIONAL RURAL EMPLOYMENT GUARANTEE ACT (NREGA) 2005.
  • Provide 100 days of guaranteed wage employment every year to every household whose adult members volunteer to do ‘unskilled manual work’.

Option A: Organ Transplantation Act 1994

  • The Act's major goals are to control the removal, preservation, and transplantation of human organs for medical treatment and to forbid the commercial use of human organs.
  • The Act contains specific provisions regarding the authority for organ removal, organ preservation, hospital regulation regarding organ removal, storage, or transplantation, functions of the appropriate authority, hospital registration, and punishment/penalties for offenses relating to the aforementioned matters.

Option B: RTI Act 2005

  • Responses to citizen requests for government information must be made promptly under the Right to Information Act of 2005.
  • The Right to Information Act's main goals is to empower citizens, encourage accountability and openness in government operations, combat corruption, and truly make democracy work for the people.

Option C: MTP Act 1971

MTP Act 1971

  • Indications
    • H - Humanitarian 
    • E - Eugenic 
    • T - Therapeutic/Medical 
    • S - Social 
    • Failure of contraceptive devices
  • Educational Qualification
    •  6 months of housemanship in OBG
    • Postgraduate OBG
    • 3 years of practice in OBG for those registered before the act was passed.
    • 1 year of practice in OBG for those doctors registered after the date of commencement of the Act
  •  Experience: ≥ 25 supervised MTP's
  •  Timing 
    • Permitted only 0-20 weeks Pregnancy of gestation
    •  Low risk 0-12 w (1 doctor opinion)
    •  High risk 12-20 w (2 doctor opinions)
  • Centre:  Authorized by GOI

questions.text:
The risk factor association of smoking with pancreatic cancer was studied in a case-control study. The values are:


	
		
			Group
			Odds ratio
			95% Confidence limits
		
		
			
			A

			B

			C
			
			
			2.5

			1.4

			1.6
			
			
			1.0-3.1

			1.1-1.7

			0.9-1.7
			
		
	


Which of the following is correct?

choices.text: Risk is more associated with Group A
Risk is more associated with Group B
Risk is more associated with Group C
Risk is equally associated with all three groups

questions.solution:
Option B: Risk is more associated with Group B

  • Both Group A Confidence interval (1.0 - 3.1), as well as Group C confidence interval (0.9 - 1.7), contains 1 in their range so there is a possibility of the true value of the strength of association being 1 (implying no association).
  • Group B (Cl = 1.1 - 1.7) has no such possibility, so this value of Odds ratio (1.4) may be least in all three groups but shows more association.

Option A: Risk is more associated with Group A

  • Group A Confidence interval (1.0 - 3.1): Contains 1 in their range so there is a possibility of the true value of the strength of association being 1 (implying no association).

Option C: Risk is more associated with Group C

  • Group C confidence interval (0.9 - 1.7): Contains 1 in their range so there is a possibility of the true value of the strength of association being 1 (implying no association).

Option D: Risk is equally associated with all three groups

  • Risk is not equally associated with all three groups.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with ASCVD complained of palpitations for the last 4 hours. On examination, her heart rate was 180 beats/min with Blood pressure 90/60 mmHg. Neck veins are fully distended. On auscultation, carotid artery bruit was present with loud S1 and narrow split S2. The chest had bilateral basal crepitations. Which of the following is not recommended for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Carotid sinus massage

Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia

The ECG in this patient shows narrow complex tachycardia with a heart rate of approximately 180 beats/min, likely paroxysmal supra-ventricular tachycardia.

  • The P waves are absent, and the RR interval is reduced and regular. ST segment depression is noted in most leads.
  • The first line of management is by carotid sinus massage; however, the carotid sinus massage is contraindicated in patients with carotid artery bruit (due to the presence of atherosclerotic plaque in the vessel wall)
  • Known cases of ASCVD (Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease)and atherosclerotic narrowing of the carotid artery (Carotid artery bruit).
  • If a carotid sinus massage is given to this patient, it can lead to the development of embolic stroke due to physical damage to atherosclerotic plaque in the carotid artery.
  • If it is unsuccessful, DC cardioversion is indicated.

Option B: Face ice pack

  • In children, supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) is a dangerous dysrhythmia.
  • Traditional vagal techniques, certain pharmaceuticals, cardioversion, and the application of freezing water to the face are all part of the first course of therapy.​​​​​​​

Option C: Adenosine

  • Adenosine will restore normal sinus rhythm so it can be used

Option D: Verapamil

  • Verapamil is an antiarrhythmic drug
  • IV verapamil is used for PSVT for rate control.

questions.text: A 28 years male presents to OPD complaining of pain abdomen, shortness of breath and dizziness. Examination shows a distended abdomen and visible ascites. The consultant suspects a malignancy. To make the scenario more clear, CECT abdomen is advised. Oral contrast in 1 litre of water is given to the patient. He develops an allergic reaction to contrast, and there is a worsening of kidney function. Which of the following is the best marker to evaluate contrast nephropathy?
questions.solution:
Option A: High Serum creatinine

  • Serum creatinine is an important indicator of kidney health because it is an easily measured byproduct of muscle metabolism that is excreted unchanged by the kidneys.
  • If creatinine is high, then this indicates renal insult has occurred, and kidneys are unable to excrete creatinine.
  • Contrast-induced nephropathy is defined as the impairment of kidney function measured as either a 25% increase in serum creatinine from baseline or a 0.5 mg/dL increase in absolute serum creatinine value—within 48-72 hours after intravenous contrast administration.

Option B: Low Serum Creatinine

  • Serum creatinine is an important indicator of kidney health
  • Low creatinine is unlikely to be significant for AKI
  • Low creatinine levels mean something is affecting creatine production in the body. This will often result from a person having low muscle mass or body weight.

Stages

S. creatinine

Urine output

Time

1

1.5-1.9 times of normal

<0.5ml/Kg/hr

6 hr

2

2.0-2.9 times of normal

<0.5ml/Kg/hr

12 hrs

3

>3.0 times of normal or

creatinine >4 mg%

<0.3ml/kg/hr

24 hrs

Option C: High Serum Bilirubin

  • Bilirubin is the end product of heme metabolism and is used as a marker of liver damage
  • Bilirubin has no significance, in contrast, induce nephropathy

Option D: Low Serum Bilirubin

  • Bilirubin is the end product of heme metabolism and is used as a marker of liver damage
  • Bilirubin has no significance, in contrast, induce nephropathy

questions.text: A 41-year-old male patient presents with recurrent episodes of bloody diarrhoea for 5 years. Despite regular treatment with adequate doses of sulfasalazine, he has had several exacerbations of his disease and required several weeks of steroids to control flares. What should be the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Option B: Azathioprine

  • Azathioprine and 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP) are purine analogues commonly employed in managing glucocorticoid-dependent IBD.
  • Azathioprine is rapidly absorbed and converted to 6-MP, which is then metabolized to the active end product, thioinosinic acid, an inhibitor of purine ribonucleotide synthesis and cell proliferation.
  • These agents also inhibit the immune response. Efficacy can be seen as early as 3-4 weeks but can take up to 4-6 months.

  • Probiotics have been shown to reduce disease activity in IBD
    • Lactobacillus
    • Bifidobacterium
    • Taenia suis
    • Saccharomyces boulardii

Option A: Methotrexate

  • Methotrexate is not used for IBDs.
  • It is used in Rheumatoid arthritis

Option C: Cyclosporine

  • Cyclosporine can be used in the acute exacerbation of IBDs and those resistant to azathioprines and 6-MP.
  • It is also used in post-renal transplantation.

Option D: Cyclophosphamide

  • Cyclophosphamide is used to treat cancer of the ovaries, breast, blood and lymph system, and nerves (mainly in children).
  • Cyclophosphamide is also used for retinoblastoma (a type of eye cancer mainly in children), multiple myeloma (cancer in the bone marrow), and mycosis fungoides (tumours on the skin).

questions.text: A 40-year-old non-smoker male presents to the emergency department with complaints of cough and right-sided pleuritic chest pain for 10 days. He also has had a fever for 1-day. A chest x-ray is done, showing Palla's sign. What is the most common ECG finding for the given clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Sinus tachycardia

The clinical features and x-ray findings of Palla's sign point towards a case of Pulmonary embolism.

  • ECG abnormality in pulmonary embolism shows Sinus tachycardia.
  • The major complaints of the patient are unexplained breathlessness and right-sided pleuritic chest pain.
  • The screening test which is done for this condition is the D-dimer test.
  • A severe strain on the right side of the heart is indicated when there is a strong S wave in lead I, a Q wave in lead III, and an inverted T wave in lead III. It is estimated that only around ten percent of persons who have pulmonary embolisms would exhibit this pattern, which is analogous to the ECG findings of a left posterior fascicular block, abbreviated as LPFB.
  • The classic findings of right heart strain and acute cor pulmonale are tall, peaked P waves in lead II (P pulmonale), right axis deviation, right bundle-branch block, and S1Q3T3 pattern.

Palla's sign and Wester mark sign:

Chest radiograph findings:

  • Posterior–anterior view showing a lateral wedge-shaped opacity (white arrow) in the right lower zone (Hampton’s hump), a focal area of oligemia (space between white arrowheads) in the right lower zone (Westermark’s sign), and a prominent right descending pulmonary artery (black arrow) (Palla’s sign).

Option B: S1 Q3 T2

Instead, S1Q3T3 Pattern is seen: This pattern includes:

  • S wave in lead I
  • Q wave and inverted T wave in lead III
  • This pattern is indicative of right heart strain, often seen in acute pulmonary embolism.

Option C: Elevated ST segment

  • Elevated ST segment is not present with Pulmonary embolism.

Option D: Absent P waves

  • Absent P waves are present with Pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female tourist to India presents with a complaint of diffuse chest pain. There is no personal history and no family history of heart disease, hypertension, and diabetes. She is admitted for observation, and the next morning she has a recurrence of chest pain, and ECG shows ST elevation in V1 to V4. Troponin is normal, and pain is promptly relieved by sublingual nitroglycerine. Which of the following is the best management plan for this patient?

choices.text: Exercise stress testing and long-acting nitrates
Coronary angiography with long-acting nitrates and CCB

questions.solution:
Option C: Coronary angiography with long-acting nitrates and CCB

  • The clinical features in these cases are most suggestive of vasospastic angina or Prinzmetal angina.
  • Prinzmetal or vasospastic angina is caused by the transient spasm of coronary arteries. There is no direct association with atherothrombotic occlusion; however, these spasms usually occur close to the areas of coronary stenosis.
  • The clinical features that suggest the diagnosis of vasospastic angina, in this case, are transient chest pain with transient ST elevation, occurring at rest or without known precipitant, and relieving by nitrates. Moreover, the relatively younger age, along with the absence of typical risk factors of heart disease (hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia) and the absence of a family history of heart disease, point towards the diagnosis of vasospastic angina.
  • In vasospastic angina, the ECG shows evidence of ischemia during pain, sometimes with ST-segment elevation. The cardiac enzymes are not elevated.
  • On coronary angiography, vasospastic angina is characterized by the demonstration of no significant obstruction of major coronary vessels. The angiography can help reveal coronary vasospasm during the acute attack (the spasm can be provoked using acetylcholine or ergonovine).
  • The treatment of vasospastic angina comprises long-acting nitrates along with calcium channel blockers.

Option A: Echocardiography and anti-inflammatory therapy

  • Echocardiography will offer no diagnostic help in the setting of acute chest pain suggestive of vasospastic angina.
  • There is no role of anti-inflammatory therapy in vasospastic angina. It is mainly treated by nitrates and calcium channel blockers.

Option B: Exercise stress testing and long-acting nitrates

  • Exercise stress testing and long-acting nitrates are done for chronic stable angina. In the case of vasospastic angina, the initial goal is to control the coronary spasm with a calcium channel blocker. Nitrates can be added to provide symptomatic control.

Option D: Thallium scan and long-acting nitrates

  • Thallium scans and long-acting nitrates are used for chronic stable angina. In vasospastic angina, the goal is to control the coronary spasm with a calcium channel blocker. Nitrates can be added to provide symptomatic control.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with the complaint of Headache, drowsiness, and palpitations. On examination, his blood pressure is 160/110 mm Hg, and his pulse is 86 beats/min. ECG shows flattened T waves. Serum electrolytes reveal K+ = 2.9 mEq/L, Bicarbonate = 34 mEq/L, also there is decreased aldosterone. A diagnosis of Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with severe hypertension has been made. Which of the following is the likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Liddle syndrome

Liddle syndrome:

  • Autosomal dominant, gain-in-function mutations of ENaC subunits.
  • Activating kidneys to excrete potassium retaining excessive sodium & water, leading to hypertension.
  • ↓ Aldosterone and Hypokalemia with hypertension is a characteristic feature of Liddle syndrome.

Option B: Bartter syndrome

  • Primary defect at Na/K/Cl channel at the Ascending loop of henle.
  • Benign condition
  • May cause hypokalemia, acidosis and hypercalciuria.

Option C: Gitelman syndrome

  • Milder form of bartter syndrome.
  • Defect is at Na/Cl cotransporter at DCT
  • Presents with hypercalciuria.

Option D: Renal tubular acidosis

  • Renal tubular disorders are a heterogeneous group of diseases that involve dysfunctions of transporters and channels in the renal tubular system.
  • These dysfunctions may cause fluid loss and abnormalities in electrolyte and acid-base homeostasis.
  • The disorders are either primary (genetic) or acquired (e.g., drug adverse effects, renal disease).
  • In renal tubular acidosis (RTA), there is normal anion gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis in a patient with normal or almost normal renal function.
  • Types of RTA include distal tubular acid secretion (type 1), proximal tubular bicarbonate wasting (type 2), very rarely carbonic anhydrase deficiency (type III), and aldosterone deficiency/resistance (type 4).

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presented to Emergency with the complaint of 2 episodes of hematemesis. The last episode occurred about 4 hours ago. She is a known case of peptic ulcer disease and gives a history of similar episodes in the past. Vital signs show a blood pressure of 100/70 mmHg and a pulse rate of 86 beats per min. After initial management, an upper gastrointestinal tract endoscopy was done, which revealed bleeding from the lesser curvature of the stomach. Which of the following arteries is the most likely source of bleeding?
questions.solution:
Option D: Left gastric artery

  • The celiac artery gives rise to the left gastric artery, which runs along the superior part of the stomach's minor curvature. Branches also supply the lower oesophagus. The right stomach artery flows from right to left, anastomoses with the left gastric artery. It is important to remember that the left gastric artery's oesophagal branch ascends and passes through the oesophagal gap.
  • The left gastric artery may be affected by peptic ulcer disease of the lesser curvature of the stomach because it can induce substantial blood loss into the stomach and symptoms like hematemesis or melaena if an ulcer erodes through the stomach mucosa into a branch of the artery.
  • The mortality rate for bleeding peptic ulcers is approximately 6-7%.

Option A: Right gastroepiploic artery

  • One of the two terminal branches of the gastroduodenal artery is the right gastroepiploic artery, also known as the right gastro-omental artery.
  • It connects anastomosing with the left gastroepiploic artery, a splenic artery branch. It travels from right to left along the greater curvature of the stomach and between the layers of the larger omentum.
  • This vessel generates a variety of branches, including:
    • Ascending "gastric branches" supply the stomach's two surfaces.
    • Descending “omental branches” supply the greater omentum and anastomose with middle colic branches.

Option B: Gastroduodenal artery

  • The gastroduodenal artery delivers blood to the proximal portion of the duodenum and the pylorus, the distal portion of the stomach. Indirectly, it also supplies the pancreatic head via the anterior and posterior superior pancreaticoduodenal arteries.
  • It is the source of bleeding in the ulcer located at the duodenal bulb.

Option C: Pancreatico-duodenal artery

  • The duodenum and pancreas both get blood flow from the superior pancreatico-duodenal artery.
  • As it descends, the pancreaticoduodenal artery splits into anterior and posterior branches. These branches eventually join the anterior and posterior branches of the inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery after circumnavigating the head of the pancreas and duodenum.

questions.text: An 80-year-old, asymptomatic man presents with a total leucocyte count of 100,000/uL, with 80% lymphocytes and 20% polymorphonuclear cells. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia

  • The above-given clinical presentation points toward a diagnosis of CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia)
  • Its median age of presentation is 65 years, with 53% male presentation.
  • Most common presentation is Asymptomatic >> fatigue(anemia) > Left upper quadrant pain/mass(splenomegaly)
  • In the accelerated or blastic phase, the presentation would be unexplained fever, significant weight loss, severe fatigue, bone and joint aches, bleeding and thrombotic events, and infections.
  • The diagnosis of typical CLL is made with B-cell lymphocytosis greater than 5000/µL & co-expression of CD19 and CD5 on lymphocytes.
  • The peripheral blood smear shows "smudge" or "basket" cells.

  • Warm autoimmune hemolytic anaemia (IgG), Coombs test positive
  • Cytogenetic studies reveal trisomy 12
  • CML presents with massive splenomegaly, elevated WBC, increase in both immature and mature granulocytes.
  • At diagnosis, bone marrow cellularity is increased, with an increased myeloid-to-erythroid ratio.

Option A: Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS)

  • Normal CD4 count can vary from 500 to 1500 cells per cubic mL of blood. 
  • AIDS is diagnosed when CD4 levels drop below 200 cells per cubic mL of blood. 
  • In contrast, lymphocyte count is increased in chronic lymphocytic leukaemia.

Option B: Chronic myeloid leukaemia

  • Chronic myeloid leukaemia is a disorder of neoplastic proliferation of mature myeloid cells, especially granulocytes and their precursors; basophils are characteristically increased.
  • Lymphocyte count in chronic myeloid leukaemia does not exceed 100,000/cubic mm

Option D: Tuberculosis 

  • Tuberculosis presents symptoms such as dry fever, cough, weight loss and night sweats, whereas the presentation of the given patient is asymptomatic.
  • Moreover, lymphocyte count in tuberculosis does not exceed 100,000/cubic mm

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient presents to the neurology clinic with weakness in both lower extremities, progressively worsening tingling and numbness, and difficulty getting up from the chair. He has had a history of having laxity in both ankles since his 20s. He also has a tendency for his feet to turn inwards, trip, and subsequently sprain his ankles. Family history also reports having hammertoes in immediate family members involving his mother, sibling, and daughter. On examination, palpable nerves are seen. A typical onion bulb appearance is noted on a biopsy of the nerve. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Charcot Marie Tooth disease

  • It is an autosomal dominant disorder due to the defective proteins involved in myelin sheath structure and function.
  • It results in foot abnormalities and motor/sensory deficits.
  • Concomitant sensory deficit leads to Gait ataxia.
  • Nerve biopsy: Classical onion bulb appearance seen in Charcot Marie Tooth disease.
  • Charcot Marie Tooth disease ( Hereditary sensorimotor neuropathy) manifests as:
  • Peroneal muscle atrophy leading to stork leg appearance as shown in the image provided in the question.
  • Thickened nerves
  • Nerve biopsy: Onion bulb appearance
  • Distal weakness
  • A summary of signs and symptoms is given below in the image:

Option B: Lambert Eaton Syndrome

  • Autoantibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated Ca2+ channels characterize Lambert Eaton Syndrome.
  • Clinical manifestations are:
  • Proximal muscle weakness
  • Autonomic dysfunction (constipation, dry mouth)
  • Absent deep tendon reflexes
  • Dysphagia and dysarthria also are seen.
  • Ocular symptoms are ptosis and diplopia due to cranial nerve (CN)involvement.
  • Repeated electrical stimulation enhances muscle power due to incremental response.
  • It is associated with small-cell carcinoma of the lung.

Option C: Neurosyphilis

  • Tabes dorsalis or Neurosyphilis is caused by tertiary syphilis.
  • It results from the degeneration/demyelination of dorsal columns and roots.
  • There is decreased sense of proprioception which leads to sensory ataxia (the patient cannot stand with closed eyes and falls to the ground).
  • There is also decreased or absent deep tendon reflexes.

Option D: Duchenne's Muscular dystrophy

  • It is a genetic mutation with dystrophin gene deletion from chromosome X, so it mainly affects boys.
  • Dystrophin is a structural protein present in muscle fibres, and its absence results in muscular abnormalities:
  • Clumsy and waddling gait.
  • Progressive proximal muscular weakness.
  • Thigh muscles atrophy
  • Hypertrophy of calf muscle (pseudo-hypertrophy to compensate for the thigh muscle weakness).
  • Kyphoscoliosis
  • It starts affecting in 3 to 4 years, and the child can become a wheelchair user by 12 years.
  • It can also cause pulmonary problems due to kyphoscoliosis

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman with Parkinson's disease for the past 8 years presented to your clinic for regular follow-up. She has been on levodopa with a good response for the past 8 years. She reported having some periods of improved mobility alternating with impaired motor function. She was diagnosed with the characteristic 'on-off' phenomenon. Which of the following is the new drug approved for the treatment of ‘off phenomenon’ in such patients?
questions.solution:
Option A: Safinamide

  • Parkinson's disease is caused by the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra of the brain. The basal ganglia and substantia nigra are balanced systems comprising dopaminergic and cholinergic neurons. In Parkinson's disease, the dopaminergic neurons are compromised, and the cholinergic system is unopposed. Lewy bodies (composed of alpha-synuclein) are intracellular eosinophilic inclusions seen in dopaminergic neurons of basal ganglia.
  • The onset of Parkinson's disease is after 50 years of age.
  • Parkinsonism refers to the signs and symptoms of Parkinson's disease. It can be caused by many reasons, including a side effect of medications (e.g. antipsychotic drugs, methyl-phenyl tetrahydropyridine (MPTP)).
  • Features of Parkinsonism include:
    • A resting tremor consists of a shaking or oscillating movement and usually appears when a person is at rest.
    • Bradykinesia.
    • Rigidity appears as cogwheel rigidity in the upper limbs and lead-pipe rigidity in the lower limbs.
    • Poor postural reflexes, difficulty initiating the first step, stooped posture and walking with small shuffling steps.
    • Expressionless face.
    • Micrographia (small handwriting).
    • Dysarthria and dysphagia.
    • Autonomic disturbances
  • Management of Parkinson's disease with levodopa is the most effective treatment for Parkinson's disease and the gold standard against which new therapies are compared. Unlike dopamine, levodopa can cross the blood-brain barrier and is converted to dopamine by dopa-decarboxylase in the brain. Carbidopa is a peripheral dopa-decarboxylase inhibitor given with levodopa to increase its bioavailability and limit peripheral adverse effects. No current medical or surgical treatment provides benefits more than levodopa. Side effects of levodopa include nausea, hallucinations, postural hypotension and an "on and off" phenomenon in which the patient has improved mobility during "on" periods and impaired motor function during "off" periods.
  • Safinamide is an orally active drug. It is a selective, reversible monoamine oxidase-B inhibitor with dopaminergic and non-dopaminergic (glutamatergic) properties. It treats “on-off” periods associated with prolonged levodopa use.

Option B: Evenamide

  • Evanamide is an antipsychotic drug used to treat schizophrenia.

Option C: Lacosamide

  • Lacosamide is an anticonvulsant drug used to treat partial and generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

Option D: Ziconotide

  • Ziconotide is an analgesic used to treat chronic pain. It is not used to manage the "on-off" phenomenon of Parkinsonism.

questions.text: A 48-year-old Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) positive patient presented with diarrhoea for 7 weeks to the outpatient department. Upon asking, he describes his bowel moment as watery, non-bloody, with a frequency of 5-6 episodes per day. He also informs that he feels fatigued and his clothes have become loose. His routine stool examination results had been negative. Which pathogen is most likely involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cryptosporidium

  • The most prevalent opportunistic protozoa that infect the digestive tract and produce diarrhoea in HIV-infected individuals are cryptosporidia, microsporidia, and Isospora belli.
  • Cryptosporidiosis, a parasite illness of the mammalian digestive system, is caused by Cryptosporidium parvum.
  • Cryptosporidium causes an opportunistic water-borne illness.
  • Constipation, nausea, and vomiting are common symptoms of diarrhoea.
  • Diagnosis is made via stool examination or small intestinal biopsy.
  • Therapy is mostly supportive.
  • Treatment with up to 2000 mg/day of nitazoxanide (NTZ) is linked with improvement in symptoms or a reduction in organism shedding in around half of the patients.

Option A: Salmonella typhimurium

  • Salmonella is a gram-negative bacteria that cause diarrhoea.
  • Infection happens after ingesting germs from food, drink, fingers, and other items.
  • Salmonella is not the most prevalent cause of diarrhoea in HIV-positive people.

Option C: Candida

  • Candida-associated diarrhoea is mostly secretory, with frequent watery stools and no blood, mucus, tenesmus, or stomach discomfort.
  • The patients are elderly, emaciated, extremely ill, suffering from a chronic crippling condition or hospitalised patients.

Option D: Escherichia coli (E. coli)

  • Escherichia coli (E. coli) is a gram-negative rod generally found in the intestines.
  • A few strains produce diarrhoea or bloody diarrhoea, vomiting, stomach discomfort and cramps.
  • Contaminated food is the most frequent method of obtaining an E. coli infection. Without treatment, most people recover within a week.
  • Some individuals, particularly children, aged five and under, who become infected with STEC (the O157:H7 strain), develop hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS).

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of very severe COPD (FEV1~1.0L, <25% predicted) presents to the ER complaining of worsening dyspnea and an increase in the frequency and purulence of his sputum production over the past 2 days. His oxygen saturation is 78% on room air. Before he is placed on supplemental oxygen, a room air arterial blood gas is drawn and reveals pH=7.25, PCO2=68 mmHg, pO2=48 mmHg, HCO3-=31 mmHg. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Respiratory acidosis partially compensated

  • This patient’s ABGs show pH=7.25 (acidic), pCO2=68 mm Hg, HCO3-=31 mm Hg (elevated) and pO2= 48 mmHg.
  • The patient has a low pH, high pCO2, high HCO3- and low pO2.
  • The patient has respiratory acidosis, which leads to a low pO2.
  • HCO3- is elevated, but pH is still very acidic, so compensation has only partially occurred.
  • So, this patient has a partially compensated respiratory acidosis.

Option A: Respiratory acidosis uncompensated

  • The serum level of HCO3- is elevated in this patient.
  • So, partial compensation of respiratory acidosis has occurred in this patient.

Option C: Metabolic acidosis uncompensated

  • The patient has an elevated HCO3- level and a low pH. So he does not have metabolic acidosis.
  • His acid-base picture is not secondary to a metabolic abnormality.

Option D: Metabolic alkalosis partially compensated

  • The patient has an elevated HCO3- level and a low pH.
  • So, he does not have metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department due to persistent shortness of breath and cough for the last 8 days. His respiratory status worsened while in the emergency department. He became severely short of breath and was unable to complete sentences. He smokes 2 packs of cigarettes a day. His blood pressure is 125/71 mm Hg, his heart rate is 122/min, his temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), his respiratory rate is 33/min, and his oxygen saturation is 77% on room air. His pCO2 is noted to be 55mmHg. He is transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for respiratory failure. Which is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease exacerbation

  • The patient's presentation of persistent shortness of breath, cough, severe shortness of breath, and inability to complete sentences, along with a history of chain smoking, low oxygen saturation (77% on room air), and elevated pCO2 (55 mmHg) is highly suggestive of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation as the most likely cause.

    Here's how the clinical findings align with COPD exacerbation:

  • Persistent shortness of breath and cough: These are common symptoms in patients with COPD, especially during exacerbations.

  • Severe shortness of breath and inability to complete sentences: Severe breathlessness and inability to speak in full sentences are indicative of significant respiratory distress, which can occur during a COPD exacerbation due to worsening airflow obstruction.

  • Chain smoking history: Smoking is the primary risk factor for the development of COPD. It leads to chronic inflammation and damage to the airways and lungs, contributing to the development and exacerbation of COPD.

  • Low oxygen saturation (77% on room air): Hypoxemia (low oxygen saturation) is a hallmark of COPD exacerbation, as the impaired lung function leads to inadequate oxygen exchange in the lungs.

  • Elevated pCO2 (55 mmHg): An elevated partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) is also characteristic of COPD exacerbation. The increased pCO2 reflects inadequate ventilation due to the obstructed airways in COPD.

  • In COPD exacerbations, the airways become more inflamed and narrowed, making it difficult for air to flow in and out of the lungs. This results in worsening symptoms and respiratory distress.

Other options

Option B: Acute asthma attack

  • Acute asthma attacks include respiratory difficulty, tight and painful chest, wheezing, and dry cough.
  • It can lead to type I respiratory failure more frequently than type II.
  • The patient had a history of long-term smoking, making acute exacerbation of COPD more likely to cause this patient's presentation.

Option C: Panic attack

  • A panic attack is characterized by shortness of breath associated with a sense of impending doom or danger, fear of losing control or death, sweating, trembling, chills, hot flashes, and rapid, pounding heart rate.
  • The patient did not have any of the above features except shortness of breath.
  • A panic attack is less likely to cause type II respiratory failure.

Option D: Pneumonia

  • Pneumonia is a lung infection that causes inflammation of the alveolar space or the interstitial tissue of the lungs.
  • It can lead to productive cough, fever, chills, and breathing difficulties.
  • Pneumonia can be brought on by several different organisms, including bacteria, viruses, and fungi.
  • Pneumonia causes type I respiratory failure.
  • The patient's history of smoking makes acute exacerbation of COPD a likely cause of this patient's presentation.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents with complaints of intermittent headaches and palpitations for three months. She also complains of having intermittent abdominal pain. On examination, her blood pressure is 155/95mmHg, and she is noted to have profuse sweating. On workup, with an MRI abdomen, she is found to have an adrenal tumour on the right side. Further workup with nuclear imaging reveals metastasis to the liver. Which of the following is the best treatment for managing this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: I131-MIBG

  • The patient’s clinical history & findings confirm the diagnosis of malignant Pheochromocytoma.

  • The first line management of malignant Pheochromocytoma is I131- MIBG at monthly intervals over three to six cycles.

  • This is followed by the Averbuch Chemotherapy protocol, including dacarbazine, cyclophosphamide and vincristine.

Option A: Alpha blockers

  • Alpha-blockers followed by beta blockers are given before surgical management of benign Pheochromocytoma.

Option B: Chemotherapy

  • Chemotherapy is not a stand-alone treatment for Pheochromocytoma. Instead, it is to be done after I131- MIBG as an adjuvant treatment.

Option C: Bulk-reducing surgery

  • Surgical resection of the tumour is the treatment of choice in case of a localised pheochromocytoma with no metastasis.

questions.text: A 66-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of shortness of breath, swollen legs, and fatigue. The physician notices that his cardiac output is low and having a murmur of mitral regurgitation. Chest X-ray and histopathology of endomyocardial biopsy are shown in the images below. Which type of pulse would be present in this case?
questions.solution:
Option A: Dicrotic pulse

  • Multinucleated myocytes on biopsy and an increased CT ratio on chest X-ray indicate Dilated cardiomyopathy.
  • A dicrotic pulse is a twice-beating pulse palpable both in systole as well as diastole.
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy causes the chambers of the heart (ventricles) to become thin and stretch, resulting in an enlargement of the chambers. 
  • In most cases, it begins in the principal pumping chamber of the heart (left ventricle). It is more difficult for the heart, when dilated cardiomyopathy is present, to pump blood to the rest of the body.
  • Fatigue, chest pain, swelling in the lower extremities, and shortness of breath are some of the symptoms associated with dilated cardiomyopathy. 
  • It can be brought on by a condition known as hemochromatosis, in which the body has an abnormally high concentration of iron in the heart and other organs; problems with the heart's rhythm, known as arrhythmias; high blood pressure, known as hypertension; obesity; and heart valve diseases, such as a mitral valve or aortic valve regurgitation.

Option B: Anacrotic pulse

  • Anacrotic pulse is seen in Valvular Aortic stenosis
  • Examination Findings of Aortic stenosis include:
    • Pulsus parvus et tardus
    • Anacrotic pulse ( due to increase in ejection velocity)
    • Double apical impulse
    • Narrow/Paradoxical split S2
    • Ejection-systolic murmur

Option C: Pulsus bisferiens

  • Pulsus bisferiens is a Fast rising pulse with a fast fall.
  • Seen in Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy

Option D: Pulsus paradoxsus

  • Difference of >10 mm Hg in Systolic Blood Pressure during Inspiration called Pulsus Paradoxsus
  • Seen in patients with cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax, severe obstructive lung disease etc.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female known case of anemia, fibrosing alveolitis, and peripheral neuropathy has reported to medical OPD. She is on methotrexate for a joint disease of her hands; she didn't bring her old file and investigations. She cannot move her finger for at least one hour after waking up. She is complaining of continuous joint pain, swelling of bilateral hand joints, shortness of breath, lethargy, and decreased exercise tolerance. The following is the picture of the patient hand. What is the best next treatment step for the patient for this patient?

choices.text: Stop methotrexate and start Monotherapy with anti-TNF- drugs

questions.solution:
Option C: Methotrexate + Sulphasalazine + Hydroxychloroquine

  • The image is of a rheumatoid arthritis hand, ulnar deviation, and swan neck deformity coupled with the clinical history; the diagnosis of Rheumatoid arthritis is made with persistent disease activity.
  • She is already on methotrexate and should now be put on triple therapy of methotrexate with sulphasalazine and hydroxychloroquine.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a type of Inflammatory arthritis
  • Chronic disease with remission and exacerbations.
  • Both genetic (HLA-DR and other immune response genes) and environmental factors (smoking, infection) are responsible. 
  • A criterion for diagnosis is based on the number of joint involvement, serology, duration of symptoms, and acute phase reactants.
  • Signs and symptoms are joint pain, swelling, stiffness, extreme morning stiffness, multiple affected joints, oedema (pitting)
  • Systemic manifestations include loss of appetite, weight loss, lethargy, muscle wasting, osteoporosis, bursitis, serositis, anemia, scleritis and episcleritis, pericarditis, myocarditis, endocarditis, vasculitis, nodules and sinuses, pleural effusion, fibrosing alveolitis, cord compression.
  • The structural complication of long-standing cases is ulnar deviation, boutonnieres deformity, Z  deformity of thumb, cock up toe deformity, and flat foot
  • Investigations are ESR, CRP, ACPA(highly specific), RF, x-ray
  • Management in the newly diagnosed case is to start with methotrexate and prednisolone. Increase the dose of methotrexate and decrease the dose of prednisolone over the next 12 weeks.
  • After 12 weeks, check the disease activity score of 28
  • If less than 2.6, continue methotrexate; if more than 2.6, add sulphasalazine and hydroxychloroquine.

Option A: Double the dose of methotrexate

  • Double the dose of methotrexate will only increase the side effects of methotrexate.
  • Common side effects are tachycardia, itching, rash, blood in stool, swelling of eyelids, stomach pain, etc.

Option B: Methotrexate + high potency Oral steroids

  • Methotrexate and high potency oral steroids combination will lead to an increased incidence of osteoporosis.

Option D: Stop methotrexate and start Monotherapy with anti-TNF- drugs

  • Anti-TNF drugs are used not alone but in conjunction with methotrexate for rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text:
A coal mine worker develops progressively worsening breathlessness and cough with expectoration. Spirometry values are: 

Forced expiratory volume (FEV1) = 1.4 L/min

Functional vital capacity (FVC) = 2.8L/min

What could be the cause?
questions.solution:
Option C: COPD

  • The FEV1/FVC ratio of the patient is low, which indicates obstructive airway disease.
  • Coal workers' pneumoconiosis with effects of coal dust on alveolar macrophages leading to the development of chronic Bronchitis and COPD

Option A: Silicosis

  • Silicosis is a type of restrictive lung disease. 
  • In restrictive lung diseases FEV1/FVC ratio increases. 

Option B: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis

  • Spirometry often reveals a restrictive pattern and a significantly reduced force due to small airway involvement.

Option D: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a rare, progressive illness of the respiratory system, characterized by the thickening and stiffening of lung tissue associated with scar tissue formation.
  • It is characterized by a progressive and irreversible decline in lung function and demonstrates a restrictive lung disease pattern in which FEV1/FVC ratio increases.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the hospital with a complaint of mucosal bleeding on trauma. She has a history of menorrhagia. On investigations, BT and PTT are prolonged. The Ristocetin assay is positive. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: von Willebrand disease

  • This patient with mucosal bleeding, menorrhagia, prolonged BT and PTT and positive ristocetin assay likely has von Willebrand disease.
  • It is the most common inherited bleeding disorder due to deficient von Willebrand factor.
  • Ristocetin fails to cause platelet agglutination, which is diagnostic of this disorder.
  • There is an increased bleeding tendency in this disorder.

Option A: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

  • In this disorder, there is immune-mediated destruction of platelets.
  • BT is elevated, but PTT is normal.
  • The ristocetin assay is negative in this disorder.

Option B: Hemophilia A

  • It is an X-linked recessive disorder resulting in factor VIII deficiency.
  • BT is normal, but PTT is elevated.
  • The ristocetin assay is negative.

Option C: Hemophilia B

  • It is an X-linked recessive disorder resulting in the deficiency of factor IX.
  • BT is normal, but PTT is elevated.
  • The ristocetin assay is negative.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with features of malabsorption and iron deficiency anaemia for three weeks. She has no history of chronic medical conditions and is currently not on any medications. Blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg, and pulse is 64 beats/min. After the examination of the patient, the physician recommends an endoscopy. Duodenal biopsy shows complete villous atrophy. Which antibody is likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Anti-endomysial antibodies

  • This patient, with features of malabsorption, iron-deficiency anaemia and villous atrophy, likely has celiac disease.
  • The best screening test for diagnosis of celiac sprue is the presence of anti-Tissue transglutaminase antibody and Anti-endomysial antibody.
  • Malabsorption and anaemia are seen due to disease affecting the distal part of the small intestine.
  • Biopsy from the Distal duodenum or proximal jejunum shows the loss or blunting of the intestinal mucosa.

Option B: Anti–goblet cell antibodies

  • Anti-goblet cell antibodies are not present in celiac disease.
  • They are found in autoimmune enteropathy.

Option C: Anti – Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies

  • Anti – Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies are associated with Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). They are usually not seen in celiac disease.

Option D: Anti-neutrophilic antibodies

  • Anti-neutrophilic antibodies can be seen in patients with autoimmune vasculitis and IBD. They are not seen in celiac disease.

questions.text: A 29-year-old married male presents to the clinic with the complaint of recurrent chronic cough with expectoration for the past 10-12 years. On auscultation, bilateral wheeze and right basal crackles are audible, with heart sounds best heard on the right side of the chest. CT chest revealed dextrocardia, and nodular opacities in bilateral lung fields suggest bronchiectasis. He also gives a history of not having children despite being married for the last 4 years. Which of the following could be the probable cause of infertility in patients with the above syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option C: Asthenospermia

  • This patient’s clinical history & features are highly suggestive of Kartagener's syndrome.
  • It is a rare ciliopathic, autosomal recessive genetic disorder that affects the cilia in the lungs and other organs.
  • It is a subset of primary ciliary dyskinesia. 50% of patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia have Kartagener syndrome.
  • Around 90% of individuals with kartageners have ultrastructural defects affecting protein(s) in the outer or inner dynein arms.
  • Kartagener syndrome is described as the triad of
    • Situs Inversus.
    • Bronchiectasis.
    • Either nasal polyps or recurrent sinusitis.
  • Other features include telecanthus, infertility in males, and subfertility in females.
  • Asthenospermia or poor sperm motility is due to missing dynein arms, which is the basic defect of Kartagener’s syndrome.
  • Symptoms of Kartagener’s syndrome include:
    • Respiratory distress in neonates
    • Recurrent respiratory tract infections
    • Bronchiectasis, situs inversus
    • Infertility and heterotaxy in approximately 50%
  • It is sometimes diagnosed at birth or most often discovered in early childhood.
  • There is no cure for Kartagener’s syndrome.

Option A: Oligospermia

  • Oligospermia refers to low sperm count.
  • It can be due to infection, genetics, hormones, environmental toxins, etc.
  • Kartagener syndrome most commonly affects sperm motility.

Option B: Blockage of the epididymis

  • Blockage of the epididymis can be due to infection, inflammation, scrotal trauma, and genetics.
  • It is seen in young syndrome, a rare inherited syndrome similar to Kartagener syndrome.

Option D: Undescended testis

  • It is also known as cryptorchidism.
  • It is not associated with Kartagener syndrome.

questions.text: A 56-years-old patient presented to emergency with complaints of breathlessness, chest pain and drowsiness. He is a known case of lung carcinoma. Examination shows engorged and distended neck veins, low blood pressure, and soft S1 and S2. Which of the following is inappropriate regarding the condition of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Prominent Y descent

  • Lung cancer can exhibit metastasis to the heart, which causes pericardial effusion leading to cardiac tamponade.
  • The three principal features of tamponade (Beck’s triad) are
    • Hypotension,
    • Soft or absent heart sounds
    • Jugular venous distention with a prominent x (early systolic) descent but an absent y (early diastolic) descent.

Option A: Electrical alternans

  • Electrical alternans (amplitude of QRS changes) are seen in Cardiac tamponade, so option A is correct.

Option B: Low voltage ECG

  • In individuals with heart failure brought on by systolic dysfunction, low voltage on the ECG is both a measure of disease severity and a risk factor for unfavourable outcomes.

Option D: Absence of Kussmaul sign

  • Kussmaul's sign, or increased jugular venous pressure on inspiration, is a popular term for this condition.
  • Patients with cardiac tamponade do not exhibit Kussmaul's sign because the right side of the heart still receives increased negative intrathoracic pressure, which leads to increased blood flow to the right atrium even though the increase in pericardial pressure compresses the entire heart inwardly during inspiration.

questions.text: A woman comes to a psychiatrist with a history of spending a lot of time in washing her hands. She is distressed about it but says that she is not able to stop washing. This has started to affect her social life as well. What is the best mode of treatment for her?
questions.solution:
• OCD is characterized by the presence of obsessions and/or compulsions. Obsessions are recurrent and persistent thoughts. urges or images that are experienced as intrusive or unwanted. Compulsions are repetitive behaviour or mental acts that the patient feels driven to perform in response to an obsession.
  • Treatment
    • According to American Psychiatric Association guidelines, the first line of treatment for OCD are Cognitive behavioural therapy that relies on the behavioural technique of 'Exposure and response preventionand Selective Serotonin re-uptake inhibitors (SSRIs).
    • Also few studies have found, that Exposure and response prevention has more lasting effect than pharmacological agents.
    • Having said that, the choice of treatment between ERP and pharmacological agents depends on patients' characteristics, which have not been provided, hence it's tough to choose.
    • However in this case, Exposure and response prevention appears to be the best answer.

questions.text: There are places famous for Cannabis use: Kerala, Meghalaya, Manipur, Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Mysuru, even Bihar. In Odisha, it is relatively more acceptable and easier to procure. In 1985, under pressure from the US (which had launched the war on drugs with much fanfare), Rajiv Gandhi clamped the draconian NDPS — the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act. This put traditional bhang and ganja on the same level as smack, brown sugar..etc. How long can a urine drug screen test stay positive for delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol in a heavy cannabis user?
questions.solution:
• A positive urine test for delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) is limited for diagnosis because it signifies past use but cannot be used to diagnose acute intoxication.
  • Cannabinoids are highly lipophilic and can remain in body fluids for weeks after cessation of heavy use.
  • Occasional use, though, rarely leads to positive urine screens for more than a few days after last use.

questions.text: When a 42-year-old guy with a sexual interest in children (pedophilia) is shown a videotape of youngsters, he receives an electric shock. Later, he becomes nervous in the presence of children and avoids them. This example exemplifies which of the following management techniques?
questions.solution:
• Aversive conditioning is a management approach in which a maladaptive but pleasurable stimulus (for this man, sexual interest in minors) is matched with a painful stimulus (e.g., a shock) to create an association between the two.
  • Flooding is a type of behavioural therapy in which the highest level of stimulation is provided in the initial encounter.
  • Biofeedback-·Uses the operant conditioning principle·Useful for autonomic dysfunction-related illnesses such tension headaches.·For example, EMG can be used to modulate muscular tone in conditions like bruxism

NOTE: Flooding is also called as Implosion. The most significant aspect of flooding treatment may be the desensitisation of psychological and physiological complex structures. The implosive sessions are thought to represent supramaximal stimulation of pathologically excited and inert complex structures, resulting in protective inhibition, irradiation of excitation, reduction of excitation and inertness, and a decrease of the complex structures' overshooting autonomic reactivity, resulting in decreased anxiety, aggression, and other pathologically increased feelings.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented to the psychiatric emergency department due to aggressive behavior, lack of sleep, singing and dancing on the streets, and claiming that he is a bigger star than all the Khans of Bollywood. The symptoms have been continuing for 3 weeks. At the time of examination, the patient appeared agitated and aggressive. Which of the following is the preferred treatment for immediate control of symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option C: Olanzapine

Mania Symptoms

  • Disconnected and fast thoughts
  • Grandiose beliefs
  • Inapproprate elation
  • Inapproprate irritability
  • Increased talking speed or volume
  • Poor judgement
  • Decreased need for sleep due to high energy

​​​​​​​                                                            
  • This patient presented with acute manic symptoms.
  • Mania presents with distractibility, indiscretion, grandiosity, flight of ideas, increased activity, sleep deficit, and talkativeness (DIGFAST).
  • Treatment for acute mania includes lithium, valproate, carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine, clonazepam and lorazepam, and typical and atypical antipsychotics.
  • Antipsychotics used in acute mania include olanzapine, risperidone, quetiapine, ziprasidone and apriprazole. These are FDA-approved.
  • The onset of lithium is relatively slow; therefore, it is supplemented by antipsychotics in the early phase of mania.
  • Valproate is effective in acute mania. It is slightly less effective than antipsychotics.
  • Carbamazepine is another anti-epileptic drug that can be used in mania but is 2nd line drug to treat mania.

Option A: Lithium

  • Lithium is a drug of choice for acute mania.
  • However, it has a slow onset. Thus, requiring an additional drug for immediate effect.
  • Antipsychotics improve symptoms till lithium becomes effective.

Option B: Valproate

  • Valproate is used for acute mania.
  • However, it is less effective than antipsychotics in acute mania.

Option D: Promethazine

  • Promethazine is a first-generation antihistamine.
  • It is not used to treat acute mania.

questions.text: A 67-year-old female presents in the surgical outpatient department due to the progressively increasing size of her left breast for the last 2 months. She also complains of itching, heaviness, and an increased temperature in her left breast. Physical examination reveals widespread erythema, intense edema, and areolar erosion of the breast, with several enlarged axillary lymph nodes on the left side. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by modified radical mastectomy and radiotherapy

questions.solution:
Option A: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by modified radical mastectomy and radiotherapy

  • This elderly female with skin thickening, erythema, the warmth of her breast, and palpable axillary lymph nodes most likely has locally invasive inflammatory breast cancer.
  • Inflammatory breast carcinoma accounts for <3% of breast cancers.
  • Inflammatory breast cancer is a subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma which does not commonly present with a palpable lump.
  • It usually presents with an inflamed, swollen breast with thickening of the overlying skin (peau d’orange appearance) due to blockage of dermal lymphatics.
  • Inflammatory breast cancer can sometimes be misdiagnosed as mastitis due to its presentation.
  • At least 33% of skin over the breast is involved with a history of rapid onset and progression.
  • More than 75% of women have palpable axillary lymphadenopathy and distant metastasis.
  • This patient most likely has stage IIIB breast cancer (tumor spread to the chest wall and axillary lymph nodes with no involvement of other organs).
  • The treatment of inflammatory breast cancer includes neoadjuvant chemotherapy (given before the surgery) to reduce tumor size.
  • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is followed by modified radical mastectomy (removal of the entire breast including skin, nipple, areola, and axillary lymph nodes with sparing of the pectoralis major and minor muscles).
  • Modified radical mastectomy is followed by radiotherapy to remove any residual tumor cells.

Option B: Radical mastectomy followed by chemotherapy

  • Radical mastectomy involves the removal of the entire breast, nipple, areola, overlying skin, axillary lymph nodes, and pectoralis major and minor muscles.
  • Patients with inflammatory breast cancer are treated with modified radical mastectomy as it has better outcomes than radical mastectomy.

Option C: Radical mastectomy followed by radiotherapy

  • The treatment of inflammatory breast cancer is initiated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
  • In addition, modified radical mastectomy is preferred over radical mastectomy for treating inflammatory breast cancer.

Option D: Chemotherapy followed by hormone therapy

  • Chemotherapy and hormonal therapy are the mainstays of treatment for metastatic breast cancer (that has spread to other body organs).
  • This patient has locally invasive inflammatory breast cancer that can be treated with chemotherapy, surgery, and radiotherapy.
  • Surgical treatment is the definitive treatment for stage III breast cancer to remove residual cancer from the chest wall and axilla.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to laparoscopic cholecystectomy?
questions.solution:
Option A: Gallbladder carcinoma

  • Gallbladder carcinoma is an absolute contraindication to laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
  • Laparotomy is the procedure of choice for gallbladder carcinoma.

Option B: Cholangitis

  • Cholangitis is a relative contraindication to laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Option C: Morbid obesity

  • Morbid obesity is a relative contraindication of laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Option D: Diffuse peritonitis

  • Diffuse peritonitis is a relative contraindication to laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

questions.text: A 55-year old male presents to the emergency department with acute right flank pain for the past 3 hours. He was prescribed painkillers and discharged. The next day, he presented again with severe pain and was referred to the urology department. A ureteric calculus associated with hydronephrosis is identified on the ultrasound abdomen. He is managed with a procedure shown in the following image. Which of the following is correct about the given procedure?

choices.text: Gold standard lithotripter is Dornier unmodified HM-3
Steinstrasse is seen in cases of proximal ureteric obstruction
The maximum size of the stone removed is 1.5 cm

questions.solution:
Option A: Gold standard lithotripter is Dornier unmodified HM-3

  • Clinical signs: Right flank pain, ureteric calculus, and hydronephrosis are indications of a renal stone.
  • ESWL- Extracorporeal Shock wave Lithotripsy:
    • Gold standard Lithotripter- Dornier Unmodified HM-3
    • Shock waves recognize the stone with the help of density changes in the body→ erosion and shattering of stones → fragmentation of stones → excreted via the ureter.
    • If there is an obstruction in the ureter, stone fragments are collected in the proximal part of the ureter leading to a complication known as Steinstrasse (also known as Street of stones/ Columnation of Gravel).
    • The maximum size of stone removed by ESWL is 2cm.
  • Absolute contraindications of ESWL:
    • Pregnancy
    • Bleeding disorders
  • Relative contraindications of ESWL:
    • Pacemaker
    • UTI
    • Distal obstruction
    • Obesity
    • Orthopaedic abnormalities like Scoliosis and Kyphoscoliosis
    • Uncontrolled HTN
    • Aneurysm
    • Renal failure
  • Whenever ESWL cannot be used→, PCNL is preferred

Option B: Steinstrasse is seen in cases of proximal ureteric obstruction

  • Steinstrasse is seen in cases of distal ureteric obstruction.
  • Distal obstruction is responsible for this.

Option C: Pregnancy is an Indication

  • In pregnancy, it is contraindicated.

Option D: Maximum size of stone removed is 1.5 cm

  • The maximum size of stone removed by ESWL is 2 cm.
  • It is not 1.5cm; stones up to 2 cm could be removed.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to a primary care physician complaining of chest discomfort for the last ten days. His primary care physician provides symptomatic treatment, which gives an initial improvement in symptoms. Afterwards, his chest discomfort started again, and he developed progressive dyspnea with exertion. A CT chest reveals a round, well-demarcated mass in the middle mediastinal compartment. Which of the following is rare enough to be included in the middle mediastinal masses found in the patient discussed above?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ganglioneuroma

  • Clinical signs: young age, progressive dyspnea on exertion and radiological evaluation round, well-demarcated mass in middle mediastinum all suggest the differentials of the bronchogenic cyst, ascending aortic aneurysm, pericardial cyst, ganglioneuroma.
  • Ganglioneuromas are usually rare and asymptomatic; some possible symptoms are usually caused by the compression of surrounding structures or hormone secretions (e.g., norepinephrine) and associated effects of them (e.g., diarrhea, hypertension).
  • In autonomic nerve cells, ganglioneuromas most often start to develop and are considered rare tumours. These are usually noncancerous (benign) tumours.
  • The intestines are the most common location of ganglioneuromas. They have a slow growth rate and secrete certain hormones.
  • No known risk factors are there. However, they are associated with genetic disorders such as neurofibromatosis type 1.

Option A: Bronchogenic cysts

  • Bronchogenic cysts form in the mediastinum and are abnormal growths of tissue.
  • They are small in size benign tumours and typically central in location.
  • The most common symptoms include fever, cough, pain, dyspnea, pulmonary infections, and tracheobronchial compression.

Option B: Ascending aortic aneurysm

  • An ascending aortic aneurysm is a focal dilatation on the upper portion of the aorta to more than 1.5 times its normal diameter. They may cause the blood vessel wall to tear or break open as the aneurysms bulge outward.
  • The condition is commonly asymptomatic, but some patients may experience back pain, chest pain, difficulty swallowing, coughing or wheezing, hoarseness, and shortness of breath.
  • A chest X-ray, chest CT scan, and MR angiography are required to diagnose the condition.

Option C: Pericardial cyst

  • The pericardial cyst causes a rare and benign mediastinal mass.
  • They are most commonly asymptomatic, and incidental findings usually help diagnose the condition on imaging.
  • Less common symptoms may include persistent cough, dysphagia, dyspnea, and atypical chest pain.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male patient was brought to the hospital with an altered state of consciousness. He has a history of chronic liver disease. On examination, there are mild ascites and tremors. Laboratory values show:


	Total Bilirubin - 2.5 mg/dL
	Albumin - 3 g/dL
	INR=2.0


Which class of Child Turcotte Pugh score does the patient belong to?
questions.solution:
Option C: Class C

  • The total score for the given patient amounts to 2+2+2+2+3=11 points, and hence he belongs to CTP Class C
  • Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) Scoring System and this patient have Grade 3 encephalopathy.
  • Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) Score:
Variable 1 Point 2 Point 3 Point
Serum albumin (g/dL)    >3.5      2.8-3.5 <2.8
Bilirubin (mg/dL)        <2          2-3       >3
Ascites None         Mild to Moderate   Severe
Encephalopathy  None  Grade I or II    Grade III or IV
Prothrombin time      
Seconds prolonged <4           4-6 >6
INR    <1.7   1.7-2.3  >2.3
  • Class A 5-6 points
  • Class B 7-9 points
  • Class C 10-15 points

Option A: Class A

  • Class A has points 5-6. This patient's point is 11, so the class should be C.

Option B: Class B

  • Class B has points 7-9. This patient's point is 11, so the class should be C.

Option D: Class D

  • There are a total of three classes (Class A, B, and C) in the child Pugh scoring system.

questions.text: While attending an outpatient rotation of gastroenterology, a patient brought his investigation records, and the professors handed over a film to the resident. Identify the technique given in the image below.
questions.solution:
Option A: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)

  • The technique given above is endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)

  • ERCP is used both as a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure.
  • ERCP helps to identify the cause and obstruction level.
  • Using a side viewing scope, the ampulla of Vater is identified and cannulated. 
  • Injection of water-soluble contrast directly into the bile duct provides excellent images of the ductal anatomy.
  • It helps in determining the cause and level of obstruction.

Option B: Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)

  • MRCP is a non-invasive imaging technique to visualize the intra and extrahepatic biliary tree and pancreatic ductal system.
  • It can provide diagnostically-equivalent images to ERCP and is a useful technique in high-risk patients to avoid significant morbidity.

Option C: CT colonoscopy

  • Computed tomographic (CT) colonography, also called virtual colonoscopy (VC) or CT pneumocolon, is a powerful, minimally invasive technique for colorectal screening.

Option D: Sigmoidoscopy

  • A sigmoidoscopy is a diagnostic test used to check the sigmoid colon, which is the lower part of the large intestine.
  • This section of the colon is close to the rectum and anus

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with chronic NSAID abuse presents with massive hematemesis, hypotension, and tachycardia. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness. IV proton pump inhibitors are administered, and endoscopy reveals a bleeding peptic ulcer in the proximal duodenum. Which of the following vessels needs to be ligated in this patient to stop the bleeding?
questions.solution:
Option A: Gastroduodenal artery

  • Peptic ulcers are open sores in the stomach (gastric ulcer) and the upper part of the duodenum (duodenal ulcer).
  • It usually presents with hematemesis and melena.
  • A peptic ulcer is the most common cause of upper GI bleeding, present in one-half to two-thirds of patients with upper GI bleeding.
  • It has the following two types:

 

 

Gastric ulcer

Duodenal ulcers

Abdominal pain

Pain increases with the meal.

Pain decreases with the meal.

H. Pylori infection

Chronic infection

Acute infection

Mechanism

Decreased mucosal protection against gastric ulcer

Decreased mucosal protection or increased gastric secretion

Causes

NSAIDS

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome

Risk of carcinoma

Increase risk

Benign

 

  • Ulcers (duodenal ulcers) is the most common cause of upper GI bleeding
  • Duodenal ulcer bleeds from the gastroduodenal artery.
  • Gastric ulcers mostly bleed from the left gastric artery.

 

 

Option B: Superior pancreaticoduodenal artery

  • It arises from the gastroduodenal artery.
  • It divides into anterior and posterior branches.
  • Both branches combine with the inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery branches to form the superior mesenteric artery.
  • It mostly supplies the pancreas and duodenum.

Option C: Left gastric artery

  • The left gastric artery is a branch of the celiac artery.
  • The lesser curve is supplied by the right and left gastric vessels, and the greater curve is by the right and left gastroepiploic vessels.
  • Gastric ulcers mostly bleed from the left gastric artery.

Option D: Left gastroepiploic artery

  • The left gastroepiploic artery arises from the splenic artery and runs within the gastrosplenic ligament.
  • The greater curve is supplied by the right and left gastroepiploic vessels.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is less likely to be descriptive of retroperitoneal fibrosis?

choices.text: Most patients present with dull, non-colicky, lower back, flank, or abdominal pain.
Evidence of impaired renal function with an elevated blood urea nitrogen is common.
CT or MRI scan can be used to diagnose the disease.
The prognosis for nonmalignant retroperitoneal fibrosis is grim, with the progression of the disease until death occurring in most patients.

questions.solution:
Option D: The prognosis for nonmalignant retroperitoneal fibrosis is grim, with the progression of the disease until death occurring in most patients

  • Retroperitoneal is a benign condition characterized by developing grey/white plaques in the low lumbar region. However, it spreads laterally and encases the common iliac vessels, ureters, and aorta.
    • It is not associated with malignant progression or a grim prognosis.
    • It is usually a static or very slowly progressive disease and has a good prognosis if removed through surgery.

Option A: Most patients present with dull, non-colicky, lower back, flank, or abdominal pain

  • Characteristic clinical features of retroperitoneal fibrosis include dull, aching lower back, flank, or abdominal pain, relieved by NSAIDs and not by opiates. 

Option B: Evidence of impaired renal function with an elevated blood urea nitrogen is common

  • Encasement and obstruction of ureters may lead to obstructive uropathy and deranged renal function tests, resulting in elevated blood urea nitrogen.

Option C: CT or MRI scan can be used to diagnose the disease

  • Imaging studies, including a simple CT scan or an MRI, can help differentiate it from other conditions and reach a diagnosis. ​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 5-month-old child is brought to the pediatrician's office for evaluation of a "lump" in his genital area. His birth history is unremarkable, and he has been feeding well. His parents report no other concerns except this lump. On physical exam, there is a tense and non-tender mass in the scrotum. The transillumination test is positive. What is the appropriate diagnosis for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Hydrocele

  • In the above mention case, the signs and symptoms such as a "lump" in his genital area,  tense and non-tender mass in the scrotum, and a trans illumination test positive are suggestive of hydroceles.
  • A hydrocele is an abnormal collection of serous fluid in a part of the processus vaginalis, usually the tunica vaginalis.
  • Acquired hydroceles are primary or idiopathic or secondary to epididymal or testicular disease.
  • A primary hydrocele is seen most commonly in the middle and later life but may also occur in older children.
  • In congenital hydrocele, the processus vaginalis is patent and connects with the peritoneal cavity.
  • Funicular Hydrocele: Processus Vaginalis patent up to top of epididymis.
  • Infantile Hydrocele: Tunica Vaginalis and processes Vaginalis patent up to Deep Ring.
  • Encysted hydrocele: The centre part of the cord is unobliterated and has fluid.
  • Bilocular Hydrocele: 2 loculi – one above the neck of the scrotum and one below.
  • Hydrocele of hernia sac: Neck of sac pulls omentum.
  • Congenital hydroceles are treated by herniotomy if they do not resolve spontaneously.

Option A: Inguinal hernia

  • An inguinal hernia results when abdominal organs protrude into the inguinal canal or scrotum.
  • About 1-5% of children will have a hernia or hydrocele, including newborns.

Option C: Varicocele

  • A varicocele is a vein enlargement within the loose bag of skin that holds the testicles.
  • The cause is the absence or incompetence of valves in the proximal testicular vein.
