  • Grading of the Varicocele is possible, with a Grade I Varicocele being impalpable (i.e. observed only on ultrasound), Grade II being palpable, and Grade III being visible.

Option D: Epididymal cyst

  • These are filled with crystal-clear fluid. They are very common, usually multiple and vary in size at presentation. They represent cystic degeneration of the epididymis.
  • The clusters of tense cysts feel like tiny bunches of grapes that lie posterior to, and quite separate from, the testis.
  • They should Trans illuminate brilliantly. The diagnosis can be confirmed by ultrasound.

questions.text: A 30-year-old otherwise healthy male presented to the emergency department with complaints of pain and bluish discolouration of the left arm, hand, and fingers for three weeks. On examination, pulses were weak in the left upper limb. A chest X-ray showed a left cervical rib attached to the first rib. Dynamic angiography revealed a left subclavian artery occlusion. Which of the following options would be the best for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Supraclavicular decompression

  • The sign, symptoms, and X-ray findings are consistent with the diagnosis of thoracic outlet syndrome.
  • Supraclavicular decompression is the best surgical option for managing thoracic outlet syndrome.
  • It refers to a group of conditions where blood vessels and nerves get compressed between the clavicle and the first rib.
  • Causes: trauma, repetitive injuries, anatomical defects, or pregnancy.
  • Anatomical defects include an extra rib above the first thoracic rib, also known as the cervical rib, or the abnormal tight fibrous band connecting the rib to the spine.
  • Clinical presentation refers to the nerve, vein or arterial compression.
    • Neurogenic by compression of brachial plexus causes:
      • Numbness and tingling in the arms.
      • Pain in arms, shoulder and neck
      • Weak grip
    • Venous by compression of the subclavian vein causing:
      • Bluish or pale discolouration of the arm
      • Pain and swelling in the arm
      • Venous thrombosis
    • Arterial by compression of subclavian artery causes:
      • Cold and painful arms, fingers, and hands.
      • Pale or bluish discolouration of the arm
      • Weak or no pulse in the arm

Option A: Therapeutic embolisation

  • It stops bleeding from the gastrointestinal, urinary, gynaecological, and respiratory tracts.
  • It is used to treat arteriovenous malformations by blocking their arterial supply and controlling tumours' growth.

Option B: Transluminal angioplasty and stenting

  • It treats arterial occlusive diseases by inserting a balloon catheter into an artery and inflating it within a blocked area.
  • This technique is suitable for patients with claudication, rest pain, or tissue necrosis,

Option D: Heparin infusion

  • Heparin infusion is indicated in patients for the prevention or treatment of deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and atrial fibrillation.
  • Heparin infusion has no role in treating arterial occlusion/compression.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of multiple red spots on his trunk. He first noticed these several months ago, and some appear to have increased in size. One day ago, he scratched one of these spots, which bled for several minutes. A photograph of the lesions is shown in the image:



Among the following clinical entities, which is this patient's most likely possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cherry hemangiomas

  • This patient most likely suffers from Cherry hemangiomas, benign vascular proliferations that commonly develop in adult patients.
  • The diagnosis is typically based on the clinical appearance of multiple bright red, dome-shaped papules on the trunk and upper extremities that bleed with trauma and usually blanch with pressure.
  • Cherry hemangiomas manifest more frequently with age and do not regress.
  • On histological examination, dilated interconnecting capillaries within the papillary dermis are seen.
  • The treatment is necessary unless lesions become bothersome such as frequent bleeding, or are cosmetically unappealing.
  • The treatment options for removal include electrocauterization, laser therapy, and excision.

Option A: Bacillary angiomatosis

  • The Bartonella henselae infections cause bacillary angiomatosis.
  • Bacillary angiomatosis manifests with vascular proliferations that bleed with trauma, like the lesions seen in this patient.
  • Although the lesions of bacillary angiomatosis can manifest with a papular appearance, they also commonly manifest as nodular, pedunculated, or verrucous lesions. In addition, this condition usually develops in patients infected with HIV, of which there is no indication here.

Option C: Strawberry angiomas

  • Strawberry angioma is characterized by benign, vascular proliferations that may bleed with trauma, like the lesions in this patient.
  • However, strawberry angiomas usually develop in the first weeks of life on the head or neck and then involute by 5–8 years of age.

Option D: Amelanotic melanoma

  • Amelanotic melanoma is characterized by a rare variant of melanoma that manifests as a skin-coloured or red papule or nodule.
  • Amelanotic melanoma may also bleed with trauma. However, unlike multiple lesions, this condition typically manifests as a solitary lesion.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presented to us with c/o epigastric pain and weight loss. He also gave a history of dyspepsia and progressively increasing jaundice with clay-colored stools with no history of fever or pruritus. On physical examination, there was evidence for icterus without any palpable neck lymphadenopathy. Abdominal and chest CT scan confirmed the presence of a tumor measuring 50 mm in the head of the pancreas. Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) also indicated that the tumor was in contact with both the SMA and the SMV, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy revealed adenocarcinoma. On the basis of these clinical findings, the patient was diagnosed with Unresectable Locally Advanced Pancreatic cancer. Which of the following drug can be prescribed to the patient to increase his survival rate?
questions.solution:
• Gemcitabine is currently the standard of care for patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer
  • Gemcitabine was approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for use in pancreatic cancer in 1996.
  • In patients with unresectable pancreatic cancer, gemcitabine results in symptomatic improvement, improved pain control and performance status, and weight gain.
  • Prior to gemcitabine, 5-fluorouracil was used as the standard treatment for unresectable pancreatic cancer

questions.text: A 27-year-old female is admitted to the hospital with a complaint of abdominal swelling associated with a history of fever for 2 weeks. She is anemic with a Hb of 10.0 g/dl; liver functions were within normal limit; ESR = 70 mm/hr (Normal = <20). Based on her CT findings, she was diagnosed with GI tuberculosis. What is the most common indication for surgery in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Acute Obstruction

  • Patients with abdominal tuberculosis have a wide range of clinical presentations due to complex pathological processes.
  • The diagnosis is usually based on radiological imaging along with endoscopy.
  • Common acute presentations include intestinal obstruction, perforation, and rarely gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • The other clinical presentation may be in the form of recurrent intestinal obstruction, ileocecal mass with an uncertain diagnosis, fistulizing tuberculosis, and incidentally detected peritoneal tuberculosis. Management includes a judicious combination of anti-tubercular treatment and intervention (surgery and endoscopic).
  • Common indication of surgery is intestinal perforation, obstruction, failed medical therapy, gastrointestinal hemorrhage, and diagnostic uncertainty.

Option B: Mucosal ulcerations

  • Gastrointestinal tuberculosis presents with different symptoms and mucosal ulcerations are one of the most common symptoms.
  • Surgery is only indicated in acute and emergency conditions. Since mucosal ulcerations in TB is not a surgical emergency, therefore it is not an indication for surgical exploration.

Option C: Mass in the abdomen

  • Mass in the abdomen is a common physical exam finding of tuberculosis. Surgery is only indicated in acute and emergency conditions.
  • Since abdominal mass in TB is not a surgical emergency, therefore it is not an indication for surgical exploration.
  • However, if the mass remains undiagnosed even after multiple biopsies, then it requires surgical exploration.

Option D: GI symptoms

  • Non-acute GI symptoms in TB are not a surgical emergency.
  • Surgery is indicated only if there is evidence of obstruction, perforation, or severe GI hemorrhage

questions.text: Which of the following is true about appendectomy?

choices.text: Lanz incision is also known as Battle incision
Purse string suture in cases of edematous and inflamed caecal wall
Crushing is done in a gangrenous base of the appendix
The base is not crushed in cases of an inflamed base of the appendix

questions.solution:
Option D: The base is not crushed in cases of an inflamed base of the appendix

  • Treatment of choice for acute uncomplicated appendicitis - emergency appendectomy.
  • Many types of incision have been introduced depending upon clinical findings about the site of maximum tenderness, confirmation of diagnosis and patient preference.
  • Upon entering the peritoneum appendix is identified, and adhesions are released.
  • The next step is clamping and ligation of the base of the mesoappendix 
  • The base of the appendix is crushed near its junction with the caecum.
  • The 2/0 ligature is followed by appendix amputation. 
  • Occasionally, a purse string suture is tied in the caecum about 1.25 cm from the base, and the appendix is invaginated.

 

Methods to be adopted in special circumstances

The inflamed base of the appendix
  • The base is not crushed as it may spread infection through the bloodstream and lymphatics.
  • The base of the appendix is ligated close to the caecal wall tightly enough to occlude the lumen, after which the appendix is removed and the stump invaginated.

The gangrenous base of the appendix
  • Neither ligation nor crushing should be done.
  • Two stitches are placed through the wall of the caecum near the base of the gangrenous appendix. It is followed by the removal of the appendix, which is amputated flush with the wall of the caecum, after which those two stitches are tied.

Edematous and inflamed caecal wall
  • Purse string suture is not applied.
  • The stump is not invaginated.

Option A: Lanz incision is also known as Battle incision

  • Lanz incision is also known as Gridiron incision incision, not battle incision.
  • It is a transverse skin crease incision of appropriate length made approximately 2 cm below the umbilicus centered on the midclavicular and mid-inguinal lines.
  • The Lanz incision gives additional cosmetic benefits because it is hidden below the bikini line.

Option B: Purse string suture is applied in cases of edematous and inflamed caecal wall

  • Purse string suture is not applied in cases of an edematous and inflamed caecal wall.
  • The purse-string suture is in danger of cutting out when applied to the edematous caecal wall.
  • If the caecal oedema is limited, this can be overcome by putting the purse-string suture into a healthier part of the caecal wall farther from the base of the appendix.

Option C: Crushing is done in a gangrenous base of the appendix

  • Neither ligation nor crushing should be done.
  • Two stitches are placed through the wall of the caecum near the base of the gangrenous appendix. It is followed by the removal of the appendix, which is amputated flush with the wall of the caecum, after which those two stitches are tied.
  • Further closure is done through the second layer of interrupted seromuscular sutures.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents to the OPD with complaints of purple spots on her body and frequent nose and gum bleeding episodes. On probing her history further, it was found that she hasa known case of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura and has been on steroid treatment for two months. On examination, the patient has a non-palpable purpura with gingival bleeding. Her platelet count is 8000/cu.mm. The patient is taken in for elective splenectomy. What is the most common post-splenectomy complication?
questions.solution:
Option B: Left lower lobe atelectasis

  • After splenectomy, pulmonary complications like left lower lobe atelectasis, pleural effusion, and pneumonia develop.
  • Left lower lobe atelectasis is the most common pulmonary complication.
  • General anesthesia and surgical manipulation lead to atelectasis by causing diaphragmatic dysfunction and decreased surfactant activity.
  • Post-operative atelectasis is treated with adequate oxygenation and re-expansion of the alveoli. Supplemental oxygen should be titrated to achieve an arterial oxygen saturation greater than 90%.
  • Severe hypoxemia associated with severe respiratory distress should lead to intubation and mechanical support.

Option A: Hematemesis

  • Hematemesis after splenectomy can develop due to complications like portal hypertension or vascular injury to short gastric vessels.

Option C: Pleural effusion

  • Pleural effusion is one of the pulmonary complications which develop after splenectomy.
  • It is not the most common complication.

Option D: Acute dilatation of stomach

  • Gastric dilatation and resultant volvulus occur when the pylorus is malpositioned after manipulation.
  • There is severe gastric distension with gas, food, and/or fluid, resulting in secondary life-threatening complications.
  • Some studies advocate gastropexy.

questions.text: A 66-year-old male presented with symptoms of urinary hesitancy, poor urinary stream, post-void dribbling, and urine retention. The prostate was hard and nodular on digital rectal examination. Imaging showed extensive, calcified areas of the prostatic parenchyma. What is the correct statement about this condition?

choices.text: Benign prostate hyperplasia is a cause of prostate stones
Usually present at the peripheral zone of the prostate
No treatment is needed in this patient
No lamellar bodies are formed in prostatic calculi

questions.solution:
Option A: Benign prostate hyperplasia is a cause of prostate stones

  • The prostatic calculi are commonly present in old-aged males but are usually asymptomatic. But if they cause any obstructive urinary symptoms, they must be treated.
  • The above-given case is prostatic calculi diagnosed by the X-ray and the pelvis CT.
  • Benign prostate hyperplasia is the inflammation of the prostate that causes the production of thick secretions from the prostate. These thick secretions tend to bind with the proteinaceous substances in the prostate. It causes fluid to become harder and tends to form into stones.
  • The patient has urinary symptoms such as hesitancy, poor urinary steam and postvoid dribbling. These obstructive urinary symptoms need management.
  • Diagnosis may be made by:  
    • CT scan of the pelvis
    • X-rays of the kidney and bladder      
    • Transrectal ultrasound
  • Treatment is usually unnecessary, but in complicated cases, antibiotics are required, or surgery is done to remove the stones. The options are:
  • Transurethral electroresection loop surgery
  • Holmium laser surgery

Option B: Usually present at the peripheral zone of the prostate

  • These stones are usually present in the peripheral region of the transition zone of the prostate.  

Option C: No treatment is needed for this patient

  • In asymptomatic patients, no treatment is needed for prostatic calculi.
  • As this patient presents with obstructive urinary symptoms, treatment is needed.

Option D: No lamellar bodies are formed in prostatic calculi

  • The prostatic calculi usually tend to form in clusters (lamellar bodies)

questions.text: A forty-five-year-old woman presents to your clinic with the complaint of a pigmented lesion on her right thigh. Her medical history is insignificant. She says this lesion has gradually increased in size. She undergoes an incisional biopsy which reveals malignant melanoma with a thickness of 3 mm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?

choices.text: Wide local excision with a 1-cm margin, followed by radiotherapy
Wide local excision with a 1-cm margin and groin lymph node dissection
Wide local excision with a 2-cm margin and sentinel lymph node biopsy
Wide local excision with a 2-cm margin and groin lymph node dissection

questions.solution:
Option C: Wide local excision with a 2-cm margin and sentinel lymph node biopsy

  • Melanoma is a type of skin cancer arising from melanocytes.
  • It usually occurs in the skin.
  • The primary cause of melanoma is ultraviolet light which usually occurs in people with low levels of melanin.
  • Treatment of melanoma is wide local excision.
  • The size of the excision is determent by the thickness of the melanoma:
    • < 1 mm – 1 cm margin
    • 1-4 mm – 2 cm margin
    • > 4 mm – 2 to 3 cm margin
  • A sentinel lymph node biopsy should follow this.
  • The sentinel node is the first node that drains a particular nodal basin.
  • It is identified by:
    • Intraoperative injection of blue dye.
    • Preoperative injection of 99m Tc sulfur colloid around the lesion and intraoperatively detected with a gamma counter.
  • Node biopsy is performed to judge the prognosis of the disease.
  • If this comes positive, it is followed by a complete lymph node (LN) dissection.

Option A: Wide local excision with a 1-cm margin, followed by radiotherapy

  • Wide local excision with a 1 cm margin is done for lesions less than 1 mm thick.
  • This patient's lesion is 3mm thick.
  • Malignant melanoma is a radio-resistant tumour.

Option B: Wide local excision with a 1-cm margin and groin lymph node dissection

  • Wide local excision with a 1 cm margin is done for lesions less than 1 mm thick.
  • This patient's lesion is 3mm thick.
  • Lymph node dissection is performed when the sentinel node biopsy comes out positive.

Option D: Wide local excision with a 2-cm margin and groin lymph node dissection

  • Lymph node dissection is performed when the sentinel node biopsy comes out positive.
  • Sentinel node biopsy will be performed before a nodal dissection.

questions.text: A male infant was born at 38+2 weeks gestation and birth weight of 3.42kg. Polyhydramnios was noted on antenatal scanning. On day one, the infant had repeated episodes of vomiting in between feeds and had not passed meconium from birth. Abdominal distension was evident and following NGT placement, there were bile-stained aspirates. The anus was patent. Abdominal radiography demonstrated dilated loops of bowel and a Gastrografin study showed no flow of contrast beyond the rectosigmoid junction.Which is a true statement regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: A coffee bean sign is seen on radiography
Snowstorm sign on ultrasound is seen
Surgery is performed in complicated cases
The terminal ileum is dilated with a relatively dilated colon

questions.solution:
Option B: A snowstorm sign on ultrasound is seen

  • This patient's presentation, including abdominal distension, vomiting, and delayed passage of meconium in the setting of normal rectal tone on digital rectal examination and dilated loops of the bowel, is consistent with meconium ileus.

Meconium ileus:

  • Meconium ileus is a bowel obstruction that occurs when the meconium in a child's intestine is even thicker and stickier than normal meconium, creating a blockage in a part of the small intestine called the ileum. Meconium ileus is most commonly associated with cystic fibrosis.
  • Meconium ileus accounts for up to 33% of neonatal small-bowel obstructions. Symptoms include emesis that may be bilious, abdominal distention, and failure to pass meconium in the first several days of life. Diagnosis is based on clinical presentation and x-rays. Treatment is enemas with dilute contrast under fluoroscopy and surgery if enemas fail.
  • Plain X-ray of the abdomen post-natally showed specks of calcification mainly at the flanks, while on ultrasonography, specks of high echogenic areas are seen throughout the abdomen, which has been described as a "snow-storm sign”.
  • This is the earliest clinical manifestation of cystic fibrosis in newborns. Risk factors include maternal polyhydramnios, which occurs in 20% of cases.
  • Clinical features: The three cardinal signs are generalized abdominal distension, bilious emesis, and failure to pass meconium

Types:

1. Complicated (prenatal perforation or vascular compromise)

2. Uncomplicated (no intestinal perforation)

Diagnosis of meconium ileus:

  • Antenatal ultrasound indicates the presence of intraabdominal or scrotal calcifications and distended bowel loops.
  • Plain radiographs show dilated and air-filled small bowel loops, no air-fluid levels as the enteric contents are highly viscous, and ground glass appearance/soap bubble appearance in the right lower quadrant (due to the entrapment of small bubbles of gas in the inspissated meconium in the distended ileum)
  • Initial diagnostic study of choice: Contrast enema using a water-soluble ionic solution.
  • An ultrasound scan may reveal a snowstorm appearance.
  • Gastrografin contrast enema demonstrates microcolon.
  • Complicated meconium ileus shows intraperitoneal calcifications are seen which produce an eggshell pattern on abdominal X-ray.

Complicated Meconium Ileus

  • Meconium ileus is considered complicated when perforation of the intestine has taken place.
  • Meconium within the peritoneal cavity results in severe peritonitis with a dense inflammatory response and calcification (Snow-storm sign on USG)
  • Management is usually conservative.

Option A: A coffee bean sign is seen on radiography

  • Sigmoid volvulus may present as Soap bubble appearance on radiography.

Option C: Surgery is performed in complicated cases

  • Meconium ileus is managed conservatively. There isn’t any indication of surgery.

Option D: The terminal ileum is dilated with a relatively dilated colon

  • The terminal ileum is dilated with a relatively small colon in the meconium ileus. Dilated terminal ileum along with dilated colon is seen in Hirschsprung's disease.

questions.text: Balu is a 15-year-old male adolescent referred to the weight clinic with a body mass index (BMI) of 50. He is referred based on his history of severe obesity and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease and for a discussion of weight loss surgery. The patient has tried a low-carbohydrate and low-fat diet, reduced his portion sizes, worked with a nutritionist, and increased his level of physical activity, but could not achieve or maintain a healthy body weight. After evaluating the patient, bariatric surgery, specifically a laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG), is Balu’s best option to treat his severe obesity. Which of the following is a feature of bariatric surgery?

choices.text: Indication for bariatric surgery: patients with a BMI of 25 Kg/m2 or more with comorbidities.
The most commonly performed bariatric procedure nowadays is Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.
Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding is irreversible
The most common cause of death within 30 days of bariatric surgery is peritonitis due to an anastomotic leak

questions.solution:
Option B: Most commonly performed procedure nowadays is Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB).

  • Bariatric surgery is a procedure to help reduce weight in cases where dietary and medical interventions have failed.
  • RYGB is a bariatric procedure resulting in a restrictive and mildly malabsorptive condition.
  • The upper part of the stomach is surgically attached directly to the small intestine.
  • It is the most commonly performed procedure now.

Option A: Indications for Bariatric surgery in patients with a BMI of 25 Kg/m2 or more with comorbidity.

  • Bariatric surgery is performed in patients with a BMI of 40kg/m2 or more with no comorbidity.

Option C: Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding is irreversible.

Laparoscopic gastric banding is a reversible procedure.

Option D: The most common cause of death within 30 days of bariatric surgery is peritonitis due to an anastomotic leak.

  • One of the complications of bariatric surgery is peritonitis due to an anastomotic leak. However, this is an immediate postoperative complication.
  • The most common cause of death after bariatric surgery within 30 days is Pulmonary embolism (36%), followed by cardiac complications (24%) and Anastomotic leaks (20%)

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presented to the emergency room after a motorcycle accident. Vital signs were within normal limits, and abdominal pain and two incised wounds on the right side of the abdomen were found on physical examination. CT scan showed multiple lacerations on the right renal parenchyma with mild urinoma. With the result of the CT and the patient’s clinically stable status, a conservative approach was decided. Now on follow-up after 12 days, the urinoma has persisted, but the patient is stable, and there is no fever. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: J–shaped urinary stent

  • Minor renal injuries from blunt trauma account for 85% of cases and do not usually require an operation.
  • The bleeding stops spontaneously with bed rest and hydration.
  • In this patient, the urinoma has persisted even after 12 days, so a J-shaped urinary stent is required.

Option A: Percutaneous exploration and repair

  • The cases in which operation is indicated include those associated with:
  • Persistent retroperitoneal bleeding
  • Urinary extravasation
  • Evidence of nonviable renal parenchyma
  • Renal pedicle injuries

Option B: Wait and watch

  • The wait-and-watch approach is useful when dealing with minor renal injuries, but in this case, the urinoma has persisted even after 12 days, which warrants interventions.

Option D: Percutaneous nephrectomy

  • It is a procedure of choice in cases of large renal stones or when other initial approaches have failed.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of malaise and abdominal pain. Eight weeks ago, he underwent liver transplantation for primary sclerosing cholangitis. At the time of discharge, his total serum bilirubin concentration was 1.0 mg/dL. His current medications include daily tacrolimus, prednisone, valganciclovir, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), his pulse is 95/min, and his blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus. His leukocyte count is 2500/mm3, serum bilirubin concentration is 2.6 mg/dL, and serum tacrolimus concentration is within the therapeutic range. Biopsy of grafted donor tissue reveals graft rejection. Which statements regarding the rejection of solid organ transplants are true?

choices.text: Hyperacute rejection begins in the operating room with reperfusion of the transplanted organ
Liver transplants are especially susceptible to hyperacute rejection.
Most immunosuppressive medications are used to prevent chronic rejection.
The major cause of graft failure is acute rejection.

questions.solution:
Option A: Hyperacute rejection begins in the operating room with reperfusion of the transplanted organ

  • Hyperacute rejection results from preformed antibodies directed against the donor tissue.
  • It occurs a few minutes after transplant when the antigens are completely unmatched.
  • It is caused by accidental ABO blood type incompatibility, which is rare.
  • It presents while still in surgery with thrombosis and occlusion of graft vessels.
  • The tissue must be removed immediately so the recipient does not die

 

Transplant Rejection
Type

 

 Onset

 

 Mechanism & Vessel Histology

 

 Type of Hypersensitivity

 
Hyperacute

 

 Immediate

 

Minutes to days

 Preformed antibodies directed against the donor tissue. Caused by accidental ABO blood type incompatibility, which is very rare. Presents while still in surgery with thrombosis and occlusion of graft vessels

 

 II

 
Acute

 

 Weeks to months

 

 T-cell mediated immune response directed against the foreign MHC. Inflammation and leukocyte infiltration of graft vessels results.

 

 IV

 
Chronic

 

 Months to years

 

 T-cell mediated process resulting from the foreign MHC "looking like" a self MHC carrying an antigen. Results in intimal thickening and fibrosis of graft vessels, as well as graft atrophy

 

 III & IV

 
Graft vs Host

 

 Varies

 

 Donor T-cells in the graft proliferate and attack the recipient's tissue. Most commonly seen in bone marrow transplants. Presents with diarrhoea, rash and jaundice

 

 IV

 

Option B: Liver transplants are especially susceptible to hyperacute rejection.

  • Hyperacute rejection occurs in rare cases when there is ABO incompatibility.
  • It is the least common type of transplant rejection in liver transplants.

Option C: Most immunosuppressive medications are used to prevent chronic rejection.

  • Most immunosuppressive agents are given to prevent acute rejection.
  • The most critical time for immuno-protection is the first few days to months after transplantation because the graft is fresh.
  • There is a heightened state of inflammation secondary to inevitable graft injury from ischemia, reperfusion, and the physical transfer of the organ itself.

Option D: The major cause of graft failure is acute rejection.

  • Chronic rejection is the most common cause of graft failure after all solid organ transplants.
  • Over time, there is intimal thickening and fibrosis of graft vessels and graft atrophy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with spinal tuberculosis at the level of L3 vertebrae with paraplegia and with 43 degrees kyphosis. Preoperative imaging demonstrated gross destruction of L3 vertebrae with spinal cord compression. The post-operative imaging has been given below. Identify which of the following statements are not true regarding the surgical intervention.

choices.text: ALD and AD results are the same
ALD: position of the patient is left lateral
ALD: Laminectomy is always a part.
ALD: part of ribs is removed and spinal nerves exposed.

questions.solution:
Option C: Antero-lateral decompression (ALD): Laminectomy is always a part

  • Skeletal tuberculosis most commonly affects the dorso-lumbar (thoracolumbar) spine in adults.
  • Antero-lateral decompression is used for spinal cord compression in tuberculosis kyphosis.
  • Laminectomy is associated with arthritis of the spinal.
  • Laminectomy is not associated with anterolateral decompression.
  • Laminectomy is indicated when the posterior parts of the vertebrae are involved.
  • It enlarges the spinal cord to relieve the pressure, which is caused by bony overgrowth.
  • Bony overgrowth can occur in patients with spinal arthritis.
  • Bony overgrowth of the spinal cord is also known as bone spurs.
  • Laminectomy is the surgery to remove the bone spurs and tissues.
  • It can cause the post-laminectomy disorder.

Option A: Antero-latera decompression and anterior decompression results are the same

  • Surgical options for most cases are anterior decompression + bone grafting or anterolateral decompression + bone grafting.
  • Both procedures have similar success rates.

Option B: Antero-lateral decompression: position of the patient is left lateral

  • In anterolateral decompression, the patient's position is left lateral to avoid damage to the inferior vena cava.

Option D: Antero-lateral decompression: part of the ribs is removed and spinal nerves exposed.

  • Structures removed in anterolateral decompression are:
  • Posterior part of rib + intercostal nerves + one side transverse process + one pedicle + small part of vertebral body anterior to the spinal cord.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a history of a fall one hour ago. He complains of right upper arm pain. No visible swelling is noted on examination. After administering pain medication, an X-ray is ordered. An X-ray of the upper limb is shown below. Keeping in view the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is not the treatment modality for the underlying disorder?
questions.solution:
Option B: Radiotherapy

The given radiograph has a characteristic fallen leaf sign which points toward the unicameral bone cyst. Radiotherapy is used for the treatment.

Unicameral Bone Cyst:

  • True Cyst
  • Most common in the proximal humerus and femur.
  • The lesions are most active during skeletal growth and usually heal spontaneously at maturity.
  • Asymptomatic
  • Radiographs:
    • Centrally located, purely lytic lesion with a well-marginated outline.
    • Thinned cortical fragment fractures and falls into the base of the lesion confirming its empty cystic nature.
    • A fallen fragment sign is pathognomonic of a unicameral bone cyst.
    • Bone fragments may also hinge around and move with fluid called a trap door sign.
  • Unicameral bone cysts are classified as
    • Active: when they are within 1 cm of the physis
    • Latent: when they are closer to the diaphysis.
  • Treatment:
    • Small, asymptomatic lesions in the upper extremities can be treated with observation with serial plain radiographs.
    • Larger lesions (lesions at risk for pathological fracture), symptomatic lesions, and lesions in the lower extremities usually are treated with :
      • Curettage (with or without bone grafting or internal fixation)
      • Aspiration and injection (steroids, bone marrow aspirate, demineralized bone matrix, or sclerosant).

Option A: Sclerosant

  • This is used for the large symptomatic lesions on the lower extremities.

Option C: Curettage and bone grafting

  • This is used for the large symptomatic lesions on the lower extremities.

Option D: Steroids

  • After the aspiration of the cyst, a steroid injection is given.
  • This is used for the large symptomatic lesions on the lower extremities.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident 20 minutes ago. He sustained an injury to the wrist and complained of wrist pain. On examination, he is vitally stable. Hands deformities are noted as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ulnar claw hand

  • Also known as Partial claw hand

The following are important points of ulnar nerve injury at the wrist:

Option B: Median claw hand

  • Also known as Partial claw hand
  • Involving only Lateral two lumbricals as in isolated median nerve palsy

Option C: Total claw hand

  • Medial two lumbricals: Ulnar nerve
  • Lateral two lumbricals: Median nerve
  • The action of lumbricals: Extension of the interphalangeal joint and flexion of the metacarpophalangeal joint.
  • Also seen in klumpky’s paralysis.

Option D: Pointing index

  • If the functioning of flexor pollicis longus, flexor digitorum profundus, and flexor digitorum superficialis is lost, the index finger can't flex upon making a fist. This results in the Pointing Index.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents to the clinic for the evaluation of his arm deformity for the past 2 months. Four months ago, he fell from the roof and got his humerus fractured. At that time, he was treated by a local doctor for his injury. On examination, his arm findings are given below.Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current deformity?
questions.solution:
Option B: Supracondylar fracture Humerus

  • The images show Cubitus varus deformity.
  • Cubitus varus (Gunstock deformity): Caused by supracondylar fracture of humerus leading to varus malunion, especially in medial comminution pattern.
  • Cubitus varus: Carrying angle decreases

Option A: Humerus lateral condylar fracture

  • Intra-Articular Fracture
  • This can also lead to ''Tardy Ulnar nerve palsy.''
  • Complication: Cubitus valgus is caused by the Non- union of fracture of lateral condyle of the Humerus bone.

Option C: Fracture shaft Humerus

  • Radial nerve injury leads to wrist drop.
  • The most common cause of radial nerve injury is the Fracture shaft Humerus.

Option D: Medial Condyle fracture of humerus

  • It is a type of avulsion injury.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by his son with complaints of left-side chest pain radiating to the left arm for 1 hour. The patient looks restless and is sweating profusely. He gives no history of any other abnormalities. He has been diabetic for five years. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. The ECG of the patient was done, which revealed ST elevation in the inferior leads. The patient had an inadequate response to all non-surgical therapies. The patient was posted for coronary artery bypass graft surgery under general anaesthesia. After the administration of premedication, preoxygenation should be done for denitrogenation and to overcome the apneic period during intubation. Ideally, this patient should be pre-oxygenated for:
questions.solution:
Option A: 3-5 min

  • This is a case of myocardial infarction in which the patient presents with complaints of left-side chest pain radiating to the left arm for 1 hour. The patient looks restless and is sweating profusely. The ECG of the patient was done, which revealed ST elevation in the inferior leads. The patient had an inadequate response to all non-surgical therapies. The patient was posted for coronary artery bypass graft surgery under general anaesthesia.
  • Preoxygenation entails the replacement of the nitrogen volume of the lung (as much as 95% of FRC) with oxygen in order to provide a reservoir for diffusion into the alveolar capillary blood after the onset of apnea.
  • In accordance, routine preoxygenation before the tracheal extubation has also been recommended.
  • To provide effective preoxygenation, a methodical approach is necessary. The importance of preoxygenation with a tight-fitting mask should be explained to the patient beforehand.
  • Preoxygenation is typically performed via a facemask with 100% oxygen at a high flow rate (10-12 l/min), and no leaks around the mask must be present.
  • Once preoxygenation is initiated, EtO2and FIO2values should be monitored closely. If the EtO2value does not increase as expected, the anaesthesia provider may have to hold the mask with both hands and/or replace the mask with a better-fitting one.
  • An end-tidal concentration of oxygen >90% is considered to maximise apnoea time. Whenever possible, the induction should not start until the EtO2 value approximates or exceeds 90%.
  • Time to oxyhemoglobin desaturation <80% can vary from 9 minutes in healthy nonobese adults to 3 minutes or less in children or obese adults.

  • Considering the normal oxygen demand of 200–250 mL/min, the preoxygenated patient may have a 5–8 min oxygen reserve

questions.text: A 27-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department in a confused state, complaining of headache, nausea, and shortness of breath. She explains that she was sleeping in a room with the heater on the whole night. There is no history of any comorbid conditions. On examination, BP=100/60mmHg, HR=112/min, SpO2=97% and RR=30 breaths/min. Which of the following poisoning can be suspected?
questions.solution:
Option B: Carboxyhemoglobin

  • Pulse oximetry, sometimes the fifth vital sign, is a non-invasive method of measuring haemoglobin saturation SPO2 using a light signal transmitted through tissue.
  • A low SPO2 can provide a warning of hypoxaemia before other signs, such as cyanosis or a change in heart rate, are observed.
  • The pulse oximeter estimates SPO2 from the tissue's differential red and infrared light absorption. The two wavelengths allow the differentiation of reduced haemoglobin and oxyhemoglobin.
  • Whole blood often contains other moieties such as carboxyhemoglobin, sulfhemoglobin, and methaemoglobin. It disturbs the absorbance ratio of the wavelengths used to determine oxygen saturation.
  • Carboxyhemoglobin is formed when haemoglobin is exposed to carbon monoxide and has an absorption spectrum similar to that of oxyhemoglobin so that most pulse oximeters will over-read SPO2 by the percentage of carboxyhemoglobin present.
  • In one study, the pulse oximeter reading did not go below 96%, with carboxyhemoglobin levels as high as 44%.
  • In vitro, carbon monoxide oximetry can measure the percentages of other moieties by using more than two wavelengths.

Option A: Methemoglobin

  • Methemoglobin is an oxidation product of haemoglobin that forms a reversible complex with oxygen and impairs the unloading of oxygen to tissues.
  • It absorbs light equally at most pulse oximeters' red and infrared wavelengths.
  • Compared with functional saturation, most pulse oximeters give false readings for saturations above 85% and falsely high values for saturations below 85%.

Option C: Haemoglobin S, Haemoglobin F

  • Most studies show that fetal haemoglobin (HbF) does not appear to affect the accuracy of pulse oximetry to a clinically important degree. However, very high levels may cause it to read slightly low.
  • The use of pulse oximetry in sickle cell disease is controversial. It is inaccurate and unreliable for detecting serious hypoxemia.

Option D: Sulfhemoglobin

  • Sulfhemoglobinemia may be caused by drugs such as metoclopramide, phenacetin, dapsone, and sulfonamides.
  • Sulfhemoglobin causes the pulse oximeter to display artefactually low oxygen saturation

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of falls and trauma to the head is brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state; a CT scan shows "EDH," and he undergoes a decompressive craniotomy. He was shifted to ICU for elective postoperative ventilation. The patient was sedated and paralyzed with infusions of propofol, midazolam, and Injection vecuronium. On 3rd day, his Blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, pulse rate is 48/minute, and SpO2 is 96% at room air. Blood investigations showed Hb-13g/dl, blood urea-80 mg/dl, serum creatinine is 3 mg/dl, PH-7.15, PO2-200 mmHg, PCO2-20 mmHg, HCO3--15 mmol/l, Na+ 140 mEq/l, K+ 5.8 mEq/l, blood cholesterol-350 mg/dl, triglycerides are 300 mg/dl. Ultrasonography Abdomen revealed hepatomegaly. Chest X-ray is normal. The most probable diagnosis will be?
questions.solution:
Option B: Propofol infusion syndrome

  • According to the above scenario, there is metabolic acidosis, and potassium and sodium are also mildly deranged. Hence the suitable answer is propofol infusion syndrome (PRIS) because it causes unexplained metabolic acidosis, arrhythmias, acute renal failure, hyperkalemia, and cardiovascular collapse.
  • Propofol infusion syndrome is a rare but lethal syndrome seen when the dose of propofol infusion is greater than 4 mg/kg/hour or more for 48 hours or longer.
  • This syndrome is common in children and critically ill adults.
  • Clinical features include acute refractory bradycardia leading to asystole in the presence of one or more of the following:
    • Metabolic acidosis (base deficit >10 mmol/L)
    • Rhabdomyolysis
    • Hyperlipidemia
    • Enlarged or fatty liver
  • Other features include cardiomyopathy with acute cardiac failure, skeletal myopathy, hyperkalemia, hepatomegaly, and lipemia.
  • The symptoms and signs are the results of muscle injury and the release of intracellular toxic contents.
  • Lipemia is a sign as increasing lipemia was the first indication of propofol infusion syndrome. It is due to defects in mitochondrial metabolism and electron transport chain function.
  • Poor oxygen delivery, sepsis, serious cerebral injury, and large propofol dosage are the major risk factors.

Option A: Critical illness polyneuropathy/myopathy

  • This disease is characterized by more proximal than distal weakness, sensory preservation, and atrophy.

Option C: Hepatic encephalopathy

  • Hepatic encephalopathy is a nervous system disorder brought on by the severe liver disease.
  • When the liver is damaged, toxins build up in the blood. These toxins travel to the brain and affect brain function.

Option D: Central pontine myelinolysis

  • It is a neurological disorder that most frequently occurs after too rapid medical correction of sodium deficiency (hyponatremia).
  • Symptoms include confusion, delirium, slurred speech and weakness of muscles.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male who is a case of pleomorphic adenoma of parotid is being posted for superficial parotidectomy under general anaesthesia. The patient is induced with Inj. Thiopentone sodium and cisatracurium are used to facilitate endotracheal intubation and maintenance. Which of the following features of cisatracurium reduces the chances of hemodynamic instability in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: No histamine release

  • Cisatracurium is a purified 1R cis-1'R cis-isomer of Atracurium.
  • It has a similar profile as Atracurium except that no histamine release is seen secondary to its administration, reducing the chances of hemodynamic instability in patients.

Option A: No ester hydrolysis

  • It is a feature of cisatracurium, but it plays no direct role in hemodynamic stability in patients.

Option B: More potent than Atracurium

  • Cisatracurium is more potent than Atracurium so that it will lead to lower doses being required clinically for the desired effects.

Option D: Metabolism similar to Atracurium

  • Cisatracurium undergoes Hofmann Elimination, a spontaneous non-enzymatic organ-independent degradation similar to Atracurium. Therefore, it is very useful in patients having hepatic or renal dysfunction.

questions.text: A 2-month-old boy was brought to the physician's office with cyanotic spells since birth. On physical examination, there was central cyanosis, ejection systolic murmur at the left mid to upper sternal border, and radiological findings as given below. After examination, an ECG was done, which showed right axis deviation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Tetralogy of Fallot

Tetralogy of Fallot

  • Most common cyanotic heart disease. There is right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Seen in older children more commonly

  • On physical examination, there is central cyanosis, a single loud second heart sound, and harsh ejection systolic murmur at the left mid to upper sternal border.

  • Four components of Tetralogy of Fallot

    • Right ventricular hypertrophy

    • VSD

    • Infundibular pulmonary stenosis

    • Overriding aorta

  • Right axis deviation (on ECG)

  • Boot-shaped heart on chest x-ray (indicates right ventricular hypertrophy)

  • Coeur-en-sabot (boot-shaped heart/ upturned apex) (suggestive of right ventricular hypertrophy)

Option A: Tricuspid atresia

  • Absence of tricuspid valve and hypoplastic right ventricle.

  • Requires both Atria septal defect and ventricle septal defect for viability.

Option C: Ebstein anomaly

  • It affects the right ventricle and tricuspid valve involving the atrialization of the right ventricle, which results in a small right ventricle with an apically displaced (low insertion) tricuspid valve.

  • A confluence of the following causes the appearance of the Ebstein anomaly:

    • Large right atrium occupying the whole right hemithorax (large, curving right atrial border);

    • The left cardiac shape seems shelved due to an enlarged right ventricular outflow tract or raised residual right ventricle.

    • Small aorta and major pulmonary artery, respectively

  • Box-shaped heart on chest x-ray.

Option D: Coarctation of Aorta

  • The arteries in the upper body and the head and neck have increased blood flow with coarctation of the aorta, but the vessels in the lower body do not receive adequate blood flow.

  •  The patient has brachiofemoral delay, and the subclavian artery branches that make up the anterior and posterior intercostal arteries interact with the descending aorta.

  • As a result, the intercostal arteries enlarge and become pulsating, which causes the inferior ribs to be notched.

    • Three sign is a stenotic segment with a pre-stenotic dilatation and a post-stenotic dilatation (due to constriction at the aorta level).

    • Bariatric swallowing: Reverse 3 sign

    • Rosler's sign Refers to inferior rib notching on chest x-ray (noted in coarctation of the aorta)​​​​​​​

    • coarctation of aorta" class="n3VNCb KAlRDb" data-noaft="1" height="194" jsaction="load:XAeZkd;" jsname="HiaYvf" src="https://f6publishing.blob.core.windows.net/b05e5264-65b4-47f6-bf46-b4233e81176e/WJC-12-167-g005.png" style="margin: 0px;" width="224" />

questions.text:
A 19-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient department due to recurrent chest infection, production of copious sputum, and hemoptysis for 2 weeks. He has had a history of cystic fibrosis, for which he takes medications regularly. Physical examinations reveal bilateral wheezing and inspiratory squeaks. The chest x-ray gives the following findings:



What is the gold standard investigation to confirm the underlying diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: HRCT

  • The patient described in the clinical vignette presents with clinical features of bronchiectasis.

  • The bronchiectasis in this patient occurred secondary to cystic fibrosis.

  • Other causes of bronchiectasis include primary ciliary dyskinesia, primary immunodeficiency disorder, and HIV/AIDS.

  • Bronchiectasis is identified by a productive cough for more than 3 weeks, recurrent infections, foul-smelling sputum, and hemoptysis.

  • Chest x-rays are usually abnormal in bronchiectasis, but they are insufficient for diagnosing or quantifying bronchiectasis. It shows tram track opacities.

  • High-resolution chest CT (HRCT) is the gold standard for diagnosing bronchiectasis.

  • Common findings in HRCT of bronchiectasis are:

    • Bronchus visualization within 1 cm of the pleural surface, particularly in the lung adjacent to the costal pleura, is the most helpful sign of early cylindrical change.

    • The bronchoarterial ratio increased due to a lack of tapering

  • Classic signs on CT include the tram-track sign, signet ring sign, the string of pearls sign, and the bunch of grapes sign.

Option A: CT chest with intravenous contrast

  • Using contrast-enhanced chest CT imaging is indicated to investigate vascular and pleural diseases.

  • It is usually not an ideal choice for detecting diseases of lung parenchyma like bronchiectasis.

Option B: MRI chest

  • MRI chest is inferior to HRCT regarding the sensitivity of detecting bronchiectasis and other lung conditions.

Option C: CT angiogram

  • It is best for the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism.

  • However, it is of no use in the diagnosis of bronchiectasis.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the pediatric OPD with the complaint of lethargy, poor growth speech and learning difficulties. On examination, she has macroglossia, coarse dry skin and growth retardation. An X-ray was done, which revealed stippled Epiphysis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Congenital Hypothyroidism

  • This patient's signs and symptoms are highly suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism.
  • Congenital hypothyroidism is a condition in which there is inadequate production of thyroid hormones in newborns.
  • It occurs due to an absent or underdeveloped thyroid gland (dysgenesis) or the inability of the thyroid gland to make a hormone (dyshormonogenesis).
  • Symptoms of infantile hypothyroidism include decreased activity, large anterior fontanelle, hypotonia, poor feeding and weight gain, jaundice, and decreased stooling.
  • If left untreated, patients present with short stature, enlarged head, and developmental delay, which can lead to permanent mental disabilities.
  • Plain radiographs reveal delayed skeletal maturation; bone ossification centers are small or absent, which gives the appearance of stippled Epiphysis and cortical thickening.

Causes for Stippled Epiphysis:

  • Congenital hypothyroidism (cretinism) is a group of skeletal dysplasias called chondrodysplasia punctate.
  • Alcohol use during pregnancy
  • Warfarin use during pregnancy
  • Vitamin K deficiency

Option B: Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis

  • It is the most common arthritic disease in childhood.
  • Synovial thickening, joint effusion, and soft tissue swelling can be appreciated on radiographs.

Option C: Scurvy

  • The radiographic finding of scurvy includes cortical thinning, ground glass osteoporosis, and corner angel signs which irregular metaphyseal margins.

Option D: Achondroplasia

  • Chevron sign is a radiologic finding and is associated with achondroplasia.
  • It is an inverted V-shaped metaphysis which causes a waddling gait.
  • In the lower limb, the radiographic features widening of the metaphysis, posterior bowing of the humerus, and bones are short and wide.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman, after total knee implant surgery, complained of calf pain and swelling in the leg for the last 2 days. She later complained of breathlessness. An urgent chest X-ray was done, which showed a Westermark sign. Which of the following describes the Westermark sign in Pulmonary Thromboembolism?

choices.text: Prominence of Descending Right Pulmonary artery

questions.solution:
Option B: Pulmonary Oligemia

  •  Oligemia is a decrease in pulmonary blood flow indicated by the regional or widespread reduction in the size and number of identifiable pulmonary vessels.
  • Oligemia occurs when there is a reduction in the pulmonary blood volume.
  • This reduction is regional most frequently; however, it is occasionally generalized. When regional, it is usually associated with reduced blood flow in the oligemic areas.
  • Pulmonary embolism occurs when there is occlusion of the pulmonary arterial system due to emboli.
  • These emboli lead to a thrombotic occlusion and result in a thromboembolic situation.
  • Sign in Pulmonary Thromboembolism:
    • Fleischner sign: Enlarged main pulmonary artery
    • Hampton hump: Peripheral wedge of airspace opacity and implies lung infarction
    • Westermark sign: Regional oligemia and highest positive predictive value.
    • Palla sign: enlarged right descending pulmonary artery
    • Chang sign: dilated and sudden change in caliber of the main pulmonary artery due to pulmonary embolism. 

Option A: Peripheral Wedge shaped infarct

  • Hampton hump refers to a dome-shaped, pleural-based opacification in the lung most commonly due to pulmonary embolism and lung infarction (it can also result from other causes of pulmonary infarction (e.g. vascular occlusion due to angio invasive aspergillosis). 

Option C: Prominence of Main Pulmonary Artery

  • The Fleischner sign refers to a prominent central pulmonary artery commonly caused either by pulmonary hypertension or by distension of the vessel by a large pulmonary embolus

Option D: Prominence of Descending Right Pulmonary artery

pulmonary trunk on chest radiography (differential) | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org" class="n3VNCb KAlRDb" data-noaft="1" jsaction="load:XAeZkd;" jsname="HiaYvf" src="https://prod-images-static.radiopaedia.org/images/307084/0d730e0b782fe7d8181e81cd3610b5_gallery.jpg" style="width: 270px; height: 270px; margin: 0px;" />

  • The Palla sign describes an enlarged right desending pulmonary artery and when present is suggestive of an occlusion of a lobar or segmental pulmonary artery or widespread occlusion of the small arteries.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents to the physician with complaints of gradually increasing intervals between her menstrual cycle. She further gives a history that her last menstrual period was 4 months ago. The patient states that she is worried about her condition. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. The clinician reassures her that these changes are normal for her age. Which of the following is true regarding the condition of the patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Decrease in Inhibin B

  • This is a case of perimenopause in which the patient presents with complaints of gradually increasing intervals between her menstrual cycle. The patient is in the menopausal transition. The menopausal transition is the period before the final menstrual period when variability in menstrual cycles is usually increased.
  • Various hormonal changes are also observed during this period.
  • Menopause is secondary to the depletion of ovarian follicles.
  • As the number of follicles decreases, there is a consequent decrease in estrogen, inhibin B and anti-mullerian hormone (all three are primarily produced by granulosa cells of the ovary).
  • Since the theca cells are relatively spared, androgen production declines more slowly.

 

Option A: Decrease in FSH

  • FSH levels increase during menopausal transition and after menopause as the decreasing estrogen gives less negative feedback to hypothalamus and pituitary, and thus LH and FSH levels start to increase.
  • FSH levels > 10 IU/mL are suggestive of menopause and > 40 IU/mL is diagnostic of menopause.

Option B: Increase in estrogen

  • In perimenopausal women, there is usually a decrease in estrogen. It is because the number of ovarian follicles decreases.

Option C: Increase in anti-mullerian hormone

  • In the females in menopausal transition, there will be a decrease in the ovarian follicles and the granulosa cells.
  • This will result in a decrease in the anti-mullerian hormone.

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient known case of PCOS who is being treated for infertility and was prescribed clomiphene citrate 20 days ago for ovulation induction has now presented with sudden onset of abdominal pain and distension with ascites reported on abdominal ultrasound. What is the most probable cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ovarian Hyperstimulation syndrome

  • A woman with a history of ovulation induction with/ without ovulation trigger, presenting with complaints of pain abdomen and abdominal distension, must always raise suspicion of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS).
  • Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is a medical complication that is completely iatrogenic and unique to stimulatory infertility treatment.
  • Its symptoms result from ovarian enlargement and fragility, extravascular fluid accumulation, and intravascular volume depletion.
  • Vascular endothelial growth factor, whose expression in granulosa cells and serum is augmented by hCG, and a variety of other inflammatory cytokines have been implicated in the pathogenesis of this disease.
  • This tends to be more severe with multiple gestations.
  • Clinical features are abdominal distension, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.
  • Management is by monitoring input and output as it is a self-limiting condition and also by:
  • Intravascular fluid intake to replenish the volume
  • Symptomatic treatment, like the tapping of the ascites and pleural effusion in cases of severity.

Option A: Uterine rupture

  • Uterine rupture is a complication of late pregnancy where a previous uterine scar (previous cesarean section scar) ruptures as the patient goes into labour. It is unlikely here as the patient is only at around day 25 of her cycle.

Option B: Ruptured ectopic pregnancy

  • Abdominal pain and distension could be a presentation of ruptured ectopic pregnancy but occur only as early as 4-6 weeks of conception. Also a history of ovulation induction points more towards OHSS. However, ruptured ectopic or ovarian cyst remains to be the most important differential here.

Option C: Multifetal pregnancy causing uterine distension

  • A multifetal pregnancy does not cause pain or abdominal distension in early pregnancy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese woman with type 2 diabetes and hypertension presented in an outpatient clinic with the complaint of heavy menstrual bleeding. After the biopsy, microscopic examination reveals endometriod type of endometrial carcinoma. The most probable gene defect expected in this condition is:
questions.solution:
Option A: PTEN

  • This patient is diagnosed with an endometrioid type of endometrial cancer. Microscopic examination reveals proliferative endometrium with a variable degree of glandular complexity and cellular polymorphism, which confirms the diagnosis.
  • Endometrioid type of endometrial cancer is associated with PTEN gene mutation and is associated with a better prognosis.
  • It is the most common type of endometrial carcinoma histologically and of all uterine malignancies overall.
  • It is directly related to long-term estrogen exposure.
  • Risk factors include obesity, diabetes mellitus and hypertension.
  • The most common presentation is abnormal uterine bleeding.
  • It has 3 grades, mostly presents early, and shows a good prognosis.
  • Surgery and radiotherapy are the mainstays of the treatment.

Types of endometrial cancer:

Type 1(Endometrioid type) Type 2(Serous, clear type)
  • Associated with PTEN gene mutations
  • Good prognosis
  • Estrogen-dependent, develop in the background of endometrial hyperplasia
  • Develops in obese women
  • Associated with HTN, diabetes
  • Associated with P-53 gene mutations
  • Poor prognosis
  • Not estrogen-dependent, develop in the background of atrophic endometrium
  • Develops in thin women
  • Not associated with HTN, diabetes

Option B: p53 mutations

  • p53 is a tumour suppressor gene whose mutations lead to most cancers.
  • It is associated with non-endometrioid type endometrial cancer and Li-Fraumeni (SBLA) syndrome.

Option C: MSH2

  • MSH2 is a mismatch repair gene which is associated with hereditary non-polyposis colorectal carcinoma.

Option D: BRCA2

  • BRCA2 is a tumour suppressor gene which is associated with breast, ovarian, prostate and pancreatic cancers.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to Gynecology OPD with complaints of abdominal distention and pain over the previous 3 months. Her physical examination reveals an abdominal mass without shifting dullness and bilateral adnexal masses. Her digital rectal examination reveals the presence of induration in the rectal pouch. Her breast examination and recent mammogram are normal. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Option A: Serous cystadenocarcinomas of both ovaries

  • The patient is a 68-year-old woman with abdominal distention, pain with bilateral adnexal masses, and induration in the rectal pouch. Bilateral adnexal masses in postmenopausal must raise suspicion of epithelial ovarian cancers. Most common of which are serous cystadenomas/ carcinomas. Induration in the rectal pouch suggests locally advanced disease and favors a malignancy.
  • The picture below shows the Serous cystadenocarcinoma.

  • Serous cystadenocarcinomas are the most common malignant tumors of ovaries and the most common tumors associated with a bilateral origin.
  • The peak incidence of invasive epithelial ovarian cancer is about 60. About 30% of ovarian neoplasms in postmenopausal women are malignant.
  • Mostly unilocular
  • Bilateral in >50%
  • Mostly malignant
  • Surface growth present
  • Psammoma Bodies are present in 40-45%

​​​​​​​

Option B: Krukenberg’s tumors of the ovaries

  • Krukenberg’s tumors are also bilateral but are associated with another primary malignancy (most commonly gastric carcinoma) and are less common than epithelial tumors.
  • Hence, it is not the correct option.

Option C: Malignant ascites

  • It is ruled out as there is no shifting dullness. Please note that serous cystadenocarcinomas do present with ascites quite commonly.
  • So, it is a false statement.

Option D: Meig's syndrome

  • Meig's syndrome is ascites and pleural effusion associated with fibroma of the ovary, which is again ruled out due to the absence of ascites.
  • So, it is not a true option.

questions.text: A 22-year-old girl presents to the OPD with moderate acne. She gives a history of sudden gain in weight. On further questioning, she also has irregular menses. The doctor chooses to prescribe her a combination pill for the regularization of her cycles. Which of the following pill content would additionally help with her acne?
questions.solution:
Option D: Cyproterone acetate

  • Androgen excess—hirsutism, acne and alopecia—are very common and distressing symptoms in women of reproductive age. This patient most likely has PCOD.
  • The anti-androgen cyproterone acetate (2 mg) and Ethinyl estradiol (35 µg) are proven effective in managing symptoms of both hyperandrogenism and menstrual abnormalities.
  • CA should never be taken in reproductive-age women without the combined use of oral birth control pills.
  • Cyproterone acetate (CA) acts as a strong anti-androgen and a weak progestin.
  • This takes a full cycle of the hair follicle to start showing results, around 8-10 months.
  • The patient is also likely to have a relapse of symptoms if stopped. Hence long-term use is the protocol.

Option A: Oral Isotretinoin

  • This drug is used for the treatment of acne.
  • But it is not available as combined contraceptive pills. It has no role in irregular cycles.

Option B: Oral Acitretin

  • This drug is used for the treatment of acne.
  • But it is not available as combined contraceptive pills. It has no role in irregular cycles.

Option C: Oral Minocycline

  • This drug is used for the treatment of acne.
  • But it is not available as combined contraceptive pills. It has no role in irregular cycles.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented to the gynaecological clinic with a complaint of pelvic pain and menorrhagia for the past 8 months. She is diagnosed with endometrial cancer. Her hysterectomy is done immediately, looking at her condition and to do staging. Her anaemia is first corrected by blood transfusions preoperatively, following which the surgery is done. The catheter is left in situ for 7 days post-operatively because of extensive bladder dissection during surgery. This patient presents with purulent discharge from her wound after 7 days of surgery. Which of the following is LEAST likely risk factor related to her presenting condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Use of blood transfusion.

  • Blood transfusion done in this question was to correct her anemia, which would improve her immunity, surgery tolerance, wound healing and reduce risk of infection.
  • Patient-related factors increasing the risk of an SSI include:
    • Pre-existing infection or smoking history
    • Malnutrition
    • Obesity
    • Low serum albumin
    • Elderly
    • Immunosuppression (diabetes mellitus, irradiation)

Option A: Surgery for malignancy.

  • Malignancies are characteristically making a woman more prone to infections because of cachexia and Immuno-suppression with malignancies.

Option B: Age > 50 yrs.

  • Older women will have poor surgery tolerance and more susceptibility to infections due to reduced  immunity.

Option C: Urinary catheterization > 7 days.

  • Catheterisation may introduce infection in the bladder and should be done only when necessary, with proper aseptic technique. Prolonged catheterisation increases the risk of catheter-associated UTIs.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with the first episode of heavy vaginal bleeding with the passage of clots over the past 2 days. Her past cycles have been delayed, with normal flow, and lasted 3-4 days. She had a USG two months back for irregular cycles, which showed a simple ovarian cyst of 3 cm. Which is the next most appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
Option B: Urine pregnancy test

  • Pregnancy remains the first cause of abnormal uterine bleeding to be ruled out in a woman of reproductive age group.
  • Since the patient here has irregular cycles, she still could likely have been conceived without her knowledge.
  • Doing a UPT (urine pregnancy test) and a pelvic examination is important to rule out early pregnancy bleeding.
  • After UPT, other tests can be done to exclude other pathologies.

 

Option A:  OCP for 3-6 cycles + tranexamic acid

  • OCP may be given after ruling out pregnancy for regularizing her cycles, which may be anovulatory and help to resolve the simple ovarian cyst. Tranexamic acid can also be used to stop the heavy bleeding in the current cycle.

 

Option C: Ovarian cystectomy

  • A simple asymptomatic ovarian cyst of 3 cm size does not require a cystectomy. It can just be followed up.

 

Option D: Dilation and curettage

  • It may be required in case of an incomplete abortion after confirmation of pregnancy with UPT and ultrasound.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G2P1 presents to the outpatient department at the 37th week of gestation. She has no complaints, and her pregnancy has been uncomplicated till now. History is significant for previous LSCS. She feels normal fetal activity, and her antenatal investigations are within normal limits. CTG is unremarkable. Pelvic examination shows a closed os and clinically inadequate pelvis. Which of the following is the best step in the delivery management of the patient?

choices.text: Wait for spontaneous labor with a trial of labor in a tertiary care setup only
Elective LSCS at 39th week or emergency LSCS at the onset of labor

questions.solution:
Option C: Elective LSCS at 39th week or emergency LSCS at the onset of labour

  • An inadequate pelvis in previous LSCS is a contraindication for the trial of labour or vaginal birth after cesarean section (VBAC).
  • However, since the patient is currently not in labour, an elective cesarean section can be planned later at 39 weeks or an emergency cesarean section at the onset of labour, whichever is earlier.

 Contraindications of VBAC

          • previous classical LSCS
          • previous > 2LSCS
          • previous uterine rupture
          • cephalopelvic disproportion
          • malpresentation
          • obstetric indications
          • non-consenting patient
          • lack of facilities for emergency LSCS round the clock

Timing of ERCS (Elective repeat LSCS)

  • Risk of perinatal death with ERCS (Elective Repeat Caesarean section) is extremely low, but there is a small increase in perinatal respiratory morbidity when ERCS is performed before 39 weeks.
  • This morbidity can be reduced with pre-op steroids.

Option A: Elective LSCS

  • An elective cesarean must be planned at 39 weeks or later unless there is any other obstetric indication for early termination.

Option B: Wait for spontaneous labour with a trial of labour in tertiary care setup only

  • Trial of labour in clinically inadequate pelvis is contraindicated due to cephalopelvic disproportion.

Option D: Induction of labour now

  • This patient is at the 37th week of gestation and has an inadequate pelvis, due to which labour induction cannot be given. The patient can wait till the 39th week, and due to the inadequacy of the pelvis, an elective cesarean section must be planned.

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman, G3P2, at 16 weeks of gestation, comes to the clinic for a routine antenatal visit. She had cervical conisation for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) 7 years ago. Her previous two pregnancies ended as preterm deliveries. Her physical examination is unremarkable. The length of the cervix is 2 cm on transvaginal ultrasound. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient to prevent preterm birth?

choices.text: Serial measurement of cervical length via transvaginal ultrasound until 24 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
Option A: Cerclage

  • Cerclage and progesterone injection is the best treatment option in this patient (short cervix with a history of preterm delivery) to prevent preterm birth.
  • A cervix is said to be short if:
  • The length of the cervix is 2 cm or less, with no history of preterm delivery
  • The length of the cervix is 2.5 cm or less, with a history of preterm delivery
  • Cervical length is measured with the help of transvaginal ultrasound during 2nd trimester.
  • The treatment options to prevent a preterm birth depends upon the length of the cervix and the history of preterm delivery in the woman.
  • No history of preterm delivery:
  • Normal cervical length= Routine care
  • Short cervical length= Vaginal progesterone administration
  • History of preterm delivery:
  • Normal cervical length= Progesterone injection with serial measurement of cervical length via transvaginal ultrasound until 24 weeks of gestation
  • Short cervical length= Progesterone injection, cerclage, and serial measurement of cervical length via transvaginal ultrasound until 24 weeks of gestation
  • Cervical cerclage is a procedure to close the opening of the cervix with stitches to prevent preterm birth.
  • This procedure is most commonly performed between the 13th to 16th week of gestation. The stitches are normally removed at the 37th week of pregnancy.
  • Intrauterine fetal demise, active vaginal bleeding, preterm prelabour rupture of membrane, and active preterm labour are contraindications to cervical cerclage.

Option B: Routine care

  • Normal cervical length with no history of preterm delivery is managed with routine care.

Option C: Vaginal progesterone

  • Vaginal progesterone administration is the treatment of choice in case of a short cervix with no history of preterm delivery.

Option D: Serial measurement of cervical length via transvaginal ultrasound until 24 weeks of gestation

  • Serial measurement of cervical length is the preferred management in the case of normal cervical length with a history of preterm delivery.

questions.text:
A 26-yrs-old patient has had three consecutive spontaneous abortions early in her pregnancy. As part of an evaluation for this problem, the least useful tests would be


	Hysterosalpinogram
	Chromosomal analysis of the couple
	Testing for TORCH infections
	Endometrial biopsy in the luteal phase
	Postcoital test
questions.solution:
Option C : A major cause of spontaneous abortions in the first trimester is chromosomal abnormalities; however, the causes of losses in the second trimester are more likely to be anatomical in origin for which an HSG (1) can be done, better investigation would be a laparo-hysteroscopy (4). Chromosomal testing (2) is also useful as chromosomal causes can also cause second trimester abortions.

Causes of recurrent second trimester abortions

  • Anatomical : uterine anomalies like septate, bicornuate, and cervical incompetence : most common
  • Maternal disease : DM, HTN, Hypothyroidism, SLE
  • Drug abuse: cocaine, smoking
  • Inherited or acquired thrombophilias
  • Chromosomal
  • Infections : may cause T2 losses but not recurrent losses

(3) A postcoital test is useful for couples who cannot conceive, due to abnormal sperm cervical interaction, but does not address post-conception losses.

(5) TORCH infections are known causes of early spontaneous abortions, however an infection would not cause abortions recurrently and hence evaluation for TORCH infections is not required for recurrent pregnancy losses

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida presents with mild abdominal pain for one week. Her last menstrual period was 6 weeks. An ultrasound reveals a 2.5 cm gestational sac in the left fallopian tube. All of the following drugs may be used for medical management of this patient except?
questions.solution:
Option C : Misoprostol is a prostaglandin and its efficiency is not proven beyond a reasonable doubt as far as management of an ectopic pregnancy is concerned.

Options A, B, D : Drugs used for Medical Management of Ectopic Pregnancy -

  • Methotrexate
  • Actinomycin D
  • KCl
  • Mifepristone

Criteria for medical management of ectopic pregnancy :

  1. Patient should be hemodynamically stable (unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy).
  2. Foetal cardiac activity absent (presence of cardiac activity is a relative contraindication).
  3. β-hCG levels <5,000 mIU/mL (levels > 5,000 mIU/mL is a relative contraindication).
  4. Gestational sac diameter <4 cm.
  5. Free fluid in POD <100 mL.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the emergency department at 9 weeks of pregnancy with excessive nausea and vomiting. She has been avoiding spicy and oily food and has been taking oral antiemetics with only transient relief. The patient reveals that despite nausea and vomiting, she is eating well and is staying hydrated. Which of these is NOT a compelling reason for hospitalization in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Vomiting > 5 times a day

Indications for hospitalization in case of nausea and vomiting during pregnancy (whenever the patient can be diagnosed with hyperemesis gravidarum) are:

  • Intractable vomiting and inability to tolerate oral fluids
  • Associated obstetric complications
  • Deranged liver or renal functions
  • Dehydration, ketonuria, electrolyte disturbance
  • Coagulopathy

 

  • So the patient should be admitted to the hospital when she is diagnosed with hyperemesis gravidum, in which there is a possibility of ketoacidosis due to constant vomiting and inability to take food. 
    • The inability to eat results in the production of ketones by the metabolism of stored fats. The body uses these fats to meet its energy requirements and consequently causes ketosis. These ketones are then excreted into the urine resulting in ketonuria.  
    • There is also an electrolyte imbalance in hyperemesis gravidum which can cause hypokalemia. It reflects in ECG as inverted T waves and prolonged QT and PR intervals.
    • A patient vomiting 5 times a day but is eating well and is able to stay hydrated does not require admission.

Option A: Inability to tolerate orally

  • A patient unable to tolerate oral food intake should be admitted to the hospital.

Option C: Electrolyte imbalance

  • A patient with electrolyte imbalance as a result of hyperemesis gravidarum should be admitted to the hospital.

Option D: Ketonuria

  • A patient with ketonuria as a result of hyperemesis gravidarum should be admitted to the hospital.

questions.text: A 20-year-old primigravida, at 33 weeks of gestation, is brought to the emergency department complaining of an absence of fetal movement for the last two days. She didn't receive any antenatal care or pregnancy check-up except a USG at 32 weeks, suggesting a growth retarded fetus corresponding to 30 weeks of fetal age. Her vitals are normal on examination, and the physician advises an antenatal doppler scan to assess fetal status. Which of the following umbilical artery Doppler findings is the most significant indication for termination of the pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Option C: Reversal of flow

  • Reversal of blood flow during diastole is suggestive of imminent fetal death.
  • The earliest sign of fetal compromise is a raised S/D ratio in the Umblical artery flow.
