  • An absence of diastolic flow indicates severe fetal compromise, and it requires intensive fetal monitoring with NST and frequent doppler up to 34 weeks or occurrence of reversal of flow (whichever is earlier), after which pregnancy should be terminated.
  • A reversal of diastolic flow is indicative of imminent fetal death (fetus is expected to die within 24-48 hours), requiring urgent termination, and therefore reversal occurring before lung maturity carries poor chances of fetal survival.

Option A: Increased S/D ratio

  • It is the earliest sign of fetal compromise
  • Management involves frequent fetal monitoring with doppler and NSTs

Option B: Absent diastolic flow

  • It signifies severely worsening fetal condition, but pregnancy can be continued with intensive fetal monitoring with NST until 34 weeks or reversal of flow occurs.

Option D: Normal S/D ratio

  • A normal S/D ratio assures good fetal condition; therefore, pregnancy must not be terminated.

questions.text: A group of researchers were conducting a study on the effects of infections in pregnancy on the developing fetus. They reviewed medical records of pregnant women from different maternity hospitals. An association was found between maternal infection and congenital fetal defects. It was observed that a newborn is born with cerebral cortical atrophy, bone and limb defects, cutaneous scarring and chorioretinitis when the mother develops an infection in the first trimester of pregnancy. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of these congenital anomalies in the newborn?
questions.solution:
Option B: Maternal varicella infection.

  • During pregnancy, if any infection occurs in the mother, it may harm the developing fetus. The severity of fetal involvement depends upon the time of gestation at which the infection in the mother occurs.
  • Varicella zoster virus, or human herpes virus-3, is a double-stranded DNA virus. It spreads via respiratory secretions and contact with a vesicular fluid.
  • It can cause varicella-zoster (chickenpox, shingles), encephalitis and pneumonia. The most common complication is postherpetic neuralgia.
  • The virus remains latent in the dorsal root ganglion of the trigeminal nerve and can cause herpes zoster ophthalmicus.
  • Pregnant women should be asked if they had chicken pox at the initial booking visit. If they do not have chicken pox, they should avoid contact with it during pregnancy, and if exposure does occur, they need to inform the doctor as soon as possible.
  • Congenital varicella syndrome is characterized by:
    • Bony defects: limb hypoplasia
    • Skin: cutaneous dermatome scarring
    • Eye defects: microphthalmia, chorioretinitis, and cataracts
    • Neurologic abnormalities: microcephaly, cortical atrophy, mental retardation, dysfunction of bowel and bladder sphincters.

The risk of congenital malformations is more when the infection occurs in the first trimester of pregnancy.

  • Women with chickenpox should avoid contact with other pregnant women and neonates until the lesions have crusted. The current recommendation states that 800mg acyclovir 5 times a day for 7 days should be given if they present within 24 hours of presentation of rash and are more than 20 weeks of gestation. Acyclovir is also given before 20 weeks of gestation. VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once the rash has developed.
  • Elective delivery should be avoided until 5-7 days after the onset of maternal rash to allow for Passover transfer of maternal antibodies to the developing fetus.
  • The varicella vaccine should not be given in pregnancy as it can cause congenital varicella syndrome in the developing fetus.
  • If the mother has shingles, the baby is protected from infection with varicella zoster virus by maternal antibodies, and no contact precaution is required.

 

Option A: Maternal rubella virus infection.

  • It leads to congenital rubella syndrome in the newborn, which is characterized by cataracts, hepatosplenomegaly, deafness, petechial rash, jaundice and congenital heart defects (patent ductus arteriosus).

Option C: Maternal cytomegalovirus infection.

  • Maternal cytomegalovirus infection leads to deafness, petechial rash, chorioretinitis, seizures, periventricular calcifications and ventriculomegaly in the newborn.

Option D: Maternal Toxoplasma gondii infection.

  • Maternal toxoplasmosis can cause chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications in the newborn.

questions.text: A 33-year-old pregnant woman presents to the antenatal clinic at 33 weeks of gestation complaining of itching all over her body. There is no history of fever or rashes. The physician rules out any underlying skin condition. Lab tests show elevated alkaline phosphatase. Which of the following is the most appropriate drug therapy?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ursodeoxycholic acid

  • This patient presenting with itching and elevated alkaline phosphatase in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy with no history of fever and rash likely has intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy.
  • The appropriate drug for this condition is ursodeoxycholic acid. It decreases bile salt levels and relieves pruritis.

Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy

  • The onset of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is usually in the third trimester.
  • It presents with pruritis, icterus or both.
  • Lab findings are:
    • Sr. bilirubin level <5 mg/dL
    •  Minimal or no elevation in transaminases.
    • Alkaline phosphatase levels are elevated.
  • Histopathology: Mild cholestasis with bile plugs in the hepatocytes of the centrilobular regions.
  • Ursodeoxycholic acid & Cholestyramine acid are used for pruritis. Ursodeoxycholic acid decreases bile salt levels and relieves pruritus. It can also decrease the chance of fetal complications.
  • Termination should be planned at 38 weeks as it is associated with increased risk fetal mortality if allowed to progress beyond 38 weeks.

Option B: Dexamethasone

  • Corticosteroids are not beneficial for intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy. Dexamethasone will worsen the condition by increasing the biliary excretion of cholesterol.

Option C: Antihistamines

  • The patient has no history of fever and rash. The pruritis is not because of an allergic reaction. So, antihistamines are not recommended

Option D: Antibiotics

  • This patient has no evidence of a bacterial infection. There is no indication for antibiotics.

questions.text: Caretakers bring a newborn delivered at home to assess for an abnormality suspected in his lower spine. The paediatrician examines it and finds that the baby's sacrum is hypoplastic. Which of the following antenatal history in the mother should be looked for?
questions.solution:
Option A: Maternal diabetes

  • Sacral agenesis/Caudal regression syndrome is the most specific anomaly associated with maternal diabetes.

Common and specific defects in the fetus of a diabetic mother:

  • The most common anatomical defects of babies born to mothers with overt diabetes Mellitus are cardiac: the most specific is the transposition of great arteries.
  • Sacral agenesis is a rare defect, much lesser than cardiac defects. It is a specific structural defect seen in newborns of overt diabetic mothers. 
  • However, compared to a transposition of great vessels, this is much less common.

Option B: Maternal hypothyroidism

  • Maternal hypothyroidism is associated with cretinism in an infant.
  • It is not the cause of sacral agenesis.

Option C: Maternal hypertension

  • Maternal hypertension is not associated with sacral agenesis.
  • It can cause low birth weight and preterm delivery.

Option D: Maternal cardiac disease

  • Maternal cardiac disease is not associated with sacral agenesis.
  • Diabetes is the strongest risk factor for sacral agenesis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 12 weeks of gestation, presents to the obstetric outpatient department for her antenatal visit. Her ultrasound scan reveals twin pregnancies and a nuchal translucency of 2.2 and 2.8 mm in the fetuses. As her pregnancy progresses, she gets her quadruple marker test done at 17 weeks of gestation, which suggests deranged biochemical markers. Her history reveals no risk factor for chromosomal anomalies. Which of the following is the correct explanation of her deranged biomarker findings?

choices.text: She is at a very high risk of having aneuploidy as the quadruple marker is positive, and, a normal nuchal translucency is less significant in twins
Nuchal translucency is not accurate here as it should have been done at 9-11 weeks
In twin gestation, nuchal translucency is more accurate than biochemical markers; hence, the risk of aneuploidy is less
Both tests are deranged and suggestive of aneuploidy risk

questions.solution:
Option C: In twin gestation, nuchal translucency is more accurate than biochemical markers; hence, the risk of aneuploidy is less.

  • Nuchal translucency (NT) is now appreciated as a sensitive marker for Down syndrome and other aneuploidies between 10 and 13 weeks.

  • Along with serum markers, it is a very reliable test to detect aneuploidy in the first trimester.
  • However, in twins and triplets, this is the only reliable indicator since the biochemical parameters are not reliable markers with multiples as they vary with the number of fetuses.
  • Other factors influencing results are :
  • Maternal age
  • History of diabetes
  • Gestational age.

Option A: She is at a very high risk of having aneuploidy as the quadruple marker is positive, and a normal nuchal translucency is less significant in twins.

  • Increased nuchal translucency and positive quadruple test are highly suggestive of Down’s Syndrome.
  • Normal Nuchal translucency is more significant than a quadruple marker in the case of twins and triplets.
  • Quadruple marker tests for the following biomarkers:
  • Free b HCG
  • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
  • Unconjugated estriol
  • Inhibin A

Option B: Nuchal translucency is not accurate here as it should have been done at 9-11 weeks.

  • It is measured between 11- 14 weeks of gestation when the crown-rump length measures 38-84 mm.

Option D: Both tests are deranged and suggestive of aneuploidy risk.

  • Normal value of NT is up to 3 mm, which is normal here for both fetuses.
  • When the nuchal translucency increases, the risk for fetal aneuploidy and various structural anomalies, including heart defects, is significantly elevated.

questions.text: In a 33 year old woman who conceived with IVF, an USG at 12 weeks shows a single developing fetus. The previous USG at 6 weeks showed a twin pregnancy. The patient has unremarkable medical history, takes only vitamins. Vital signs and physical examination are normal. What should be the next appropriate step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Advice medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) as the second twin is at increased risk of aborting
Continue pregnancy like a normal singleton pregnancy
Watch for coagulation defects in the mother

questions.solution:
Option B: Continue pregnancy like a normal singleton pregnancy

  

  • The patient presented with clinical features of vanishing twin syndrome.
  • Vanishing twin is one of the types of miscarriages that can happen during multiple pregnancies.
  • It may occur in up to 1 out of 8 twin pregnancies.
  • It occurs when one of the embryos stops growing, and its tissues eventually get absorbed by the mother or the surviving embryo.
  • Therefore, multiple pregnancies observed at the initial ultrasound cannot be seen on follow-up ultrasounds.
  • The cause of vanishing twin syndrome could be chromosomal abnormalities in the vanished twin or improper implantation of the umbilical cord.
  • When a twin dies in the first trimester, it has no significant effect on the mother or the surviving fetus.
  • The pregnancy should therefore be continued as a normal singleton pregnancy.
  • Fetus compressus is a process of fetal degeneration and maceration seen in slightly more advanced twin pregnancies.
  • In some cases, the fetus eventually becomes more flattened and mummified, known as fetus papyraceous.

Option A: Advice medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) as the second twin is at increased risk of aborting

  • The chances of the demise of the second twin when the first one dies at such early gestation are minimal.
  •  Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) must not be advised.

Option C: Watch for coagulation defects in the mother

  • Coagulation defects are seen after fetal demise at later gestation when thromboplastin is released from the dead fetal tissue if left for a prolonged duration in utero.

Option D: Chorionic villous sampling

  • Chorionic villous sampling is not indicated here.
  • It will only increase the chances of abortion of the second fetus.

questions.text: A 29 year old woman is on HCG follow up after her previous pregnancy with complete mole was terminated by suction and evacuation. All of the following features are high risk factors for the development of choriocarcinoma except:

choices.text: Presence of bilateral theca lutein cysts of ovary.

questions.solution:
Option C : Following are the risk factors for the development of choriocarcinoma:

  • Increased hCG levels(>105)at the time of diagnosis
  • Uterine size big
  • >6 cm theca lutein cyst

Features of thyrotoxicosis are not associated with increased risk of development of choriocarcinoma.

Option A, B, D : All are associated with increased risk of development of choriocarcinoma.

questions.text: A P1L1 woman with previous normal delivery, presents with irregular bleeding and uterine mass. The HCG is 8,120 mIU/mL. Biopsy reveals trophoblast tissue with absent chorionic villi with local invasion. The patient is now being evaluated for spread of disease and prognosis. Which of the following is TRUE about the patient's condition?

choices.text: Most common site of metastasis is vagina
Presence of Lung metastasis classifies as stage 4 GTN
This HCG value has a good prognosis
Prognosis is good as previous pregnancy is a full term delivery

questions.solution:
Option C : BHCG <10,000 carries good prognosis.

PROGNOSTIC SCORING 0 1 2 4
1. Age <=39 >39    
2. Antecedent pregnancy mole abortion term pregnancy  
3. Interval (pregnancy and start of CT) <4 4-6 7-12 >12
4. Hcg <10,000 1000 - 10,000 10,000 - 1 lakh >1 lakh
5. Blood group   O or A B or AB  
6. Largest tumor size <3 3-5 >5  
7. Site of metastasis   spleen, kidney GIT Brain, liver
8. No. of metastasis   1-3 4-8 >8
9. Prior chemotherapy     1 drug >=2 drugs

Option A : Most common site of metastasis in choriocarcinoma is lung, which is classified as stage 3.

Option B : Lung involvement in choriocarcinoma is classified as stage III and not IV.

Option D :GTN following term pregnancy carries worse prognosis than that following a molar pregnancy or an abortion.

questions.text: A 6-month-baby presented with recurrent seizures and developmental delay. On examination, there was alopecia and scaly skin rashes. Investigations revealed metabolic acidosis, elevated lactates and ketonuria. What could be the underlying enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
Option C: Multiple carboxylases

  • Multiple carboxylase deficiency affects all four carboxylases, i.e. pyruvate carboxylase, acetyl-CoA carboxylase, propionyl-CoA carboxylase, and 3-methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase.

  • The underlying disturbance of multiple carboxylase deficiency involves the metabolism of biotin.

  • It presents with perioral eruptions and alopecia with the presence of ketones and metabolic acidosis.

Option A: Phenylalanine hydroxylase

  • Phenylketonuria is an autosomal recessive disease caused by the deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase. 

  • The patient presents with blonde hair, fair skin, blue iris, microcephaly, mousy body odour, intellectual disability, convulsions, hypertonia, dental enamel changes, irritability, and tremors.

  • The treatment includes

    • A low phenylalanine diet is used

    • Adequate intake of tyrosine

  • The diagnosis of PKU is made via

    • Ferric chloride test: It turns a green colour when positive 

    • Guthrie’s bacterial inhibition test: It is the screening test for PKU

    • Increased levels of serum and urinary phenylalanine and its metabolites like phenyl acetate and phenylpyruvate are also diagnostic of PKU

    • Provocative protein meal tests also help in the diagnosis

Option B: Epimerase

  • Epimerase deficiency is a variant of classic galactosemia.

  • UDP-galactose epimerase deficiency results in similar clinical implications as classic galactosemia.

  • Ultimately, levels of galactose-1-phosphate reach toxic levels, and galactose may be alternatively reduced to its sugar alcohol form, galactitol causing similar clinical features.

  • A newborn with galactosemia seems healthy at birth, but within a few days or weeks, they lose their appetite and begin to vomit.

  • Failure to thrive, jaundice, hepatomegaly, infantile cataracts, intellectual impairment, amino acids and proteins in the urine, and oedema emerge after the newborn begins feeding.

Option D: Glucose 6 phosphatase

  • Von Gierke disease is an autosomal recessive deficiency of Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency.

  • Clinical signs include doll-like facies, severe fasting hypoglycemia, glycogen buildup in the liver and kidneys, elevated blood lactate, triglycerides, uric acid, hepatomegaly, and nephromegaly.

  • Treatment consists of taking glucose and cornstarch regularly and avoiding fructose and galactose.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents to the Gynaecology Department complaining of lower abdominal pain associated with vaginal bleeding for the last two days. She is primigravida and has gestational amenorrhea of 30 weeks. Her CTG shows decelerations suggestive of fetal distress. A newborn weighing 1000 g is born. The child is suffering from respiratory distress within 1 hour of birth. Which of the following is the diagnostic possibility?
questions.solution:
Option A: Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • The child was delivered at 30 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 1000g. The child is suffering from respiratory distress within 1 hour of the birth. Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is one of the causes of this presentation.
  • Diaphragmatic hernia is a congenital disability with a defect in the diaphragm, the large muscle that separates the thoracic cavity from the abdominal cavity.
  • Organs in the abdomen (such as intestines, stomach, and liver) can herniate through the hole in the diaphragm and upwards into the thorax, causing respiratory distress.
  • Causes of Respiratory distress that can present within the first 6 hours of life:
    • HMD
    • Transient Tachypnea of Newborn (TTN)
    • Congenital pneumonia
    • Pneumothorax
    • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH)
    • Pulmonary haemorrhage

Option B: Laryngomalacia

  • Laryngomalacia is a condition that results from a congenital disability in the larynx. The soft tissues of the larynx fall over the airway opening and partially block it.
  • This can result in stridor — a high-pitched sound on inspiration. It manifests after six months of age and outgrows by 24 months of life.
  • It does not cause respiratory distress at birth.

Option C: Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD)

  • It occurs in a neonate of Hyaline Membrane Disease treated with O2 & mechanical ventilation. It usually takes weeks to develop.

Option D: None of the above

  • The case mentioned above has respiratory distress in the first hour of life, and the cause can be a diaphragmatic hernia.

questions.text: A newborn with a gestational age of 34 weeks and a birth weight of 1600 grams has been managed in a warmer for the last 18 hours. On examination, the neonate is shivering and has a heart rate of 122 beats per minute and a respiratory rate of 60 breaths per minute. The child has an axillary temperature of <36.5° and a warm abdomen but cold extremities. What is the quick diagnosis that should be made in this clinical setting?
questions.solution:
Option C: Cold stress

  • Pre-term and low birth weight babies are more at risk of developing neonatal hypothermia.
  • The presence of shivering, a temperature of <36.5oC and a warm abdomen but cold peripheries suggest mild hypothermia. The cardio-respiratory systems are also in compensation.
  • Mild hypothermia is also called cold stress.
  • During mild hypothermia, the body stimulates the shivering mechanism and increases metabolism. Heat loss is also decreased by peripheral vasoconstriction.

Option A: Normal body temperature

  • In Fahrenheit, the normal core body temperature range is 95.8 to 99.3oF.
  • In Celsius, it is 36.5oC to 37.5oC.

Option B: Severe hypothermia

  • In severe hypothermia, body systems fail to function. The core temperature is < 32oC.
  • The patient is in a coma with fixed dilated pupils, apnoea and pulselessness.
  • Muscles also become stiff.

Option D: Shock

  • Clinical findings of tissue hypo-perfusion manifest it.
  • On examination, cold extremities, acrocyanosis, poor capillary refill, and tachycardia suggest the diagnosis of neonatal shock.

questions.text: A preterm neonate with low birth weight is kept in the neonatal ICU as the child's bilirubin levels are relatively high. He was given phototherapy and steroids for lung maturity as a treatment. While phototherapy was being given, his eyes were covered with a cotton pad, but a dark, greyish-brown skin discolouration was noticed after a few days. What could be the possible reason behind this colour change?
questions.solution:
Option A: Phototherapy

  • The bronze baby syndrome is a dark, greyish-brown skin discolouration mainly seen in infants with elevated conjugated bilirubin as an adverse effect of phototherapy. 
  • It is a benign condition.
  • Indications of phototherapy:
    • When bilirubin is 5mg below the exchange level and mainly hemolytic.
    • In hemolytic disease of the newborn during the wait for exchange transfusion.
    • Following the exchange, transfusion is to prevent further rise.
    • Prophylactic phototherapy is indicated in severely bruised infants.
  • Complications of phototherapy are:
    • Overheating and dehydration
    • Hypothermia
    • Skin rashes
    • Loose stools
    • Eye injury

  • Phototherapy is contraindicated in the presence of porphyria

 

Option B: Phenobarbitone

  • It is given to mothers just before birth to decrease the level of bilirubin in the infant.
  • This decreases the need for phototherapy.
  • This drug induces the activity of uridine-di- phosphate glucosyl transferase enzyme, which blunts the bilirubin rise in neonates.

Option C: Hemosiderosis

 

  • It is an excessive accumulation of iron in the tissues.
  • Hemosiderosis is caused by bleeding within an organ or red cell breakdown in the bloodstream.

Option D: Chloramphenicol

 

  • It is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections.
  • Its side effects include passage of loose green stools, bluish tone to the skin, and unusual tiredness or weakness.

questions.text: A preterm newborn was delivered after a C-section. On assessment, his APGAR score was 1; his birth weight was 1000 g. On Neonatal Resuscitation, HR < 100/min + no respirations → Positive pressure ventilation, no response with PPV →Endotracheal intubation, HR < 60/min → Chest compressions, no response to chest compressions → Epinephrine. What would be the ratio of chest compressions : positive pressure ventilation?
questions.solution:
Option B: 3:1

  • Chest compression: ventilation ratio used in neonatal resuscitation - 3:1
  • Components of NRP resuscitation include: (TABCD)
  • T temperature: Maintain between 36.5 and 37.5 C
  • Airway:
    • Sniffing position
    • Clear secretions if needed
  • Breathing:
    • Free flow O2 (maintain sats 91–95%),
    • PPV (40–60 breaths/min),
    • ETT
  • Circulation:
    • Chest compressions: Ventilation - 3:1 or 90:30;
    • Lower 1/3rd sternum;
    • 2 thumb technique preferred
  • Drugs:
    • Epinephrine,
    • Volume expanders
  • Algorithm states:
    • HR < 100/min + no respirations → Positive pressure ventilation.
    • No response with PPV →Endotracheal intubation.
    • HR < 60/min→Chest compressions.
    • No response to chest compressions → Epinephrine.

Option A: 2:1

  • Compression in neonates can be done with two fingers.
  • The compression should be 30 compressions at the rate of 2 compressions per second (2:1).

Option C: 4:1

  • During the compression, hold the baby's head to avoid dropping the chin.
  • There should be two compressions per second, not four compressions per second.

Option D: 5:1

  • During the compression, the chest should be pushed down about one-third.
  • Five compressions per second (5:1) is not indicated in neonates

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents at the clinic with a complaint of a cough persisting for 1 month, a low-grade fever, night sweats, and failure to thrive. The medical history is significant. However, the family history is positive for a recent diagnosis of tuberculosis in the grandfather. The chest X-ray of the child given below suggests which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option D: Primary tuberculosis

  • Chest X-Ray showing lung parenchymal lesion with enlarged hilar lymph nodes in a child with a persistent cough, fever, night sweats and failure to thrive with a significant history of contact with tuberculosis suggestive of ‘Primary Tuberculosis’.

  • In most cases, the infection becomes localized, and a caseating granuloma forms (tuberculoma), which usually eventually calcifies and is then known as a Ghon lesion or Ghon focus.

  • Ghon focus plus hilar lymphadenopathy is called Ghon complex.

Option A: Pleural efusion

  • Pleural effusions are abnormal accumulations of fluid in the pleural space.

  • The X-ray finding of pleural effusion is blunting of costophrenic angles and cardiophrenic angles.

Option B: Miliary tuberculosis

  • Miliary tuberculosis is a life-threatening type of TB that occurs when a large number of bacteria travel through the bloodstream and spread throughout the body.

  • It usually affects the lungs, but almost any organ can be involved.

Option C: Cavitation

  • Cavitation is uncommon in primary TB, seen only in 10%-30% of cases.

  • The above-mentioned X-ray is more suggestive of tuberculous granuloma rather than cavitation.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child who has received one dose of DTP and OPV at 2 months of age. What will be your next immunisation plan?

choices.text: Restart the immunisation schedule as per age
Measles, BCG, a booster dose of DPT and OPV
Measles, a booster dose of DPT and OPV
BCG, 2nd dose of DPT and OPV

questions.solution:
Option C: Measles, a booster dose of DPT and OPV

  • For catch-up immunisation, vaccines are to be given on the first visit:
    • 1 dose of all the vaccines the child should have received until now, but did not receive, are to be given, including Measles, OPV & DPT.
    • As this child has already received DPT & OPV, a booster dose of these is recommended.
    • BCG may be given with other live vaccines on the same day, but as per the national immunisation schedule, catch-up for BCG is recommended till 12 months of age only.

Option A: Restart the immunisation schedule as per the age

  • For catch-up immunisation, vaccines are to be given on the first visit:
    • 1 dose of all the vaccines the child should have received until now, but did not receive, are to be given, including Measles, OPV & DPT.
    • As this child has already received DPT & OPV, a booster dose of these is recommended now.
    • BCG may be given with other live vaccines on the same day, but as per the national immunisation schedule, catch-up immunisation for BCG is recommended till 12 months of age only.
  • Restarting the immunisation schedule as per age is not the correct option.

Option B: Measles, BCG, a booster dose of DPT and OPV

  • For catch-up immunisation, vaccines are to be given on the first visit:
    • 1 dose of all the vaccines the child should have received until now, but did not receive, are to be given, including Measles, OPV & DPT.
    • As this child has already received DPT & OPV, a booster dose of these is recommended now.
    • BCG may be given with other live vaccines on the same day, but as per the national immunisation schedule, catch-up immunisation for BCG is recommended till 12 months of age only.
  • Measles, BCG, a booster dose of DPT and OPV is not the correct option.

Option D: BCG, 2nd dose of DPT and OPV

  • For catch-up immunisation, vaccines to be given on the first visit:
    • 1 dose of all the vaccines the child should have received until now, but did not receive, are to be given, including Measles, OPV & DPT.
    • As this child has already received DPT & OPV, booster dose immunisations are recommended.
    • BCG may be given with other live vaccines on the same day, but as per the national immunisation schedule, catch-up immunisation for BCG is recommended till 12 months of age only.
  • BCG, 2nd dose of DPT and OPV is not the next option.

questions.text:
A one-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to concerns about poor weight gain and difficulty feeding. On examination, the pediatrician notes that the infant is tachypneic and has a mild cyanotic hue. Auscultation reveals a widely split S2 and an ejection systolic murmur at the left sternal border. The infant's oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. A chest X-ray is given in the image. An echocardiogram is performed, which shows an anomaly, and the right atrium and ventricle are enlarged. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?



What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Return

  • This patient presenting with cyanosis, respiratory failure, and fixed split S2(due to ASD) is most likely suffering from TAPVR.
  • All pulmonary veins are draining into systemic circulation instead of the left atrium in TAPVR. It is usually associated with heterotaxy syndromes.
  • Chest X-ray for TAPVR has a snowman or figure of 8 appearance as shown in the given X-ray.
  • Treatment is surgery regardless of the severity of the disease.

Option A: Tetralogy of Fallot

  • TOF presents with cyanosis, which gets better with squatting position.
  • The patient presents with characteristic "tet spells" and a harsh holosystolic murmur at the sternal border on auscultation.
  • Chest X-ray shows a characteristic boot-shaped heart, not a "figure of 8" appearance. In addition, this patient's cyanosis did not get better with putting the patient in a knee-chest position. Therefore, TOF is a less likely diagnosis for this patient.

Option B: Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

  • TGA is caused by failure of spiralling of the aorticopulmonary septum.
  • The patient presents with postnatal cyanosis, tachypnea, and a single loud S2.
  • Chest X-ray for TGA shows an Egg on side appearance, not a snowman appearance as in TAPVR.
  • The X-ray given in the question shows a "snowman appearance". Therefore, this diagnosis is less likely.

Option C: Tricuspid Atresia

  • Tricuspid atresia is a cyanotic heart disease characterised by the absence of the tricuspid valve.
  • The patient has a hypoplastic right ventricle and right atrial dilation.
  • Tricuspid atresia is the only cyanotic heart disease presenting with left axis deviation on ECG.
  • Chest X-ray of tricuspid atresia is nonspecific and shows cardiomegaly.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy presents to a pediatrician with difficulty breathing for the past few hours. For the past few days, he has had low-grade fevers, runny nose, and barking cough. On examination, there is audible inspiratory stridor. Lungs are clear to auscultation. He does not appear to be in acute distress. Chest X-ray is performed as shown below:



He is started on symptomatic treatment, and his symptoms improve in a few days. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

  • Laryngotracheobronchitis, also known as croup, is a laryngeal infection commonly seen in the pediatric population.
  • The parainfluenza virus is the most common cause.
  • Croup is characterized by inflammation of the larynx and upper airways.
  • It presents with a seal-like barking cough, sore throat, hoarseness, biphasic stridor, and steeple sign (Inverted V configuration of subglottis due to airway narrowing) on anteroposterior radiographs of soft tissue neck.
  • It is treated with symptomatic treatment, cool mist, and a single steroid dose.
  • Nebulized epinephrine can be considered for moderate to severe croup.

Option B: Acute epiglottitis

This is false because:

  • Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency.
  • It presents acutely with severe symptoms such as high-grade fever, difficulty breathing, stridor, and tripod positioning.
  • It is diagnosed based on clinical presentation and imaging (thumbprint sign on lateral neck X-ray).
  • It warrants immediate securing of the airway alongside IV antibiotics.

Option C: Acute laryngitis
This is false because:

  • Acute laryngitis is a mild and self-limiting condition that typically lasts 3-7 days.
  • The most common cause is viral upper respiratory tract infections.
  • It presents with voice changes, vocal fatigue, and a dry cough.

Option D: TB laryngitis

This is false because:

  • TB laryngitis is an uncommon condition.
  • It can be seen in the later stages of TB infection, characterized by tubercular nodule-like growths in the larynx.

questions.text: A 35 years old male came to the E.N.T. outpatient department with complaints of fluctuating hearing loss and experienced a sudden onset of spinning sensations and imbalance associated with a ringing in her left ear. The patient also reports progressive left-sided hearing loss and is unable to follow conversations in noisy surroundings. On physical examination patient also complained of hearing the same sound in two different frequencies. There is horizontal nystagmus to the right. Which of the following test is confirmatory for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Electrocochleography

  • Electrocochleography-confirmatory test for Meniere's disease measures summating potential (S.P.) vs. action potential (A.P).
  • The above clinical features are seen in the case of Meniere’s disease.
  •  In Meniere's disease, males are affected more than females.
  • Usually, the disease is unilateral, but the other ear may be affected after a few years.
  • The exact cause of Ménière's disease is not yet known.
  • Episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and sense of fullness or pressure in the involved ear.

Meniere’s disease

  • Meniere’s disease is also known as endolymphatic hydrops.
  • Due to faulty reabsorption of endolymph by the endolymphatic sac.
  • Unilateral, episodic, fluctuating hearing loss.
  • Tullio’s phenomenon- Vertigo on hearing loud noises.
  • Diplacusis- hearing the same sound in 2 different frequencies.
  • Electrocochleography - confirmatory test for Meniere's disease- it measures summating potential (S.P.) vs action potential (A.P.).
  • In normal ear → SP < 30% AP.
  • In Meniere's disease → S.P.>70%-confirmatory.
  • →SP >45% - indicative

Option A: Tuning fork test

  • Meniere's test indicates sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Rinne's test is positive, absolute bone conduction is reduced in the affected ear, and Weber is lateralized to the better ear.

Option C: Tympanometry

  • It is an acoustic evaluation of the functioning and condition of the middle ear by creating a variation pressure in the middle canal.

Option D: Audiometry

  • P.T.A./pure tone audiometry:
  • There is sensorineural hearing loss.
  • In the early stages, lower frequencies are affected, and the curve is of rising type.
  • When higher frequencies are involved curve becomes flat or a falling type.
  • The amount of intensity that has to be raised above the normal level is a measure of the degree of hearing impairment at that frequency. It is charted in the form of a graph called audiogram. The threshold of bone conduction is a measure of cochlear function.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents to the ENT department with complaints of recurrent bony fractures and reduced hearing for one year. The patient is vitally stable. On further investigation, tympanometry showed the following findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Van der Hoeve syndrome

  • This is a case of van der Hoeve syndrome.
  • Van der Hoeve syndrome is the all-around variant of Lobstein's disease (late osteogenesis imperfecta) and is characterized by the simultaneous presence of osteoporosis, blue sclerae, and deafness.
  • The histological findings in the stapes of a patient suffering from this disease demonstrated that the actual stapes were abnormal, its crura being fragile and incomplete. In contrast, the footplate and its surroundings were expected compared to the observations in otosclerosis.

Type Implications
Type A Normal tympanogram/sensorineural hearing loss where conductive mechanism is normal.
Type B Flat curve, no change in compliance with pressure changes. Seen in fluid in the middle ear.
Type C Maximum compliance in negative pressure. Seen in eustachian tube obstruction.
Type As Compliance is lower at or near ambient air pressure. Seen in otosclerosis or malleus fixation.
Type Ad High compliance at or near ambient pressure. Seen in ossicular discontinuity.

Treatment:

  • Treatment of this disease consists of I.V. clodronate disodium at a dose of 300 mg daily in 250 ml saline solution for seven consecutive days.

Option A: Wardenburg syndrome

  • Wardenburg syndrome is characterized by the following:
    • Autosomal Dominant.
    • White forelock, heterochromia iridis, and depigmentation of the skin.
    • Dystopia Cantorum.
    • SNHL (unilateral or bilateral).

Option C: Usher’s syndrome

  • Usher's syndrome is characterized by the following:
    • Retinitis pigmentosa.
    • Night blindness.
    • SNHL.
    • Delayed onset.

Option D: Pendred syndrome

  • Pendred syndrome is characterized by the following:
    • The perchlorate discharge test shows a defect in the organic binding of iodine. Goitre (nontoxic) is usually evident before puberty.
    • SNHL.
    • Congenital onset.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents to the office with a complaint of nasal obstruction for the past two months. His mother also reports foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On nasal endoscopy, the obstruction caused by crust formation is noted. He denies any bad smell. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ozaena

Ozaena/ Atrophic rhinitis:

  • Klebsiella Ozaena is causative organism.
  • Seen in young females and people with low socioeconomic status.
  • Presents with iron deficiency/ multivitamin deficiency/ vitamin D deficiency.
  • The pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium is replaced by stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Clinical features
    • Most common:
      • Nasal obstruction (crust formation).
      • Foul smell.
      • Merciful anosmia.
    • Foul smell from the nose.
    • The patient himself is unaware of smell due to marked anosmia (merciful anosmia), which accompanies these degenerative changes.
    • The patient may complain of nasal obstruction despite unduly wide nasal chambers due to large crusts filling the nose.
    • Epistaxis may occur when the crusts are removed.

Treatment for Atrophic rhinitis

  • Steam inhalation, humidification, and saline nasal douching are useful in atrophic rhinitis.
  • A 25% glucose in glycerine solution restores moisture to the nasal mucosa.
  • The drops can be used several times a day and provide some relief to this distressing condition

Option A: Rhinitis medicamentosa

  • It is due to rebound congestion from decreased vasomotor tone, or increased parasympathetic activity, due to topical nasal decongestants or cocaine use.
  • Treatment is discontinuing topical decongestants; consider short-term oral corticosteroids (for weaning).
  • As our patient has no history of cocaine use or nasal decongestants over the past years, this is not the right answer.

Option B: Rhinosporidiosis

  • It is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and affects humans and animals.
  • As there is no granulomatous inflammation in this patient, thus option B is not right according to the given scenario.

Option D: Rhinoscleroma

It is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Gram-negative bacillus called Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis or Frisch bacillus. The disease runs through the following stages

  1. Atrophic stage: It resembles atrophic rhinitis and is characterized by foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge and crusting.
  2. Granulomatous stage: Granulomatous nodules form in nasal mucosa. There is also subdermal infiltration of the lower part of the external nose and upper lip, giving a "woody" feel. Nodules are painless and nonulcerative.
  3. Cicatricial stage: This causes stenosis of nares, distortion of the upper lip, adhesions in the nose, nasopharynx, and oropharynx. There may be subglottic stenosis with respiratory distress.
  4. As the patient's clinical features are inconsistent with Rhinoscleroma, "option D "can't be correct.

questions.text: A 50-year-old presents to the clinic with a growth involving the right nasal cavity invading bone of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus, medial wall of orbit & ethmoid sinuses. No cervical lymph nodes are detected. The metastatic evaluation is negative. A biopsy is performed, and the report shows squamous cell carcinoma. What would be the further best treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Combined Surgery & Radiotherapy

  • T3: Tumor invades any of the following: Bone of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus, subcutaneous tissues, floor or medial wall of the Orbit, pterygoid fossa, and ethmoid sinuses.
  • No metastasis or nodal involvement is making it stage III (T3No Mo).
  • Treatment of choice for carcinoma maxillary sinus stage III (T3 N0 M0): Combined Surgery & R.T.
  •  Research has shown that surgical excision with clear margins is the standard of care and results in the lowest recurrence rate.
  •  This is often done by an external approach, including lateral rhinotomy, partial rhinectomy, and total rhinectomy.
  • Patients who have insufficient margins are at significantly increased risk of local or regional recurrence of disease, even if radiation is given afterwards.
  • Total rhinectomy is often deferred with a preference for radiation therapy for multiple reasons. Patients may be concerned about the cosmetic appearance and emotional impact of such an extensive surgery. 
  • Early cases with Stage I and II squamous cell carcinomas are treated with only surgery or radiation with similar results.
  • Chemoradiation- Used for large and inoperable tumors.

 

Stage Grouping of Cancer of Maxillary and Ethmoid Sinuses
Stage 1 T1 N0 M0
Stage II T2 N0 M0
Stage III T3 N0 M0 T1 or T2 or T3 with N1 M0
Stage IV A T4 N0 M0 T4 N1 M0
Stage IV B Any T N2 M0 Any T N3 M0
Stage IV C Any T Any N M1

Option A: Surgery only

  • Surgery and radiotherapy are used to treat maxillary sinus carcinoma stage III. Surgery alone can't give the results required.

Option B: Radiotherapy

  • Radiotherapy alone is not enough for treating maxillary carcinoma stage III.
  • The best treatment is a combination of both surgery and radiotherapy.

Option D: Chemoradiotherapy

  • Chemoradiotherapy has not been able to show promising results for treating maxillary carcinoma.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female presents to the clinic complaining of a throat lump for the last 4 weeks. There is no difficulty in swallowing or respiration. The feeling of a lump is more marked between meals. The patient is worried that the lump may be some cancer. Her pharyngeal examination is completely unremarkable and shows no pathology. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Globus Pharyngeus

  • This patient, with a feeling of a lump that is more marked between meals, a constant worry that the lump may be some cancer, and a normal pharyngeal examination, most likely has Globus Pharyngeus.
  • The significant features of globus pharyngeus include:
  • It is a functional disorder.
  • The patient complains of a "lump" in the throat.
  • Not true dysphagia. The feeling of lump is more marked between the meals rather than during meals. Such a patient may have a fear of cancer in the throat.
  • Clinical examination of the pharynx, larynx, and tongue base is normal.
  • Treatment- Reassurance to the patient when no cause has been found.

OPTION B: Carcinoma Oropharynx

  • Earlier symptoms are sore throat, feeling of a lump in the throat, and slight discomfort in swallowing. Late features are referred to as a pain in the ear, dysphagia, bleeding from the mouth, and change in speech quality (hot potato voice).

OPTION C: Carcinoma esophagus

  • Progressive dysphagia is the main feature. Dysphagia is to solids at first and then progresses to liquids as well. It leads to weight loss and emaciation of the patient. Pain is referred to the back.

OPTION D: Pharyngeal pouch

  • Dysphagia is a prominent feature. It appears after a few swallows when the pouch gets filled with food and presses on the esophagus. Undigested food may regurgitate at night when the patient is recumbent, causing cough and aspiration pneumonia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with a complaint of recurrent aspiration for the past month. He underwent lateral skull base surgery a few months back and had experience aspiration episodes ever since. There is no change in the voice of the patient. Which of the following nerve is most likely injured during surgery?
questions.solution:
The correct option is: 4. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve

Explanation:

During lateral skull base surgery, several important nerves and structures can be at risk of injury. In this case, the patient's recurrent aspiration suggests that there may be an issue with the function of the vocal cords, leading to difficulty in preventing food or liquid from entering the airway during swallowing. Let's go through the options:

  1. Unilateral vagus nerve: The vagus nerve is a cranial nerve that plays a vital role in the function of the digestive system, heart, and respiratory system. If the unilateral vagus nerve were injured, the patient might experience various symptoms, such as difficulty swallowing, voice changes, and impaired digestive function. However, the specific symptom of recurrent aspiration without voice changes makes this option less likely in this case.

  2. Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve is another cranial nerve involved in swallowing and sensory functions in the throat. While an injury to this nerve can lead to problems with swallowing, it is less likely to cause recurrent aspiration without any voice changes.

  3. Unilateral superior laryngeal nerve: The superior laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve that supplies motor and sensory innervation to the cricothyroid muscle and a small area of the laryngeal mucosa. An injury to the unilateral superior laryngeal nerve may cause voice changes, especially affecting the ability to reach high notes in singing, but it is less likely to cause recurrent aspiration without other voice-related symptoms.

  4. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve: The recurrent laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve that supplies motor innervation to most of the intrinsic muscles of the larynx (voice box). Unilateral injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve can lead to vocal cord paralysis on the affected side, resulting in a hoarse or breathy voice and difficulty in closing the vocal cords during swallowing. This condition, known as vocal cord paresis or paralysis, can cause recurrent aspiration as the vocal cord on the affected side cannot adequately close the airway during swallowing, allowing food or liquid to enter the trachea.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the physician's office with complaints of hoarseness of voice for the past month. She is a biology teacher and says that due to workload, she used to take extra classes to complete the syllabus on time. On laryngoscopic examination, the findings seen are as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Vocal nodule

The patient presents with hoarseness of voice and a history of occupational voice abuse (biology teacher); based on this and the laryngeal examination, she likely has vocal nodules, i.e., singer's/screamer's nodule.

  • They appear symmetrically on the free edge of the vocal cords, most commonly at the junction of the anterior 1/3rd and the posterior 2/3rd.
  • They are caused by trauma to the vocal cords due to chronic vocal abuse, which results in edema and hemorrhage in the submucosal space, which undergoes hyalinization and fibrosis.
  • The patient presents with hoarseness of voice and voice fatigue.
  • The early vocal nodule is managed conservatively by patient education against voice abuse and using the voice properly. This treatment can completely disappear many nodules.
  • For large nodules or those of persistent standing, microlaryngoscopic surgery is done.

Option B: Vocal polyp

  • Appear as unilateral and localized swelling of the membranous part of the vocal cords.
  • Appear as soft, pedunculated mass

Option C: Reinke's edema

  • Also called smoker's larynx
  • Describes the vocal cords when they become chronically and irreversibly swollen
  • Bilateral and diffuse symmetrical swelling of the whole membranous part of the vocal cords
  • Occurs due to edematous epithelial hypertrophy and polypoidal degeneration
  • Vocal cords appear as fusiform swellings with a pale translucent appearance and prominent superficial vessels showing hyperemic and hypertrophic ventricular bands.

Option D: Vocal papilloma

  • Adult-onset papilloma usually occurs as a single, small mass that does not recur after surgical removal.
  • More common in males than females and arises at age 30-50.
  • It arises from half of the vocal cord or the anterior commissure.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presented to the ophthalmology clinic with a history of bilateral red sore eyes for 6 weeks. His family history is insignificant. His vitals are stable. On examination of his eyes, a characteristic finding is noted, which is shown in the given image. Which of the following diseases/syndrome would have this particular finding?
questions.solution:
Option A: Keratoconus

  • The given image shows prominent corneal nerves, which are seen in the keratoconus due to thinning of the cornea.

  • Prominent or enlarged corneal nerves are linear stromal opacities that extend from the corneoscleral junction towards the corneal centre in a radial manner.

  • Keratoconus is a noninflammatory corneal condition in which the cornea becomes thinner than normal and develops a conic shape, bulging outward at the centre.

  • Its symptoms include:

    • Progressive decrease in visual acuity.

    • Myopia

    • Astigmatism

    • Photophobia.

  • Slit lamp examination shows protrusion and thinning of the cornea.

Option B: Von Hippel-Lindau disease

  • The common findings of Von Hippel-Lindau disease include:

    • Pheochromocytomas

    • Bilateral renal cell carcinomas

    • Hemangioblastoma in the retina.

  • Prominent corneal nerves are not seen in Von Hippel-Lindau disease.

Option C: Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 1

  • Multiple endocrine neoplasias (MEN) 1 is characterized by:

    • Pituitary tumours

    • Pancreatic tumours

    • Parathyroid adenomas

  • Prominent corneal nerves are seen in MEN-2A and MEN-2B, not MEN 1.

Option D: Sturge weber syndrome

  • Sturge weber syndrome is a rare congenital vascular disorder caused by somatic (and not inherited) mutations in the GNAQ gene that result in capillary-venous malformations.

  • The clinical manifestations of Sturge-Weber syndrome include:

    • Port-wine stain (nevus flammeus)

    • Leptomeningeal angiomas

    • Recurrent seizures

    • Intellectual disability

    • Episcleral angiomas cause increased intraocular pressure and early-onset glaucoma.

  • Prominent corneal nerves are not seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome.

questions.text: A 23 yr old male was recently diagnosed with herpetic keratitis. Which of the following is used in the treatment of such patients?
questions.solution:
Option D: Idoxuridine

  • HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus) keratitis is an infection of the cornea caused by HSV.
  • The infection usually heals without damaging the eye, but more severe infections can lead to scarring of the cornea or blindness.
  • Idoxuridine is a pyrimidine analogue antiviral used to treat viral eye infections, including herpes simplex keratitis.
  • The drug of choice for herpetic keratitis is Acyclovir Q (topical)
  • Other antiviral drugs used are
    • Idoxuridine
    • Trifluorothymidine
    • Vidarabine

Option A: Analgesics

  • Not used in herpetic keratitis.

Option B: Atropine

  • Not used in herpetic keratitis.
  • Atropine sulfate eye drops are used to dilate the pupil before eye exams. It is also used to treat an eye condition called amblyopia (lazy eyes) and other eye conditions (e.g., cycloplegia).

Option C: Steroids

  • Not used in herpetic keratitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the ophthalmology department with three days history of mild irritation, watering, and localized redness in the right eye, as shown below. Her past medical history reveals that she is a known case of hypertension and takes lisinopril 5mg daily. On history, it is confirmed that she is compliant with her medication. Her blood pressure at the visit is 125/85 mmHg. The resident ophthalmologist wants to differentiate between scleritis and episcleritis. He instills 10% phenylephrine, and there is quick blanching of the vessels. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Nodular episcleritis:

  • The image shows a purplish nodule on the medial epicanthus with surrounding injected blood vessels.
  • They are not reaching the limbus, though.
  • This is a presentation of nodular episcleritis.
  • Vasoconstricting eye drops (phenylephrine) allow episcleritis to be differentiated from scleritis. They cause blanching of the vessels.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anterior uveitis:

  • It affects the iris at the front of the eye and not the medial epicanthus with surrounding injected blood vessels.

Option B - Nodular scleritis:

  • Phenylephrine drops do not cause blanching of the vessels in scleritis.
  • There is a blue coloration of the eyes (deep inflammation).

Option D - Scleromalacia perforans:

  • Scleromalacia perforans is an anterior necrotizing scleritis without inflammation.
  • It is a rare eye disorder causing damage to episcleral and scleral vessels.
  • Usually associated with autoimmune disorders.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with progressive deterioration of vision. He also complained of missing things out of the corner of his eye. On examination, the pupillary reaction is sluggish, and IOP is normal. Fundoscopy shows a large and deep cup with progressive excavation or 'cupping' of the optic nerve head from retinal nerve fibre layer loss resulting in corresponding visual field deficits. Visual field reveals paracentral scotoma. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Normal tension glaucoma

  • The question describes a patient with normal IOP but optic disc changes and visual field changes suggestive of glaucoma. Hence the answer is normal tension glaucoma.
  • Normal-tension glaucoma is a characteristic glaucomatous optic neuropathy with intraocular pressures in the normal range. It is a common condition and can lead to bilateral blindness.

Option A: Neovascular glaucoma

  • Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) is a severe form of secondary glaucoma characterized by the proliferation of fibrovascular tissue in the anterior chamber angle.
  • This patient presents with features of normal tension glaucoma.

Option B: Primary Open-angle glaucoma

  • Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is a subset of glaucomas defined by an open, normal-appearing anterior chamber angle and raised intraocular pressure (IOP) with no other underlying disease.

Option D: Absolute glaucoma

  • An eye that has lost all vision and uncontrolled pressure is sometimes called "absolute glaucoma". In such situations, the mechanism of underlying pressure elevation may be apparent (e.g., neovascular or uveitic glaucoma), whereas in other cases, it may not.

questions.text: A forty-six-year-old patient presents to your clinic with the complaint of visual difficulties in his right eye. He was recently diagnosed with a cataract in his right eye and was operated on for it with the placement of an intraocular lens. Eye examinations are performed. When the patient is asked to look from side to side, a pendulum motion resembling the action of a windshield wiper is noted. What is the cause of the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Malposition of lens

  • The pendular movement of the eye is characteristic of Windshield wiper syndrome.
  • Windshield wiper syndrome is seen due to the malposition of the lens.
  • This is due to the intraocular lens's to-and-fro movement with the head's movement.
  • Windshield Wiper syndrome mostly occurs after cataract extraction with a posterior chamber intraocular lens when the lens is too short and moves in its position. 

Option A: Dislocation of intraocular lens

  • Dislocation of the intraocular lens (IOL) is a rare but serious complication of cataract surgery.
  • Dislocation because of total zonular or capsular instability.
  • Symptoms include a decrease or change in vision, diplopia and glare, and patients may have ocular pain or headaches from intermittent angle-closure and inflammation. 
  • This is not associated with the windshield wiper sign.

Option B: Posterior capsular opacification

  • Posterior capsular opacification (PCO) is also known as after cataract.
  • The most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery occurs in 20-25% of patients.
  • This occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that remain in the capsular bag following cataract surgery.
  • This is not associated with the windshield wiper sign.

Option C: Reaction to the lens material

  • The reaction to lens material depends on the degree of biocompatibility of the lens.
  • Low biocompatibility can cause a series of inflammatory reactions.
  • This is not associated with the windshield wiper sign.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the eye clinic with complaints of photophobia, blurred vision, and floaters for the past 3 days. The patient also has a past medical history of an inflammatory condition for which he takes steroids on and off. The general physical examination was unremarkable except for a few round skin lesions on the shins. On fundal examination, snowball opacities and snow banking appearance are observed. What is the most relevant blood investigation in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Option D: ACE levels in the blood

  • Based on the history and the clinical signs and symptoms given in the scenario, the most likely diagnosis is intermediate uveitis secondary to sarcoidosis. Therefore, ACE levels in the blood will be the most relevant blood investigation. ACE levels will be elevated in 50% to 80% of cases with active sarcoidosis. The finding of a high ACE level helps to confirm the diagnosis.
  • Intermediate uveitis is also known as pars planitis.
  • The most common cause of pars planitis is idiopathic.
  • The second most common cause is sarcoidosis.
  • The most common symptom is the presence of floaters.
  • On the fundus examination, snowball opacities are seen, which may join together to form snow banking, a Hallmark Feature.
  • Snowballs are the inflammatory cells from pars plana thrown into the vitreous, causing vitreous floaters. These gravitate and sink, forming snow banking.

Option A: ANA

  • Based on the history and the clinical signs and symptoms given in the scenario, the most likely diagnosis is intermediate uveitis secondary to sarcoidosis. Therefore, ANA will not be the relevant investigation for this scenario.
  • An ANA test is a blood test for antinuclear antibodies.
  • It's normal to have a few antinuclear antibodies. But a large titer may be a sign of an autoimmune disorder. 
  • For example:
    • Systemic lupus erythematosus.
    • Rheumatoid arthritis.
    • Scleroderma.
    • Sjogren’s syndrome.
    • Autoimmune hepatitis.

Option B: Blood glucose

  • Based on the history and the clinical signs and symptoms given in the scenario, the most likely diagnosis is intermediate uveitis secondary to sarcoidosis. Therefore, blood glucose levels will not be the relevant investigation for this scenario.
  • A blood glucose test is a blood test that screens for diabetes by measuring the level of glucose in a person's blood. A fasting blood sugar level of 99 mg/dL or lower is normal, 100 to 125 mg/dL indicates prediabetes, and 126 mg/dL or higher indicates diabetes.

Option C:  ESR

  • Based on the history and the clinical signs and symptoms given in the scenario, the most likely diagnosis is intermediate uveitis secondary to sarcoidosis. ESR is the erythrocyte sedimentation rate and will be raised in sarcoidosis along with ACE levels.
  • ESR is not a specific sarcoidosis marker and will be raised in every other inflammatory condition. So, in this case, the relevant blood investigation will be ACE levels.
  • ESR measures the rate at which red blood cells in a test tube separate from blood serum over time, becoming sediment in the bottom of the test tube.
  • The ESR increases with more inflammation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the physician with complaints of progressive loss of vision in both eyes over the past 8 months. The patient further gives a history that he has had blurry vision during this time and glare in the evenings. His blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg at the time of the check-up. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and raised serum cholesterol. A slit lamp shows cloudy opacities of the lenses bilaterally. His surgery was planned. A retrobulbar block was given in the retrobulbar space. Which of the following is a part of the space involved in this case?

choices.text: All parts of Tenon’s capsule enclosing the globe

questions.solution:
Option B: All parts of Tenon’s capsule enclosing the globe

  • This is a case of cataracts in which the patient presents with progressive loss of vision in both eyes over the past 8 months. The patient complains that he has had a blurry vision during this time and glare in the evenings. A slit lamp shows cloudy opacities of the lenses bilaterally.
  • Equatorial veins are not a part of the retrobulbar space of the orbit.
  • Retrobulbar space/ central space / muscular cone.
  • Contents: extraocular muscles with intermuscular septa.
  • Includes optic nerve.
  • Boundaries:
    • anteriorly - by the posterior part of Tenon’s capsule enclosing the globe.
    • peripherally - by four recti muscles and their intermuscular septa.
    • posteriorly - continuous with the peripheral space.
  • Site of the retrobulbar injection.
  • Tumours lying here produce axial proptosis.

Option A: Intra-ocular muscles with intermuscular septa

  • Retrobulbar space doesn’t contain intra-ocular muscles with intermuscular septa.
  • It contains extraocular muscles with intermuscular septa.

Option C: 7th cranial nerve

  • Retrobulbar space contains the following cranial nerves.
    • Optic nerve - CN II
    • Trochlear nerve - CN IV
    • Abducens nerve - CN VI
  • ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Retrobulbar space does not contain the facial nerve (CN VII).

Option D: Vorticose veins

  • The vorticose veins, also known as the vortex veins, drain the ocular choroid.
  • They provide an important clinical landmark for identifying the ocular equator.
  •  Vorticose veins run posteriorly in the sclera exiting the eye well posterior to the equator.

​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 70-year-old school teacher presents to the ophthalmologist with sudden onset of blurring of vision from the last 6 hours. Her examination reveals that she had isolated superior rectus paresis. Magnetic resonance imaging reveals a small-sized infarct in the oculomotor nucleus on the contralateral side. Which of the following features can be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Compensatory chin elevation

  • Based on the symptoms of blurring of vision, isolated superior rectus paresis on examination, and infarct in the oculomotor nucleus on MRI, the patient is likely suffering from superior rectus muscle palsy.
  • Compensatory chin elevation is a squint in which one of the eyes deviates downwards when both eyes are open.
  • The eye deviates downward and blurs vision without the upward pull by a superior rectus muscle.
  • To compensate for this blurring of vision, the patient tends to develop a compensatory chin lift.
  • In this, the patient keeps his chin lifted to align his eyes and focus on an object without experiencing blurred vision.

Option A: Hypertropia

  • It is the deviation of the eyes in an upward direction.
  • It is caused by inferior rectus palsy.
  • It is not present in superior rectus palsy.

Option B: Floaters

  • It is a condition in which a patient sees small blobs of light floating in his field of vision.
  • Floaters are primarily present in retinal disorders.
  • They are uncommon in other ocular conditions.

Option D: Decreased abduction

  • Abduction or adduction of the eye is governed by the eye's lateral rectus and oblique muscles.
  • While the superior rectus is responsible for the upward movement of the eye.
  • The paralysis of the superior rectus muscle does not affect adduction or abduction.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with a blistering rash on the face and scalp for the past three months. The rash appears as fragile blisters which break easily, leaving crusted erythematous ulcers on the skin. He also complains of pain and itching. The rash does not involve the oral cavity. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Skin examination shows shallow erosions on the scalp, face, and the right armpit with an erythematous base. Image shows the result of applying pressure in the perilesional area:



Bulla spread sign is also positive. On direct immunofluorescence, desmoglein 1 antibody is present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pemphigus Foliaceus

  • The above patient with bullous lesions, positive bullous spread sign and antibodies against desmoglein 1, most likely suggest pemphigus foliaceus
  • Pemphigus describes a group of autoimmune intraepidermal blistering diseases of the skin and the mucous membranes.
  • Three types are:
    1. Pemphigus. Vulgaris (the most common type)
    2. Pemphigus. Foliaceus
    3. Paraneoplastic Pemphigus
  • Pemphigus Foliaceus is differentiated from the other 2 types by the milder/benign course of the disease with little or no involvement of the mucous membranes. Labs show the following results:
  • Diffuse immunofluorescence: Perilesional skin biopsy demonstrates intraepidermal IgG and C3 deposition on surface keratinocytes.
  • Indirect immunofluorescence: Circulating IgG antibodies against keratinocytes cell surface antigen.
  • Autoantigens: Antibodies (Ab) directed against desmoglein-1

Option A: Dermatitis herpetiformis

Associated with celiac disease

  • Antigen: Transglutaminase 3
  • Clinical features: Itchy papulovesicular lesions of the extremities, knees, elbows, and buttocks.
  • IgA deposition at papillary dermis in a granular pattern known as picket fence appearance.

Option B: Pemphigus. Vulgaris

  • It affects both skin and mucosa.
  • Antigen: desmoglein 3 (desmoglein -3)
  • Clinical features: Flaccid bullae over the normal or erythematous base with mucosal involvement.
  • Intraepidermal IgG, C3. Biopsy shows a Chicken-wire pattern/fish-net pattern/lace-like pattern.
  • Defect in desmoglein-3: In early disease, only desmoglein-3 is involved, but in late disease, along with desmoglein-3, desmoglein -1 is also involved.

Option D: Bullous Pemphigoid

  • It is an autoimmune sub-epidermal blistering disorder
  • Clinical feature: Tense bullae with perilesional erythema [redness around lesion] are seen, which heals with Milia formation [Milia: small keratin cysts. Sometimes seen de-novo over face].
  • The Nikolsky sign is negative, but the Bulla Spread sign is positive.

questions.text: A 6-day-old male infant presents to the clinic accompanied by his mother with a complaint of purpuric skin lesions on the upper body since birth. During pregnancy, the mother had a flu-like illness with a maculopapular rash on her face and body. Physical examination of the neonate reveals a low birth weight, cataracts, and a grade II/VI continuous murmur most audible in the left infraclavicular region. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Congenital Rubella Syndrome

  • Cardiac manifestations, a "blueberry muffin" rash, and the maternal history strongly suggest congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).
  • Blueberry muffins eruptions- Generalized dark blue to magenta, non-blanchable, indurated, hemispheric purpuric papules.
  • Lesions favor the head, neck, and trunk.
  • Triad of congenital rubella:
    • Cataracts
    • Congenital heart defects (most commonly patent ductus arteriosus, a loud continuous murmur is heard in the left infra-clavicular region)
    • Bilateral sensorineural Deafness (cochlear defect)
  • Late manifestations include:
  • Intellectual disability
  • Skeletal abnormalities
  • Endocrine disorders
  • Vascular diseases

Option A: Congenital Cytomegalovirus infection

It is characterized by:

  • Jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly
  • IUGR
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Sensorineural Deafness
  • Periventricular calcifications
  • Petechiae and purpura (blueberry muffin rash)
  • Microcephaly
  • Seizures
Option B: Congenital Syphilis
 
Early Congenital Syphilis Late Congenital Syphilis
  • Extremely variable.
  • Most infants are asymptomatic at birth.
  • 2/3 manifest around 3-8 weeks.
  • By three months, most infants manifest.
  • Contagious.
  • Delayed consequences of localized inflammatory processes established at sites of treponemal infection during an early stage of the disease.
  • Seen beyond 2nd year of life.
  • Correspond to Tertiary stage of acquired syphilis.
  • Non-infectious.
  • BUENO'S TRIAD: Snuffles, Palmar & plantar bullae, Splenomegaly.
  • MARFAN'S DIAGNOSTIC PENTAD: Bueno's Triad, Pseudoparalysis, Cutaneous syphilis.

HUTCHINSON'S TRIAD- Pathognomonic sign

  • Interstitial keratitis
  • Eighth nerve deafness
  • Hutchinson's teeth: Upper central incisors- shorter, widely spaced, have a notch in biting edge- peg or screwdriver shape.

CUTANEOUS LESIONS

  • Vesiculobullous rash: Pemphigus syphilitics – earliest,
  • Rash: Large pink macules, papules, plaques,
  • Condyloma lata,
  • Nail changes: Paronychia, claw nail, shedding of nails,
  • Hair changes: Alopecia, brittle sparse hair.

MUCOSAL LESIONS

  • Rhinitis (snuffles): Earliest watery nasal discharge thicker, purulent and bloody - Breathing and suckling difficulties
  • Pharyngitis & obstruction of the larynx occurs with characteristic hoarse cry (syphilitic aphonia) and cough.

SKELETAL INVOLVEMENT

  • Osteochondritis of long bones: earliest (upper end of tibia, the distal end of radius, and ulna).
  • Pseudo-paralysis of Parrot: (symptomatic- pain and tenderness)
  • Syphilitic Dactylitis: Painless, fusiform swelling of the digits; osteochondritis of phalanges.

SYPHILITIC STIGMATA

  • Frontal bossing.
  • Hot cross bun deformity- Parietal bone inv.
  • Olympian or beetled brow.
  • A high cranium or "tower skull."
  • Saddle-nose deformity.
  • Short maxilla, high palatal arch, prominent mandible- bulldog jaw.
  • Scaphoid shape scapula.
  • Circumoral radiating furrows (rhagades).
  • Hoarseness of voice.
  • Sabre tibia: Anterior bending of tibia
  • Hutchinson's teeth

Option D: Congenital Toxoplasmosis

  • Classic triad
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Hydrocephalus
    • Diffuse intracranial calcifications (ring-enhancing lesions)
  • Petechiae and purpura (blueberry muffin rash)

questions.text:
A 63-year-old farmer presents to the clinic for the evaluation of a lesion on the back of his hands. He complains that the lesion bleeds and has been present for the past few months. On examination, the following lesion is seen as shown below: 



Considering the most likely diagnosis in this patient, which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Excisional biopsy

The following points are suggestive of the probable diagnosis of Squamous cell carcinoma

  • Old age.
  • Warty irregular surface with crusting.
  • Rapid growth and bleeding.
  • Photo exposed area with surrounding evidence of solar damage.

Excision biopsy with histology is an essential step to perform in the evaluation.

Option A: Cryotherapy

  • This patient most likely has squamous cell carcinoma
  • The best next step is to perform an excisional biopsy
  • Cryotherapy does not provide tissue for histology

Option B: Silver nitrate cautery

  • This patient most likely has squamous cell carcinoma
  • The best next step is to perform an excisional biopsy
  • Silver nitrate cautery is not suitable

Option C: Salicylic acid

  • This patient most likely has squamous cell carcinoma
  • The best next step is to perform an excisional biopsy
  • Salicylic acid use is not suitable here.

questions.text: A 6-year-old female child visits the clinic accompanied by her mother with a complaint of a progressive bluish lesion over the left side of the forehead and left eye for the past several months. She has no chronic medical condition and takes no medications. On examination, an irregular bluish lesion is found on the left forehead and conjunctiva of the left eye. The contralateral side is spared. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Nevus of Ota

  • It is characterized by a unilateral bluish-grey skin discoloration secondary to entrapment of the melanocytes in the upper third of the dermis.
  • The most common distribution is along the ophthalmic and maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve.
  • It is generally asymptomatic.
  • Spontaneous resolution is seen in most cases.
  • Laser treatment can be used for persistent cases.

Option B: Naevus of Ito

  • It presents as unilateral, asymptomatic, blue or brown skin pigmentation within the acromioclavicular and upper chest area (involving the side of the neck, the supraclavicular and scapular areas, and the shoulder region).

Option C: Becker's nevus

  • It presents as irregular macular pigmentation associated with the development and fusion of new macules forming a geographical contour.
  • Terminal hairs are present on and around the lesion.
  • The most common sites are the shoulder, anterior chest, or scapular region.

Option D: Mongolian spots

  • It is characterized by a bluish skin discoloration that is commonly present at birth or sometimes appears shortly after birth.
  • It is a benign condition and is typically not associated with any underlying pathology.
  • The most common location of the lesion is the lower back.
